text.0: Thank you very much. This is a question to both parties, please. Having read the file and various submissions by the parties, I still don't exactly picture how the person at the material time, the applicant, moved in the prison. So I really would like to have a better understanding. I assume that after having breakfast and having cleaned whatever he had to clean, was he, was the cell door open and he could leave wherever he wanted? And then, assuming that this is the case, where was he able to go? I understand that there is a courtyard. There are some gym-like facilities. But I don't, assuming that the same applies to all other inmates, how many of them are at the same time playing basketball, reading in the library? I just don't understand because I don't have a full picture. So if you could explain to me or to us what actually happens, how many people are there at the same time, what happens if it's raining? So all of them have to leave the courtyard, and so on and so forth. It would be extremely helpful to understand whether really he is not all the time, as the applicant's lawyer claims, is locked up. So even if he's not locked up, I don't understand what exactly happens to him if he wishes to go one place or another within the prison. And what is the size of those places compared to the number of all the inmates wishing to do the same thing he might wish? Thank you.
text.1: Thank you, Mr. President. My question is addressed to the government. According to Croatian law, and I refer to Section 74 of the Enforcement of Prison Sentences Act, there shall be a minimum space of four square meters and 10 cubic meters per prisoner in each dormitory. This looks like to me as an absolute minimum approach to the size of the available space to each prisoner. Now, my question to the government is the following. How can the government today defend before this court a flexible overall approach, a flexible overall standard, which is not only contradictory vis-a-vis the national law, but also with the CPT standards to which the government itself has referred to? Thank you very much.
text.2: A very brief question to both parties. It's in average, how many hours a day is the prisoner locked up in his cell? I mean, you can give me a figure. Thank you.
text.3: Thank you, Mr. President. As the parties are aware, this case was relinquished to the Grand Chamber, so the convention stipulates that we are dealing with a serious question affecting the interpretation of the convention and is on that basis, and due to some of the arguments made here today, that I would like to pose a question, mainly to the applicants, but I would like, with the permission of the president, to ask the government and the third-party intervener to maybe comment. There was some notion or suggestion here that we, in examining the applicability issue, should look at the implications, the possible consequences of that approach, and that issue is not dealt with directly by the applicants in their brief, so that's why I put forward the question. And I would like to focus here on what the applicants consider to be the possible consequences of that approach in the following terms. We see that freedom of information legislation sometimes provides, or often provides, for absolute limitations under domestic law. In certain circumstances, there simply is not a document, for example, dealing with national security issues, law enforcement issues, they are simply excluded from the domestic right. How would the applicants invite the court to deal with those types of situation, assuming that there is a right under Article 10, and thus, in general, Article 10 would necessitate a proportionality-type analysis? How would we, the court, be able to deal with those kinds of situations in particular? And on that note as well, would the court, assuming that such a right would be recognized, what about notions such as what constitutes a public authority, a quasi-public authority, an official document? Would these kinds of notions have to be autonomously interpreted by the court, or do you foresee a possible different way the court could proceed on that basis? My second question is linked to an argument made by the applicants here today. They invite us to look at, the court to look at, other international instruments and decisions. The Inter-American Court of Human Rights, the UN Human Rights Committee, if I'm not mistaken, the provisions they are dealing with explicitly mention a right to seek information, which, as you know, Article 10 does not. Can the applicants confront that issue in particular, and could they tell the court, are there any examples either in international norms, or even in constitutional norms, where the right of access to documents has been considered an inherent rule in a similar textual formulation like Article 10 of the Convention? Thank you.
text.4: Thank you very much, Mr. President. My question is mainly addressed to the government, but it is also open to the applicants if they wish to comment. According to Article 31, Paragraph 3C of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties, the court must take into account any relevant rules and principles of international law applicable in the relations between the contracting parties, in our case, Hungary. As you know, this provision has been repeatedly invoked and applied by our court as an important rule of interpretation of the European Convention of Human Rights. The UK government has correctly referred to Article 31 of the Vienna Convention. Now, Hungary is bound by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights of 1966, whose Article 19 explicitly recognized the right to seek information. Hungary has also ratified the Council of Europe Convention on access to official documents. Furthermore, Hungary is a member of the EU whose Charter of Fundamental Rights and relevant 2001 regulation recognized the right of access to documents of the EU institutions. So in view of those apparently relevant rules and principles of international and European law binding upon or accepted by Hungary, how do you see the functioning of Article 31, paragraph C, of the Vienna Convention in the present case? Thank you very much.
text.5: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. Ma question s'adresse également au gouvernement hongrois et aussi au requérant, s'il veut en faire partie, s'il veut commenter. Quelque chose est lié à la question qui a été mise par le juge Sicilianos. Donc, on connaît que la première règle d'interprétation du droit international qui existe dans la Convention de Vienne, c'est la règle qui est prévue par l'article 31, normalement l'article 31, paragraphe 3, et qui fait référence aux autres instruments internationaux qui ont été déjà cités et à leur jurisprudence. Et on connaît aussi que l'interprétation des droits de l'homme, des traités des droits de l'homme, des traités multilatéraux des droits de l'homme, est différente par rapport aux traités qui ne sont pas, qui ne concernent pas les droits de l'homme, vu que dans les traités des droits de l'homme, la question de réciprocité ne s'applique pas. Donc, normalement, on dit dans la doctrine que dans les traités des droits de l'homme, on n'a pas le même type d'interprétation vu le fait que les intentions des partis, et ici je fais référence aux travaux préparatoires dont le gouvernement britannique a fait référence, ne jouent pas le même rôle comme ils jouent dans les traités bilatéraux ou les traités multilatéraux qui ne traitent pas les droits de l'homme. Donc voilà une question qui est reconnue dans la doctrine et qui fait la différence entre les deux types d'interprétation dans les traités multilatéraux qui traitent les droits de l'homme et dans les traités multilatéraux qui ne traitent pas les droits de l'homme. Et en relation avec cette question, je voulais poser une question plus concrète au gouvernement hongrois parce que dans le paragraphe 11 de votre mémoire, le gouvernement hongrois se réfère au fait que dans l'affaire Taraschuk, ils n'étaient pas capables de contester l'applicabilité de l'article 10 vu qu'ils n'étaient pas partis dans l'affaire Mackey contre la République tchèque. Mais comme on reconnaît dans la doctrine et comme le Lord Brown l'avait expliqué dans l'affaire Sugar, on regarde ces trois affaires, ça veut dire l'affaire Mackey, l'affaire Taraschuk et l'affaire Kennedy, comme une trilogie de notre cours, ça veut dire trois affaires qui reconnaissent d'une manière progressive ce type de droit. Et ma question au gouvernement hongrois est la suivante. Est-ce qu'au moment où l'affaire Taraschuk était devant le gouvernement hongrois, pourquoi est l'affaire Mackey précédente à l'affaire Taraschuk de l'année 2006, pourquoi est-ce qu'en ce moment-là, le gouvernement hongrois n'a pas contesté comme il le fait aujourd'hui l'applicabilité de l'article 10 à ce genre de question? La deuxième question que je pose au gouvernement hongrois et qui est plus concrète et qui vise aussi l'article 31, le paragraphe 3, se réfère au droit de l'Union européenne. Et le gouvernement hongrois donne plusieurs exemples du droit de l'Union européenne concernant la protection des données, mais ils ne font pas référence, par exemple, à une affaire qui est très importante pour le droit de l'Union européenne, notamment pour l'article 8 de la charte des droits fondamentaux, ça veut dire « austerite contre le Randfund » où on sait qu'il y avait un accès concernant les données qui étaient plus privées concernant les salaires vu que le requérant demandait un contrôle de dépense publique. Donc, quelle est la position du gouvernement hongrois par rapport à cette jurisprudence de la Cour de Luxembourg et par rapport au fait que la Hongrie est membre de l'Union européenne et qu'elle est soumise aux dispositions et aux sources du droit européen? Je vous remercie beaucoup, Monsieur le Président.
text.6: Thank you, Mr. President. My question goes, first of all, to the representatives of the government, but of course, the applicants can also comment on it. And the question relates to — it's a factual question. It relates to a broader context of the applicant situation. Most of the police departments provided the information to the applicant, which the applicant requested. However, a couple of departments refused to provide it, and that's why we have the case here. And the basis for that, according to the interpretation, was that the information contained private data which cannot be disclosed under the domestic law. That's what the government defended, this position. I have a question which then splits into probably four questions, and I will now tell all of them in certain consequence. First of all, are there any provisions, and if so, what provisions in the Hungarian domestic law regarding liability for disclosure by public officials of information which is not to — which cannot be disclosed under the domestic law, which is protected, such information as private data? Second, if the answer to this first question is in the positive, that such provisions exist, and I believe that they must exist, then have these provisions been applied to any public official, any police department that disclosed the information which was requested by the applicant? My third question is, if the answer to this question is no, if it is in the negative, then why they have not been applied, if they have not been applied? And the fourth question, or the fourth part of this big question is, if they have not been applied because persons concerned have not initiated this application, still, have there been any ex post facto — I mean ex post facto, that is, after the final judgment of the Supreme Court — instructions by the executive or by whichever authority to the police departments that they should not disclose such information in the future if such information is requested? Thank you.
text.7: Thank you, Mr. President. The question is addressed to the government, but the applicants are free to react to this question. Government refer to the continuous legal relationship inherent in this type of welfare or pension schemes. Now, I would like to ask two questions, factual questions related to this. First, assuming that Act 191 of 2011 does not exist, did not enter into force, would the applicant be eligible on the basis of her medical condition as established in 2012, although she was not a recipient of benefits at that point of time? So once again, the hypothetical is, without the new law under the old system, was would have been a possibility to provide her benefit. The second question is somewhat similar to this one. There was a change in 2014 regarding the years in service which are to be taken into consideration. Those, to some extent, if I may call them, are more favorable. The applicant, nevertheless, if I understand correctly, was still not eligible. Now, assume that someone in her situation, that is to say, denied of the benefit in 2012, but satisfying the new conditions of 2014, would that person be eligible to be a recipient of the benefit from 2014 onwards? Thank you.
text.8: Thank you very much, President. I would have first two questions to the applicants. My first question is the withdrawal of the disability pension as of 1st February 2010 was brought to the labor court, which decided on 1st April 2011. And as I understand, the case was not brought further to any other Hungarian court or the Hungarian Constitutional Court nor to the European Court of Human Rights. And I would just like why. And my second question is on what financial means did the applicant live after the withdrawal as of 1st February 2010? And if she had no financial means as a basis for existence, why was the case not argued under Article 3? My other three questions are of quite a technical nature and more addressed to the government. So in as far as the applicant has contributed to the disability pension, is there a specific contribution to disability pension or covers it both disability and old age pension? Or is there a differentiation? And the next question is, if the pension had not been withdrawn, would it be transferred, the disability pension, into an old age pension at a certain moment? And if yes, when? And last question, if she now, is she still eligible to get an old age pension or is she excluded from the possibility of having an old age pension as well? Thank you.
text.9: Thank you. Well, as far as it could have any relevance for the assessment of the case by this court, could the applicant give us some information on the medical or clinical reasons for the disability of the applicant? Of course, I'm not asking for any details, but just some general information of the reason for the impairment of the applicant, which made him unable to work. Thank you.
text.10: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions, both to the government and to the applicant. The first question is the following. Was the applicant, after the withdrawal of her disability pension, eligible to receive any types of benefits or allowances under the Hungarian law? Did the applicant apply for such benefits or no? And the second question, I would like to know the exact amount of the disability pension which was granted, if I remember correctly, in 2001. What was the amount at that time, and what was the amount of that disability pension at the time it was withdrawn? Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you.
text.11: Thank you very much, Mr. President. It's a bit of a question in line of what my colleague just asked, but a very precise question. When the pension allowance was withdrawn in 2010, did the applicant at that moment receive a rehabilitation allowance? Some uncertainty in the facts. I'm asking that because if she had received a rehabilitation allowance, which I understand is of a lower amount than the pension allowance, than a disability pension, then she might benefit from a transitional rule in the act of 2011. So a very precise question about the disability allowance, whether she received it or not.
text.12: Thank you very much, Mr. President. My first question goes to the applicant. And I would like to ask you, in the light of what you had said at the beginning, how you take into account the recent resolution of the Security Council, 2249, adopted recently, a few days ago, which considers, again, that terrorism is a threat to the peace and security. And this is not the first time that the Security Councils have qualified terrorism as such. How you take into account this resolution of the Security Council in relation with Article 103 of the Charter of the UN and in relation with Article 6 in our convention as such? My second question is also to the applicant. And I would like to see, because you have invoked the U.N. Directive, I would like to have your interpretation of you about the Article 12 of this directive, which, now, it's not very clear for a lot of the doctrine, and especially to the reference in the Article 12 to the Article 3, Paragraph 6 of this directive. My third question, it's addressed to the government of the UK. And I would like the government of the UK to comment in the Paragraph 39 of the Supreme Court of Judication, Court of Appeal, Criminal Division, which said, in this type of cases, the court is only likely to conclude that there have been an abusive process if a defendant can establish that there have been an unequivocal representation of those responsible for the conduct of the prosecution and the defendant has acted in this statement. And I would like to see what means for this court to be unequivocal, where he was not aware that he became a suspect because he was called to be a witness. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
text.13: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have one question for the Council for the first three applicants, and then two questions for the government that have been provoked by the pleadings here today. I noticed that in the pleadings of the Council for the first three applicants, there was no direct pleadings or reference to whether compelling reasons existed for restricting the first three applicants' rights to legal advice. Do I understand it to be the case that the Council stipulates that there were compelling reasons to restrict advice of the first three applicants, or is it the contention of the Council that it really doesn't matter for the legal assessment whether compelling reasons existed or not, as an overall fairness assessment needs to be considered? Or does it need to be conducted anyways? Could I just get a clarification from the Council on that issue? And may I, as the Council referred to international legal instruments and the EU position, may I ask Council to take into account in their answer Article 3 of the directive just mentioned by Judge Motok, the directive of 2013 of the right of access to a lawyer, where in Article 3 there is an explicit exception provided to the right of access to a lawyer when the government, the police, are confronted with adverse consequences or an urgent need to protect life and liberty? To the government, may I firstly ask a clarification on a factual issue? There is a distinction in the facts as regards the way in which the decision was taken in restricting legal advice of the first three applicants, in the sense that that decision in all the first three applicants' cases was explicitly reasoned and recorded. So we have information in the file on the actual thinking behind the decision to restrict legal advice. However, in the fourth applicant's case, there is no such recording or reasoning given at the time when the decision was taken. May I ask, was the fact that this decision was not recorded or reasoned, is that an anomaly under UK criminal procedural law or guidelines or codes? And if this is not an anomaly, is there a basis for an exceptions to recording or reasoning for procedural decisions of that nature? The second question is a linked question. I understand the government to rely heavily on the fact that under domestic law, Schedule 8 of the Terrorism Act, there is an explicit statutory regime regulating when restrictions on legal advice can take place. Now, in the fourth applicant's case, as I understand it, there was an explicit decision taken not to caution. Is it the government's contention that the superintendent who decided, who made that decision at that moment, also in the individual circumstances, made an assessment on whether the conditions under Schedule 8 for restricting legal advice, not just the breach of the code on the right to remain silent, but he also made a determination which the government has emphasized is part of the assessment of compelling reasons, also made a determination under Schedule 8 of the Terrorism Act. And the reason I ask is because we do not have any record or reasoning given for that decision. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
text.14: Thank you, Mr. President. My questions are addressed primarily to the government, but the applicants' lawyers are free to comment if they wish so. I had a difficulty following your argument, so this is just for clarification. Is it the position of the government that the compelling reasons are to be determined at the level of domestic proceedings, or is it within the power of this court to analyze compelling reasons? Or would it be, in your view, an act of force instance? Related to this, and I apologize for asking this, but I was forced by arguments made by applicants. In paragraph 38 of the applicants, Ibrahim and others' observations to the court, there is a discussion of the presence or availability of lawyers before and during the safety interview. If I understand you correctly, your argument is that this situation was extraordinary, and I think no one can doubt that. But then you also mentioned that it is obvious why these interviews were taken in the absence of lawyers who were, at least in some cases, available. And sometimes even the obvious needs some explanation. So I would be very grateful if you were kind enough to explain what is the interest that necessitates the absence of lawyers in those circumstances and in the particular circumstances of this case. My second question is related to a case, and I apologize if my pronunciation is not correct. Maggie, or Maggie, this is a case we decided in 2000. This is a Northern Ireland terrorist case. The facts, as far as I can see, are comparable. There, one of the reasons for finding a violation was that holding the applicant incommunicado for around 48 hours in appalling conditions amounted to coercion. Now, I wonder whether you would like to distinguish the present situation from that one, and if so, on which ground. I understand that the period is shorter, but these facts were not presented by you so far. In regard to Maggie, finally, and obviously related to Maggie, there was no discussion of the problem of self-incrimination. And related to it, the problem of remaining silent. I would like to know the position of the government. What is the place of the rule against self-incrimination in the convention? Do you consider this to be, because it's not there. And there was argument recently in this auditorium, if I may call this chamber an auditorium, where it was argued that the absence of certain words which are in the Universal Declaration and in the covenant being absent from the convention mean that there is an intention not to include it. And we know that these considerations, self-incrimination, et cetera, are not in the text. So what is the place of those principles or rules according to the government from the perspective of Article VI? Thank you very much.
text.15: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to ask both parties whether they can assist the court in the interpretation of the famous paragraph 55 of the Saldus judgment. It is said there that even where compelling reasons may exceptionally justify denial of access to a lawyer, such restriction, whatever its justification, must not unduly prejudice the rights of the accused under Article 6. And then the next sentence reads, the rights of the defense will in principle, and I stress in principle, be irretrievably prejudiced when incriminating statements made during police interrogation without access to a lawyer are used for a conviction. This seems to suggest that apart from the principle, there is also an exception. I would like to ask whether the applicants agree with this part of the Saldus principles, including the in principle term. I know from the government that they agree with the fact that there is a principle and therefore also an exception, so I'm not going to ask them the question. But then I would like to ask both parties whether they can give examples. In the first place, and that would then be especially for the applicants, what could be exceptions where the use of statements made without the assistance of a lawyer would not violate the overall fairness? But the government can reply to that too. And then vice versa, especially for the government, but the applicants can also give an answer, when would such use violate the overall fairness, also taking into account that according to Saldus, this is what usually as a matter of principle would happen. So I'm asking for some clear examples because a lot has been said, but it's for me not clear how you look at the application of this last part of the Saldus principles in practice. Thank you.
text.16: Thank you very much. Just a brief question to the government. As I understand, the three first applicants were cautious about their rights in several ways, but there was a caution given to them. However, the fourth applicant was not cautious. I mean, no warning was given to him. Now, the question is, well, the government seems to maintain that there were compelling reasons for not cautioning the fourth applicant. However, I would like to some explanation why the government considered there were not compelling reasons for not cautioning the three first one, but there were compelling reasons for not cautioning the fourth one. What was the difference between the three first applicant and the fourth applicant in this respect? Thank you.
text.17: Thank you, Mr. President. The question is put to the government but can also be dealt with by the applicant. I looked for the position of the UK government on the Internet this morning, and the UK government has a webpage where the issue of the types of prison sentences is clarified. And I quote from that page on the web, All life term means there is no minimum term set by the judge and the person is never considered for release. This is the position of the UK government on the Internet. The page was last updated on the 12th of November 2014. I also looked at the official position of the Sentencing Council for England and Wales and the same statement is made there. I also looked for the official position of the Law Commission and the same statement is there to be found. In none of these sites is there reference to Bieber or Newell. My question is what is the official position of the UK government? Is this clear enough for the UK citizens and for the outside world? How can the UK government clarify this discrepancy between what is on the Internet in these various sources and the position that was presented today to the court? Thank you very much.
text.18: I would very much appreciate to learn about the legal nature of the LIFE First manual. Is the manual a source of law? Is it subject to judicial review? It would be very helpful to learn about that. Thank you.
text.19: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question for the parties. It's quite long, but there's no need to worry about scribbling down the terms of the question, as a written copy will be given to them at the beginning of the pause. My question is as follows. What would be the scope of the judicial scrutiny carried out by the domestic courts in applications for judicial review of a negative decision by the Secretary of State in relation to release of a whole life prisoner under Section 30, paragraph 1 of the Crime Sentences Act 1997? In particular, would the scrutiny be as narrow as that suggested by the applicant? Paragraphs 42 to 43 of his observations. And then the second particularity, and I would say this is not part of the written text that you'll get. Here I'm thinking of the local authority housing cases, where people are rejected from their housing to failure to comply with the legal conditions, and where the nature of the judicial scrutiny of such administrative decisions under Article 8 of the Convention has been explained by the courts. And the question here is, would the domestic court have to verify that the Secretary of State had actually exercised his statutory power of release under Section 30, paragraph 1, compatibly with the whole life prisoner's rights under Article 3 of the Convention in the particular circumstances of the case? And would the domestic court order the Secretary of State to release the whole life prisoner if the latter could establish that on the facts and circumstances of his case, his continued imprisonment, despite his whole life sentence, is no longer justified on legitimate penological grounds? And the third and last indent is, would the domestic court examine such matters as the question, what would amount to a legitimate penological ground in this context, as the government suggests at paragraph 27 of their obligations? Thank you.
text.20: Thank you. We have heard that none of the prisoners was released, but what I would be interested to hear is whether any of the prisoners since winter has applied, regardless whether he was denied or was not denied. So whether he applied and how then, what was the procedure then, and how that was done, and whether any procedural safeguards in connection with that, whether any procedural safeguards are provided once the person, the prisoner, is applying for the review. Then you have told us then that the prisoner may come whenever. And as soon as the Article 3 standard for continuum detention has dropped away. So you have told us and you emphasized several times that a person can apply, but when actually there is obligation really to get a review, not just to apply, but to get a review in terms that you are saying as soon as the Article 3 standard for continuous detention has dropped away. So to what extent is that determinative to get a review? And then the question, third question, when the person is entering the prison, is the person getting any information on early release? In general, I'm asking. In general, not only for the whole life prisoners. And has McLaughlin or Winter changed anything in this respect for life prisoners? So are they told? Because European prison rules are requiring that, and I'm not quite sure how the domestic system is regulating that. Thank you.
text.21: I would have a question concerning the Norwegian law. We are here, we have two laws. We have Article 10.2 of the Tax Assessment Act and we have Chapter 12 on tax fraud of the Penal Code. And in the case at hand, we have learned that the courts, when assessing the criminal punishment, they took into account the administrative tax surcharges. I wonder, and the government argued that this was, as it was said, a statutory law demand. I would like to understand was that discretionary or is there a duty in the law to take into account the administrative punishment that has been before? And if the procedure had been vice versa, so if there had been first criminal punishment and then the conclusion of the administrative procedure, I read that in the event that the conditions imposing a tax surcharge are fulfilled, the surcharge will normally be assessed at 30%. Would that mean that this normally that we would have an exception if there had been already a high criminal punishment to reduce the administrative sanction? That would be my question, thank you.
text.22: Thank you Mr. President. My question goes to the government, but of course the applicants may also take a position on this question. In fact, I have two questions to the government. I would like the government to elaborate on the consequences, the negative consequences for a Norwegian citizen who does not pay the tax surcharge. The government pleads that there are no penal means to impose the tax surcharge. No imprisonment, no criminal record, no publicity. Are there any negative consequences for someone who does not pay the surcharge in whatever form, as a fine or any other form of negative consequence that may arise from the fact of not having paid the tax surcharge? And my second point is related to the interaction between the administrative and the criminal procedures. In what measure is the tax surcharge applied in the administrative procedure taken into account in the conviction and sentencing in the criminal procedure? Are the facts established in the administrative procedure binding for the criminal procedure? Is the tax surcharge considered in order to diminish the criminal penalty? And these questions could be put as an alternative seen from the perspective of the criminal procedure seen from the other side of the coin. Are the facts established in the criminal procedure binding for the administrative procedure? Is the criminal penalty considered in order to lower the tax surcharge? So I would like the government to elaborate on this interaction, possible interaction between the effects of each of these procedures in one another. Thank you very much.
text.23: Thank you, Mr. President. I would ask both parties for very short comments about concerning the situation from 29 June of 2007 when Kishnev Court of Appeal quashed the decision from 26 June of 2007 about house arrest and reordered applicants detention in jail pending the trial for next 20 days. I would ask for very short comments in the context of both exhaustion of domestic remedies and effectiveness of domestic remedies. Thank you.
text.24: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions. The first question for both parties. I would like to have more detailed information about the regime of the house arrest in the Republic of Moldova. What are the exact obligations imposed on a person placed under house arrest? This is the first question. The second question is for the government. The government has emphasized that the residents did not provide any resources to contest the decision to assign residents. I would like to ask the residents to respond to this argument and perhaps also to explain that they were right not to provide resources to contest the decision to assign residents. Thank you.
text.25: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question to the government. So my first question is, I'd like to find out whether, from the point of view of the government, the preventive measures during the domestic criminal proceedings against the applicant represented a continuing situation. And the second question, in the paragraph 69 of the government memorial to the Grand Chamber, it stated that from the point of view of the government, the applicant requests and consent to be placed under the house arrest, I'm citing, can decrease the domestic court's duty for the justification of the arrest measure. In that respect, could you please give an example of legal provision, if any, from the Moldovan legislation and or from the domestic judicial practice and or from the case law of the European court in favor of this statement? And the last question, take into account your pleadings before today, I mean today, I'd like to find out where in the Moldovan legislation is stated that the house arrest represent, by itself, an alternative measure to the detention pending trial. Thank you.
text.26: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two very short questions arising out of what was said by the two distinguished counsel for the applicant and the government. And this is irrespective of what we have in our dossier. It's simply to help me clarify my ideas, to make sure I understand everything. The first question is addressed to counsel for the applicant. You said, if I understood you correctly, that the domestic courts did not adequately consider alternative measures, by which I understand alternative measures apart from house arrest. text.90: Merci, M. le Président. Ma dernière question s'adresse au gouvernement défendeur. La Cour suprême de l'Ethonie a écarté les griefs du requérant par la motivation suivante. Je cite. Il me semble qu'il faut rappeler que l'article 34.2 du règlement n'exclut pas le contrôle de l'Etat requis en cas d'absence de recours. Il l'exclut, je cite, lorsqu'il est établi que ce recours n'a pas été exercé à l'encontre de la décision alors qu'il était en mesure de le faire. Ma question est alors la suivante. Avant d'écarter les arguments du requérant pour ce motif, c'est-à-dire l'absence de recours, la Cour suprême a-t-elle vérifié que l'appel du jugement du tribunal de Limassol devant les juridictions chypriotes était possible ou pour reprendre la formule de l'article 34.2, que le requérant était en mesure de le faire? Si c'est le cas, quels éléments établissent que cet examen a été fait par la Cour suprême? Si la Cour suprême estimait qu'il appartenait au requérant de prouver que le recours n'était pas possible, pourquoi n'a-t-elle pas précisé dans sa décision que le requérant n'avait pas apporté la preuve qui lui incombait? Et enfin, passant du droit de l'union que notre Cour n'a pas pour mission ni pour pouvoir de contrôler, mais passant à l'article 6 de la Convention, est-ce que cette absence de vérification peut poser problème au regard de l'article 6 de la Convention? Enfin, ma dernière question s'adresse aux représentants de la Commission. L'article 34-2 du règlement encadre de façon très stricte le contrôle que l'Etat requis peut exercer sur le respect des droits fondamentaux par l'Etat d'origine. Dans l'hypothèse, je dis bien dans l'hypothèse, où les standards de la Convention seraient plus exigeants, l'Etat requis, qui est également parti à la Convention, devrait-il s'interdire absolument de toute appréciation sur le fondement de la Convention? Il me semble que cette question pourrait être utilement envisagée à la lumière de certains passages de l'avis de 2013 de la Cour de justice relatifs à l'adhésion.

And I just wonder how the statement here, that this is an accepted typology, fits into what I thought so far is at least a most respected approach in structuring, in understanding religious structures, namely Max Weber until Stark. So my question is how your position fits into that tradition. So is this really the only possible consideration of the problem? Thank you.
text.98: Oui, merci, M. le Président. J'ai d'abord 2 questions pour le gouvernement. Ça concerne l'arrêt du tribunal administratif du 4 juillet 2007. Alors, dans cette décision, le tribunal administratif d'Ankara a rejeté la demande des requérants pour 2 motifs. Tout d'abord, il a considéré que le refus de l'administration opposée aux demandes des requérants était conforme à la législation. Alors, en vertu de la Constitution, article 136 de la Constitution, la direction des affaires religieuses, qui fait partie de l'administration générale, remplit les fonctions qui lui sont confiées en vertu de la loi spécifique, conformément aux principes de laïcité. De même, selon l'article 1er de la loi 633, la direction des affaires religieuses est chargée de traiter des affaires religieuses dans le domaine des croyances, du culte et de la morale de l'islam. Alors, vu ces deux dispositions, on peut considérer que la direction est chargée de fournir un service religieux à l'ensemble des musulmans, y compris aux personnes adhérentes à d'autres ou diverses interprétations de l'islam. Alors, comment expliquez-vous que le tribunal a jugé le refus de l'administration de la demande des requérants conforme à la législation en vigueur? En deuxième lieu, le tribunal a précisé qu'il n'était pas possible de donner une suite favorable à la demande des requérants sans revoir la législation. Est-ce que la législation doit être modifiée pour satisfaire aux demandes des requérants? Et dans l'affirmative, si oui, alors dans quel sens? Ma deuxième question pour le gouvernement concerne l'avis de la Commission de Venise, adopté en 2014. C'est un avis qui concerne les lignes directrices sur la personnalité juridique des communautés religieuses. Alors, dans cet avis, la Commission de Venise a essayé d'établir un document de référence énonçant les normes internationales minimales en matière de justice et minimales en matière de reconnaissance des communautés religieuses ou de convictions. Alors, je voudrais savoir la position du gouvernement vis-à-vis de cet avis. Ma deuxième question concerne les deux parties, alors pour les requérants aussi. On a abordé ce sujet, mais il faut préciser de plus. Les services religieux relatifs à la religion musulmane ont le statut de service public en Turquie. Donc, par conséquent, le service public religieux dépend du régime juridique du service public en général. Donc, comment peut-on concilier ce système avec le principe d'égalité devant le service public et le principe de neutralité du service public toujours? Merci beaucoup.
text.99: Thank you, Mr. President. My question is prompted by the relative silence of the government towards the already existing case law of the court. This is not the first case in which the European Court of Human Rights has dealt with the Alevi community in Turkey. As mentioned by the applicants, in December, the second section of this court gave judgment in the case of Kumur Yeci. If I recall correctly, the government requested a referral of this case to the Grand Chamber. This was rejected in April. In this case, as correctly mentioned by the applicant, the second section found that the cemevi Center in Yenibosna should have been considered in the same way as other recognized places of worship, a place of worship of the religious conviction involved. The reason I ask this is that one of the four concrete demands which are before this court in this case, and perhaps the most concrete one, which was rejected by the administrative tribunal for reasons related to law number 633 and Article 128 of the Constitution, was the impossibility of recognizing the cemevi as a place of worship. And in the judgment in Kumur Yeci, the legal consequences of such non-recognitions are presented. So my question is this. Is the government here today inviting the Grand Chamber to re-examine the assessment made and the findings of the second section, which were not brought before the Grand Chamber? And I would ask that a position on this issue be made as clear as possible. And if so, does the government then reject the findings of the second section? And on what basis? Thank you.
text.100: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. Je voudrais également poser une question, surtout au gouvernement, mais les requérants peuvent répondre aussi, une question qui est suscitée par le jugement du tribunal d'Ankara, le tribunal administratif d'Ankara, qui a rejeté la demande des requérants en disant, à la fin de son jugement notamment, que si l'État répondait sous la forme d'un service public à chacune des attentes et des demandes des requérants, alors il y aurait un risque de distance avec le principe de l'État laïc et un risque que les libertés de religion et de croyance seraient réduites, seraient limitées, de sorte que la paix civile serait mise en péril. Est-ce que le gouvernement est d'accord avec ce point de vue du tribunal? Et est-ce qu'il pourrait expliquer en quoi consisterait surtout le risque pour la jouissance de liberté de religion et de croyance quand on va donner précisément à une tendance qui s'appelle une religion des avantages qu'on donne aussi à une autre tendance?
text.101: Président, j'ai deux questions à poser au gouvernement. Un argument majeur du gouvernement français, ayant demandé le renvoi de l'affaire devant la grande chambre, réside dans l'incertitude qui aurait prétendument été créée par la manière dont la Chambre a utilisé le concept du sujet d'un drait général. Pour expliquer l'absence d'intérêt public à la publication en cause, le gouvernement a indiqué qu'il était impossible qu'Alexandre puisse prétendre au trône au regard de la constitution de principauté de Monaco. Le gouvernement français, tout comme les juridictions nationales, ont estimé qu'Alexandre Coste ne pouvait prétendre au trône car il était né hors des liens du mariage. Toutefois, d'un point de vue purement légal, cette circonstance ne semblait pas décisive. D'un point de vue légal, à la date de la publication litigieuse et au moment où les juridictions internes se sont prononcées, et bien que cette éventualité puisse paraître totalement improbable, le fils de Mme Coste et du prince de Monaco aurait pu être prétendant au trône en cas de légitimation par le mariage de ses parents biologiques, eu égard à la constitution et au code civil de Monaco. Le gouvernement peut-il expliquer sur quels fondements légaux il parvient à une opinion différente en la matière? Deuxième question. La publication dans Paris Match concerne une interview de Mme Coste. Les juridictions internes ont estimé que la société éditrice et la directrice des publications en étaient responsables. Selon le gouvernement, cela aurait-il fait une différence si Mme Coste avait publié sa biographie et celle de son fils dans un article qu'elle aurait elle-même rédigé? En d'autres termes, le contenu de l'interview était-il tel que les devoirs et responsabilités de l'éditeur impliquaient une intervention active, pas seulement au regard du droit du public d'être informé des questions relevant de l'intérêt public, mais également contre le droit à la liberté d'expression de Mme Coste afin de protéger la vie privée du prince Albert II de Monaco? Les juridictions nationales auraient-elles dû également donner du poids au droit à la liberté d'expression de Mme Coste dans la mise en balance des droits en jeu? Merci.
text.102: Thank you very much, Mr. President. Just following up on Judge Silvis's question, I have one question to the government. The government, in its referral request, firstly and foremostly emphasizes that the Fifth Section's judgment wrongly interpreted the concept of a contribution to a debate of generalists and it opened the way for considerable judicial uncertainty, that is the crux of the referral request. May I ask, and the government of course follows this up in its brief and here orally by inviting the court not to substitute its own judgment for the assessment of the domestic courts, namely the court of cassation, referring to our classic expressions in our case law that if the balancing of interest has been performed by the domestic courts in accordance with the criteria in our case law, it is not for this court, unless it has strong reasons, to substitute its assessment. It is on this basis that I would like the government to clarify its statements in paragraph 70 and 71 of the observations, where in paragraph 70, the government refers to the court of cassation's reasoning in the case. This is also developed at paragraph 24 of the chamber judgment, where the court of cassation noted that on the date on which the article was published, the child's existence and his family relationship were unknown to the public. And that the principality's constitution rules out the possibility of his accession to the throne since he was born outside a wedlock, a situation that moreover, and I quote, the company did not allege to be a subject of debate in French or Monegasque society or of examination in the impugned publication. Do I understand the government's pleading correctly as inviting the court then firstly to formulate this concept of what constitutes a contribution to a debate in the public interest or in the general interest in such a way that a debate on this subject matter must be already ongoing, must be already ongoing for the condition to apply? And secondly, that the article in question must primarily or its core feature must be the examination of the issue that is alleged to be forming a contribution in the public interest? Because I understand the government saying it agrees with the assessment of the court of cassation. And if that is the view of the government, may I ask the government kindly to refer to a case of this court that would support that kind of formulation of the issue of the concept of a contribution in the general interest? Thank you.
text.103: Merci beaucoup, Monsieur le Président. Juste une question de suivi et une clarification que, cette fois-ci, s'adresse à la partie requérante. On sait des pièces de dossier que l'enfant avait été reconnu quatre mois après sa naissance chez le notaire. Vous avez pourtant invoqué le fait que la reconnaissance de l'enfant, cette fois-ci la reconnaissance, vous dites, publique de l'enfant, aurait des délais dans lesquels elle aurait pu être faite. Ça veut dire qu'au moment, en 2005, quand Madame Coste avait donné cette interview, on s'approchait d'une certaine façon, selon vous, de ce délai. De quoi exactement il s'agit? Est-ce qu'il y a un délai pour ce type de reconnaissance? Et quelles sont les conséquences? Est-ce qu'il y a des conséquences juridiques pour ce type de reconnaissance par rapport à la reconnaissance que déjà Albert de Monaco avait fait devant le notaire, comme les pièces de dossier l'ont dit? Merci beaucoup.
text.104: Thank you, Mr. President. This question is addressed to the government, but of course the other parties may comment. Allow me to quote the Italian Constitutional Court in its decision number 49 from 2015. It is the Italian Constitutional Court speaking. In other words, the Italian Constitutional Court said in this judgment that the judgments of this court are only binding as precedent for the Italian courts when they are diritto consolidato, meaning what we usually call WECL, well-established case law, or pilot judgments. Now, my question is the following. Would the government mind to comment this position of the Italian Constitutional Court in the light of the Brighton Conference commitments that member states undertook, and namely that they guarantee, and I quote, the full implementation of the convention at the national level, which requires state parties to take effective measures to prevent violations, and that to that end, all state parties and more generally all public authorities should discharge their responsibilities in a way that gives full effect to the convention, end of quote. Is the Italian Constitutional Court's decision an informal reservation to this convention? Does Italy intend to make a reservation to the effect of the judgments of this court when they are not diritto consolidato? I put this question in these terms because the government is certainly aware that this possibility has been discussed in the intensive debate in the Italian doctrine caused by the Constitutional Court's judgment number 49. Thank you very much.
text.105: Le Président, en fait, ma première question était celle de M. Pinto de Albuquerque, mais je vais la poser d'une manière un peu différente qu'il l'a fait. D'ailleurs, la question a été analysée d'une certaine manière par l'opinion en partie concordante commune des juges Casadevall, Raimondi, Bahr, Nicola et Dedov dans l'arrêt Paris contre l'Italie, où les juges montrent comment la pratique a été changée depuis les arrêts qui étaient nommés jumeaux 30, 40, 48 et 39 de 2007 à l'arrêt qu'il a fait référence 49 de 2015, à laquelle a fait référence mon collègue, monsieur le juge Pinto de Albuquerque. Je voulais aussi savoir, parce que j'ai un peu une autre question différente que mon collègue avait mis. Je suis devant moi la sentence de la juge de la cour en italien et ici on marque une présence de una diritto consolidata ou de una sentenza pilota. Donc je veux savoir exactement qu'est-ce que vous comprenez par diritto consolidata, parce que je vois que l'arrêt pilote c'est une catégorie différente dans cet arrêt de la cour de concionelle qui ne préoccupe et qui était en partie expliquée par cette opinion en partie concordante commune des juges que j'ai cités auparavant. J'ai une deuxième question à mettre, qui est adressée au gouvernement, mais aussi au requérant. Quelle était la disposition du code de procédure pénale à l'époque où ils avaient le non-lieu par rapport au requérant qui était avec le non-lieu? Ça veut dire pas la société G.I.E.M. qui se trouve dans une autre situation, les autres sociétés. Est-ce que c'était possible que les sociétés, après que la cour décide qu'il y a la prescription, exige de la part de la cour de continuer le procès pénal pour établir qu'ils ne sont pas, pour les acquitter finalement, qu'ils établissent qu'ils ne sont pas responsables? Il y avait cette possibilité dans le droit de procédure pénale italien ou non? Parce que selon les actes qu'on a maintenant devant nous, le code de procédure pénale italien, l'article 129, on dit que même si la prescription est acquise, le juge doit quand même acquitter l'accusé sur le fond, ce ressemble manifestement au dossier que l'accusé n'a pas commis les faits réprochés, sauf les faits n'ont pas eu lieu. Il faut en en sous-exister que l'infraction n'est pas constituée ou que les faits ne relèvent pas du droit pénal. Mais ma question est un peu différente. Sauf cette hypothèse, il y avait la possibilité pour le requérant de demander que le juge continue le procès pour établir qu'ils ne sont pas coupables ou non dans le code de procédure pénale. Et ça s'agit du gouvernement et aussi au requérant que j'ai mis cette question. Je vous remercie Monsieur le Président.
text.106: My question is addressed mostly to the applicant companies Hotel Promotion, R.I.T.A. Sarda and Falgest. In the Eastern cases, these applicant companies were not parties to criminal proceedings of any kind and only a physical person, that is, the legal representatives of these companies, Hotel Promotion and Falgest, and two associates of Rita Sarda were committed for trial. Now, the question is, did these accused physical persons, as representatives of the applicant companies, have received from these companies sufficient legal powers or legal authorization to perform the site development which was declared illegal? Or, on the contrary, did this physical person act ultra vires, that is, did they act without legal power or legal authorization from the companies they were representing? Thank you.
text.107: Thank you, President. My question goes to the representative of the government, but as other judges, I also invite other parties' representatives to tell their views on this question. I spring from the government's position that the confiscation which is dealt with in this case is not a criminal sanction by its nature and is only applied by a criminal court. So I would like to know whether this non-criminal sanction applied by a criminal court is a typical phenomenon in the Italian legal system, or is it an exception? And in particular, are there any other, and if so, how many, non-criminal sanctions in the Italian legal system that are applied by criminal courts and especially under the criminal procedure law? If you could provide a list or at least some examples that could be confirmed by statutory law, by the court's case law, or at least by the legal doctrine, thank you.
text.108: Thank you, President. I have a question to both parties. It concerns the issue of self-defense before us today, self-defense of the officers of the unit of SO19 who were deployed on 22nd of July, 2005, and who eventually killed Mr. de Menezes. It concerns the briefing of these officers. When they reported on 22nd of July, 2005, at 0745 to duty, they were briefed as follows. I have this from the documents before us. First, they were told that they might be required to use unusual tactics. When asked for clarification, the briefing went on. I quote from the documents, if they were deployed to intercept a subject and there was an opportunity to challenge, but the subject was noncompliant, a critical shot could be taken, end of quote. My question concerns these instructions at the briefing, according to which the special firearms officers were instructed to shoot to kill, critical headshot. I would like to know the party's views on whether this briefing, in fact, permitted the special firearms officers to differentiate, differentiate, to react proportionally, in particular, whether the special firearms officers could have employed less far-reaching means, namely nonlethal shots, which could have prevented the presumed suicide attack while not killing Mr de Menezes. Thank you.
text.109: Thank you, Mr. President. My questions are to the government. Is the UK government aware that Article 31c of the Rome Statute, which was, by the way, the subject of extensive negotiations, and is today considered as customary international law, is the UK government aware that this provision warrants that the person acts reasonably, I'm quoting from the provision, reasonably to defend himself or herself or another person and in a manner proportionate to the degree of real present danger to the person attacked or the third person? Is the government of the UK aware of the UN basic principles on the use of force by law enforcement officials, which provide that intentional lethal use of firearms may only be made when strictly unavoidable in order to protect life and only when less extreme means are insufficient to achieve this objective, and that in any case, officials should exercise restraint in such use in proportion to the seriousness of the offense? Is the UK government aware that the UN Code of Conduct for law enforcement officials, as well as the OSCE guidebook on the democratic policing, also require that self-defense be not only proportionate, but reasonable and unavoidable? Final question, is the UK government aware of these universal standards, according to which the test for self-defense is based on a crucial, necessary, objective element of reasonableness of the belief of an imminent attack, or does the government of the UK consider that it is not bound by any of these universal standards, including those set by customary international law? Thank you very much.
text.110: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have one question to the government. You repeatedly invoke the margin of appreciation doctrine. Article 2 is an underrogable right. Do you believe that margin of appreciation is applicable in relation to such a provision? And if yes, to which extent? Thank you very much.
text.111: My question to both parties concerns the application presented to the High Court by the applicant for judicial review of the initial decision of the director of public prosecution, the decision not to prosecute any individual police officer. The High Court, a division of High Court, based its dismissal of this application on the so-called Manning test, derived from the case R versus the director of public prosecution, Ex parte Manning, which seems to have been decisive in this case. According to this case law in Manning, a court would accord great weight to the judgment of experienced prosecutors concerning prosecution decisions. Now, my question is, up to what point does this Manning case law represent an impediment or a strong difficulty for the courts to review DPP decisions? Is there a presumption in favor of the DPP decisions? In that case, what is the extent, what is the intensity of this presumption? Up to what point in practice the courts are bound to follow the DPP initial decision to prosecute, or, as is the case here, not to prosecute? What is the strength of this presumption? Thank you.
text.112: Thank you, President. I have two questions to the government, but of course, if the applicant wish to comment, he can do so. My first question relates to applicability of Article 6. It appears that claiming that the first condition of the Escalinan test, namely the explicit exclusion of access to court, has been met. Your government relied heavily on the fact that the applicant's dismissal had been written into the fundamental law itself, namely transitional provisions of the fundamental law, and was therefore not subject to any form of judicial review. I would like to refer, however, to the decision of your constitutional court, number 45, 2012, of 28 December 2012, in which the constitutional court concluded as follows. I quote, the constitutional court possesses, beyond doubt, the competence to proceed with reviewing transitional provisions of the fundamental law in whole and in parts on formal grounds with regard to its validity, invalidity, under public law, irrespectively to the fact whether transitional provisions of the fundamental law is or is not part of the fundamental law. I would like to ask you to clarify your position in light of this decision by the constitutional court. And my second question relates to the undertaking by your government to the Venice Commission in July 2011. Again, I quote, Hungary assures the commission that the drafting of transitional provisions will not be used to unduly put an end to the terms of office of persons elected under the previous legal regime. I wonder if this undertaking's set times included the applicant or not. Thank you very much.
text.113: Thank you, Mr. President. My two questions addressed to the government, but of course, the applicant can also comment on them. The first one is on a point of Hungarian constitutional law. Professor and judge Otto Bachof in 1951 wrote a marvelous text on a for fast ones, "Verfassungswidrige Verfassungsnormen", meaning unconstitutional constitutional norms. My point is the following. Uh, what is the situation with regard to Hungarian constitutional law? Uh, does, uh, the constitutional law and the constitutional doctrine, um, uh, in Hungary acknowledge the possibility that there might be norms in the constitution that are unconstitutional. For instance, imagine that a reform of the constitution provides for a suspension of in a mobility of a part of the judiciary. Would that, uh, law enshrined, uh, through the means of a transitional provision, for instance, in the constitution be valid? My second question, uh, is related to, uh, section 114 of the organization and administration of the courts act. These provision established a new criterion for the election of the new president, which led to the eligibility of the former president of the Supreme court as president of the courier. This criterion referred to the time served as a judge in Hungary, not counting the time served as a judge in the European court, for instance. Now, Mr. Baka, the applicant served these courts 17 years from 1991 to 2008. We are today that the position of the garment is that a career of 17 years in this court, in the European court of human rights as the one of Mr. Baka is not of equal value as the career for the same period of time in the domestic courts, I would like to hear the reasons I would like that the government clarified the reasons why this career of 17 years here at the court is not of the same value of a career at the national courts. I'm not sure if I understood correctly the point of the government when it referred to the discussion, the ongoing discussion in the, um, council of Europe on the independence of the judges of the European court. I'm not sure if I understood correctly that the government of Hungary doubts about the independence of these judges, of the judges of this court, that the judges of this court are not politically independent. And that was the reason why the career of 17 years of Mr. Baca was not of equal value of a career of a judge in the domestic courts for the same period. I would like the government to clarify if that is the position, um, that was presented because I did not really understand the point of the government when it referred to the ongoing discussion in the council of Europe about the independence and the reinforcement of the independence of the judges of the European court. Thank you very much.
text.114: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to ask a question to both parties. And the question is somewhat prompted by something that was mentioned by counsel for the applicant about the possibility for judges to bring claims before the service tribunal. I would like to ask what would be the situation in, legal situation in two somewhat different situations than the one that we are discussing today. One is, the first one is the situation where a judge, an individual judge would be considered to be no longer suitable for the job. What sort of a suitability could be mentioned? Illness, would this also include political insuitability? Would that be a reason to take action against a judge? And my question here would be in particular, what would be the competent body to take action? And would there be any possibility of judicial review? And the second situation is the one of an alleged, in inappropriate conduct of a judge, a conduct of a judge that is incompatible with judicial ethics. Would it be possible to bring disciplinary proceedings against the judge? And if so, what would then be the competent body? And would there be a possibility of judicial review? I repeat, I realize that these are not the situations in this case, but to get a broader picture, I would like to know what would happen in these two situations. Thank you.
text.115: Thank you, President. I would have two questions to the government, please. One question concerns Article 49, Paragraph 4 of the Act on Parliament, on which the sanctions in this case were based, which provides or which it's necessary to state a conduct that is gravely offensive to the authority of the parliament. And I wanted to ask how it's defined that a conduct is gravely offensive, not only offensive. Which criteria are used to determine the gravity of the disturbance, a length of time of the disturbance, number of people involved, size of billboards, deprivation of the rights of others? And if I understood the agent of the government correctly, also previously exhibited conduct. I just want to know which criteria are applied. And the second question is closely linked to the first one. Is it necessary for such a sanction to be reasoned on the basis of Section 49, Paragraph 4 and 49, Paragraph 7 of the Act on Parliament? In the case at hand, it was explained why the amounts of the sanctions were differentiated according to the status of the MPs. But it was not explained otherwise why it was considered that there was a gravely offensive conduct, gravely offensive to the authority of the parliament. Thank you.
text.116: Thank you, Mr. President. My question is directed to both parties. As it results from the dossier, the fines to the applicants were proposed by the Speaker of the House several days after the facts, and these fines were approved without debate by the plenary of the parliament. My question is whether within this disciplinary proceedings within parliament, whether the applicant has any effective possibility to state their position or adducing any arguments in the defense or challenging the charge formulated by the Speaker before the final decision by the plenary of the House. The government has made some passing reference to this point, but I would appreciate some precision of whether this possibility were effective. I know that there was a reform of the law last year on this matter, but my question refers to the situation in the moment of the fact discussed in this case, that is, in the spring of 2013. Thank you.
text.117: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions, and one question concerns a clarification. But my first question concerns the government. My question to the government is about the scope of the possible retroactive effect of the court's judgments. After the Vinter judgment, it's clear that life sentences, if proportionate to the facts, can only be in conformity with Article 3 of the Convention if the life sentence is de facto and de jure reducible. There is a longstanding position on the part of the court concerning cases in which the applicants have already lodged a complaint with the court at the time of the reversal of case law. As they are in exactly the same position as the successful applicant, they should be treated in the same way. So one of the differences between the Vinter position and Murray is that at the moment, the court may have to deal with the merits of this case. There has been a significant change in the law of Curaçao by the introduction of the review system. Now, the government states that the pardon system is already in conformity with the Vinter criteria, if I understand you well. But perhaps you may explain why, when introducing the review system, the arguments for introducing this system were to bring the legislation in conformity with current standards of human rights. Was it necessary to introduce this new system if the old system already met the criteria? Perhaps you would like to elaborate on this. Now, my question to the applicants. One very small but perhaps important point is the representative of the government stated that there is a pardons act. And the representative of the government also stated that that was not in line with the position presented by the applicant, because the applicant referred to the Constitution in which there is a basis for a pardon request. Perhaps you could explain whether there is a difference on this legal point between the government and the representative of the applicant. The point of clarification is this. Listening to your intervention, you refer to an observation of the CPT, the Committee on the Prevention of Torture, observing in 2013 an incapacity culture in the prison institutions in the Antilles. However, in 2013, the CPT has not visited the Antilles. There is, however, and I think you are referring to this observation report, there is an observation report of two experts assigned by the Dutch government which relates indeed to the CPT observations from 2007 reported in 2008. And according to these experts, there are shortcomings, especially in relation to the promotion of sensible activities for the inmates. And in this context, they note that the guards are trained to keep control and order, but they are not equipped in the process of re-socialization. Is that the observation you have in mind when expressing that there is an incapacity culture in the prisons of the Antilles, more specifically in the Correctional Institute in Aruba? Perhaps you may clarify this issue. Thank you.
text.118: Thank you, Mr. President. Both parties have in their pleadings before the Grand Chamber addressed the importance of the principle of rehabilitation as recognized in this court's case law. It has been mentioned that the convicted person should know what he must do to rehabilitate himself in order to have the prospect of release. It has also been mentioned that the convicted person should be allowed to rehabilitate himself in order to have the prospect of release. In other words, it has been argued that the state should not hinder the convicted person from rehabilitating himself. This may, in my view, be seen as a negative obligation on the state following from Article III, not to hinder but to allow. At the same time, it has been argued today that the state has to provide the convicted person with necessary treatment. This may, in my view, be seen as a positive obligation on the state to rehabilitate the convicted person, to rehabilitate or to assume responsibility for the rehabilitation of the convicted person. My question to the parties concerned these two aspects of the principle of rehabilitation, the positive and the negative aspect. In the view of the parties, taking into account the court's case law, is it necessary to make a distinction between these two aspects of the principle of rehabilitation? In other words, are they on an equal footing should the rights of the applicant and the obligation of the state be treated on an equal footing? Thank you.
text.119: I have two questions for the government, but of course the applicant may also elaborate on these questions. The applicant has said that no plan for the rehabilitation of James Murray has ever been prepared by the prison authorities who took care of him. The applicant has also said that it is the policy of the Kingdom of Netherlands that all life prisoners do not qualify for activities aiming at rehabilitation. And the applicant has even quoted the Dutch Secretary for Justice and Security. My two questions are the following. First, can you confirm that it is the policy of the Kingdom of Netherlands that all life prisoners do not qualify for activities aiming at reintegration, as Mr. Teeven has said? Second, can you confirm that no plan for the rehabilitation of James Murray was ever prepared during the time he spent in prison, over 30 years?
text.120: Thank you, Mr. President. One very, very short question for government. Which were the main reasons, I would say compelling reasons, made the transfer of applicant unfeasible in the realm of Europe to custodial clinic for adequate psychological or psychiatric treatment? Thank you.
text.121: Thank you, Mr. President. I do have one question, which is addressed to both parties, to the government, as well as to the applicant. The parties before the court seem to be in agreement that no distinction should be made between, on one hand, the collection of taxes, and on the other hand, tax surcharges, as under domestic law, Belgian law, both are assessed in the single procedure, the same document, and they are inextricably linked for the purpose of the calculation of the limitation period. The parties, however, seem to draw different conclusions from the two limbs being closely tied. The chamber made it clear that Article 6 was not applicable to the tax proceedings, but applicable to the tax surcharges. Therefore, if one accepts the logic of the chamber, if there are any problems under Article 6, it will be solely because of the tax surcharges, not because of the tax assessment. Therefore, my following question, would it have been possible under Belgian law for Belgian authorities to pursue the assessment of the tax liability, but to refrain from imposing tax surcharges, or put in other words, could Belgian authorities have assessed that retrospective application of the new act in calculation of the statutes of limitation was justified for the purpose of tax assessment liability, but not for imposing the penalty, the tax surcharges? Thank you.
text.122: Merci beaucoup, monsieur le Président. J'ai une question pour maître Wouters, mais le gouvernement est invité à développer sa réponse aussi. Vous avez tous les deux adressé cette question lors de vos plaidoiries et par écrit, mais je voudrais creuser un peu plus. Alors, selon la société réclairante, la solution retenue par la Cour de cassation en 2002 ne constituait pas une nouvelle jurisprudence, mais la suite est la conséquence normale de deux arrêts de 1993. La société réclairante a estimé dans ses observations écrites que la jurisprudence de 1993 était, et je cite, « dépourvu de toute ambiguïté et toute personne normalement prudente ne pouvait arriver à la conclusion depuis lors qu'une simple mise en demeure sans disposition légale expresse pouvait valoir au titre d'acte d'interruption de la prescription ». Donc, ma question est assez simple. Pourquoi donc la société réclairante n'a pas, en décembre 2000, lorsqu'elle a introduit son action en première instance, soulevé la question de la prescription? En effet, elle a attendu jusqu'à avril 2004 pour ce faire, et pendant les observations orales, la société réclairante nous a expliqué que c'était à cause du besoin de certitude pour le réclairant qu'elle ait intervenu en 2004. La raison pour laquelle je voudrais creuser un petit peu plus, c'est parce que cette question vise deux aspects qui pourraient être importants en l'espèce, c'est-à-dire l'attente légitime de la société réclairante, mais aussi l'existence ou non d'un effet aubaine. Merci beaucoup.
text.123: Merci, monsieur le Président. J'ai une question, ou plutôt une invitation à revenir sur certains aspects déjà traités et peut-être donner des précisions. Premier aspect, l'existence et les caractéristiques d'une jurisprudence au sujet de l'interruption de la prescription par un commandement de payer qu'on pourrait appeler pur. Si je ne me trompe pas, alors, le gouvernement se réfère à sept ou peut-être même huit décisions de première instance d'appel dans le sens de l'interruption, tandis que la récréation fournit 5 exemples dans le sens de la non-interruption, dont trois, si je ne me trompe pas, ont conduit au jugement de la Cour de cassation dont on parle ici. Les autres jugements, et je crois que maître Jafferali l'a noté, me semblent être postérieurs au jugement de la Cour de cassation. Alors, sur ce sujet-là, il me semblerait important que chaque parti prenne position sur les exemples jurispondenciels fournis par l'autre parti. On a déjà entendu maître Wouters, qui a dit que, selon lui, l'autre jurisprudence était minoritaire, tandis que maître Jafferali a parlé d'une jurisprudence divisée. Et là, j'ai aussi l'obligation... Ah, je me trompe. J'ai aussi l'obligation de noter que les deux parties se sont référées, il me semble, exclusivement à la jurisprudence publiée. Je sais ça, s'il existe de la jurisprudence non publiée. L'autre aspect, les nombres des affaires pendantes à notre sujet et les sommes d'argent en jeu. Sur ce point, alors, les gouvernements se réfèrent à la somme de 1,2 milliard d'euros qui est mentionnée au fin de la décision optime et finistère. Et, encore une fois, si je ne me trompe pas, cette somme renvoie au montant total affecté par les lois-programmes de 2003 et 2004. Alors, je crois que la Cour, au fin de notre affaire, est intéressée surtout sur les montants attachés par la loi-programme de 2004, exclusivement. Et les nombres des affaires pendantes, il me semble, n'est pas mentionnés dans notre dossier. Alors, ça pourrait être un sujet pour quelques précisions. Merci.
text.124: Thank you, Mr. President. I would also like to thank the parties for their submissions. My first question is directed to the applicants' representatives and concerns the relationship between the alleged crimes and the events of June 2010. First of all, with respect to the misappropriation charges brought against the first applicant, is there any factual evidence in support of the allegation that they are based on ethnic bias? I would think that everyone accused of this kind of crime would claim insufficient evidence, but does this prove that the charges are ethnically motivated? With respect to the second applicant, I would like to hear more about the complaint that the murder and other charges were, in fact, fabricated. Is it enough nowadays to claim that the charges related to the inter-ethnic clashes of 2010 in order to find a real risk of ill treatment? And I would like to emphasize that we are taking a current perspective, excellent perspective here. Now, assuming that the charges were indeed ethnically motivated, one might ask, why then did the applicants apply for a refugee status, one of the applicants, only several years after coming to Russia? Moreover, I would like to know from both parties whether and why ethnic Uzbeks are at a heightened risk of ill treatment in detention in Kyrgyzstan nowadays compared to in the years after the clashes of 2010.
