I understood the applicant's representative to making this kind of claim, but I would like to have a little bit more of a clarification because so far what we've heard are allegations about the commission of torture, and this is somewhat related to the ethnic Uzbeks, but I haven't heard anything supporting this kind of allegation brought forward by the applicants. And then, in this respect, the question is also asked, who has to prove this kind of aspect? Turning now to the government representative, I would like to ask as follows. Did the domestic courts sufficiently evaluate the individual risks in light of the court's jurisprudence at the relevant time, including with respect to the assurances? Thank you very much.
text.125: The court asked already within the framework of the general questions to the parties in preparation of today's hearing whether the assurances provided by the Kyrgyz authorities in respect of the applicants had legal effects, were binding and reliable, and met with all the other requirements set out in the court's case law. Replying to the above concerning the binding character, the government in their observations before the grand chamber, I think this is in paragraph 68, qualified the assurances as being a sort of statement of confirmation of the obligations undertaken by Kyrgyzstan under the Minsk Convention of 1993. Also other instruments are mentioned, but they are not specifically indicated. The applicants, on the contrary, in general denied such binding effect. My question is, can the parties, and in particular the government, clarify in which way this Minsk Convention or any other international instrument is relevant in order for the court to assess the binding effect, and especially under which specific provision? Is this provision also relied upon explicitly or implicitly in the documents we have? Thank you.
text.126: Thank you, President. I would also like to ask the government to clarify certain issues related to the assurances. In particular, to what extent the assurance mechanism has changed over the past years so that the court could come to a different assessment than in Khamarokulov versus Russia judgment of 2015? More specifically, and also to amend the question put by Judge Sabato, what is the legal basis for monitoring mechanism by the diplomatic staff? We just heard from the applicants that there is no solid legal basis apart from the instructions referred to. Also, are visits scheduled for the early phase of detention, meaning after the transfer? And finally, what about the restrictions that according to the applicants made the mechanism fragile? Why is there is a need for prior authorization for the visits? And we heard this morning from the applicants that there is no guarantee that such a request will be granted. And why should Kyrgyz authorities be allowed to be physically present during the visits, even though they are prevented from listening to what is being said, and you have just confirmed that those visits should be private? Thank you very much.
text.127: Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to follow up on the question put to my distinguished colleague, Ms. Zeibert, on concerning the vulnerability of ethnic Uzbeks in Kyrgyzstan. So my question is addressed more to the applicants, but of course the government could also answer to this question. So could you give please more details concerning the practical, particular vulnerability of ethnic Uzbeks? Information, more detailed information on to what extent they are persecuted and more particularly, they are subjected to ill treatment because of their ethnic origin. And whether this real risk of being subjected to ill treatment is related to their ethnic origin or it's more related to the 2010 events. Thank you.
text.128: Thank you very much. I would like to pose a factual question which either party might address concerning the situation of the second applicant. We learned from the applicant's submissions that both charges and extradition requests against other people have been made in connection with the same events of which the second applicant has been charged with. I wonder if we have any information regarding what has happened to these other persons who have been charged with and in respect of whom extradition requests have been made. Do we have any information what has happened in those cases? Thank you.
text.129: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. D'abord, j'ai une question qui s'adresse principalement aux récurrents. Dispose-vous d'informations concernant la situation actuelle des filles et petits-enfants des récurrents, s'agissant notamment de leur localisation exacte et leur état de santé? Ensuite, j'ai 3 questions à poser au gouvernement. Premièrement, en ce qui concerne la juridiction. Les récurrents soutiennent que l'article 3, paragraphe 2 du protocole numéro 4, est applicable par définition ou par sa nature, même si les victimes se trouvent en dehors du territoire de leur état national, et que l'exercice de tout droit en vertu de cette disposition est tout simplement inconcevable sans la reconnaissance d'une juridiction extraterritoriale. D'après vos observations écrites, il semble que votre gouvernement est d'accord avec ce point de vue. Et c'est bien le cas. Deuxièmement, dans ces observations écrites, votre gouvernement fait valoir que les filles de récurrents doivent être poursuives en Syrie pour les crimes commis dans ces pays. Alors, par quel type de tribunal qu'en est-il de l'avancement de la création d'un tribunal pénal international à cet égard? Et troisièmement, votre gouvernement a fait référence dans ces observations écrites et oralement à cette audience au protocole "cazeneuve", un accord entre la France et la Turquie. Quel est le mécanisme précis introduit par cet accord? A l'heure actuelle, y a-t-il des personnes qui retournent en France depuis la Syrie via la Turquie grâce à cet accord? Enfin, j'ai une question sur le droit international humanitaire, à laquelle j'aimerais que tous les deux partis répondent si possible. Dans ces observations écrites, le gouvernement a souligné que les filles et petits-enfants de récréants, lorsqu'ils se trouvaient dans le camp, étaient protégés par l'article 3 commun aux 4 conventions de Genève de 2049. Les autorités locales kurdes sont les responsables directs des conditions dans le camp. Cependant, je note que selon l'article 1 commun aux 4 conventions de Genève, tous les Etats partis aux instruments en question, y compris les Etats des nationalités respectives comme la France, sont tenus de veiller à ce que ces autorités respectent leurs obligations au titre de l'article 3 commun, en faisant tout ce qui est raisonnablement à leur pouvoir pour mettre fin aux violations de droits internationaux humanitaires. Voilà donc ma question est la suivante. Cette obligation de faire tout ce qui est raisonnablement à leur pouvoir pour mettre fin aux violations de droits internationaux humanitaires, peut-elle avoir une influence sur l'examen de ces affaires? Merci pour votre patience, et je vous remercie d'avance pour vos réponses. Je vous le précise.
text.130: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai une question de fait qui s'adresse aux représentants du gouvernement français. Il apparaît des pièces du dossier, et cela a été redit dans les plaidoiries, que les demandes des familles, des 2 familles requérantes, tenant au rapatriement des filles et des petits-enfants, des requérants ici, sont restées sans réponse. Et il a été mentionné qu'il y avait des décisions implicites de refus. Je voulais savoir si le gouvernement était en mesure d'expliquer ce choix de ne pas répondre. Il ne s'agit pas ici de dire pourquoi il y a eu une non-suite donnée à la demande. C'est vraiment une question de formalisation, d'absence de formalisation de la position française à la suite de demandes précises et réitérées. Merci.
text.131: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai une question adressée au gouvernement, mais bien évidemment, les requérants peuvent, s'ils le veulent, y répondre également. Ma question concerne la législation en vigueur en France. Comme vous le savez, les requérants se passent sur l'article 3, ainsi que l'article 3 du protocole n°4, aguent et invitent la Cour à conclure que la France a une obligation positive de prendre des mesures pour faciliter le rapprochement des requérants vers la France. Une telle obligation existe-t-elle ou découle-t-elle de la Convention? C'est à nous d'étranger. Ma question est au gouvernement. Existe-t-il dans la législation en vigueur en France un droit d'être assisté par son État si on est un citoyen français et on se trouve à l'étranger? Existe-t-il un droit dans la législation en France pour le rapprochement ou l'assistance? Bien évidemment, je suis conscient qu'un tel droit n'est pas justiciable. Je fais référence au Conseil d'État qui a dit que le Conseil d'État n'a pas compétence parce que, faisant référence à la séparation du pouvoir et les actes de gouvernement, la Cour a conclu qu'elle n'avait pas une compétence. L'existence d'un droit et la question de justabilité, ce sont deux choses distinctes. Et donc, la deuxième question qui est étroitement liée, dans l'affirmative, si un tel droit existe, comment un particulier peut le faire exécuter ou le faire respecter si les tribunales administratifs se déclarent incompétents? Donc, est-ce qu'il y a, existe-t-il d'autres moyens ou d'autres recours effectifs? Merci.
text.132: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai une question aux avocats de récurrents. Les avocats de récurrents ont mentionné des tentatives pour entrer en contact avec les familles qui se trouvent en Syrie. J'aimerais avoir plus de précisions sur ce point. Je voudrais demander quelles démarches exactes ont été entreprises, à quelle date, pour essayer de contacter les familles en Syrie? Est-ce que les récurrents ont aussi entrepris d'autres démarches auprès des autorités autonomes du nord-est syrien, en vue soit de faciliter le contact avec la famille qui se trouve là-bas, ou en vue d'améliorer leurs conditions de détention? J'aimerais aussi avoir des précisions sur l'éventuelle suite donnée à des démarches de récurrents par des autorités autonomes du nord-est syrien sur ces questions. Merci.
text.133: Thank you very much. I have two questions for the government. The first is more of a clarification on the position. So it is my understanding that the French government has a position that the adults in the camps, including the daughters of the applicants in these cases, are not to be repatriated, that no effort is made to be repatriated. And that is not a question of a capacity to do so, but a policy. So if my understanding is correct on that point. And if so, whether that applies irrespective of the potential dangers to their life, the conditions of their detention, the duration of their detention, and the realistic likelihood of them getting a fair trial where they are now. The second question, and both of these questions leave aside for the moment the issue of jurisdiction, relates to your claim, as I understand it, you have ruled out any form of positive obligation in respect to repatriation, either under Article III of the Convention or Article III of the Fourth Protocol. Let's envisage a situation where a large number of French tourists, due to some transportation disaster, are stranded on a deserted island, which happens to be within the territory of another state, but for some complicated reasons, they would face certain death in the absence of intervention by the French authorities. And let's also assume that this situation is due in part also to their own recklessness. Would it be your submission, then, in such circumstances, there would be no duty, no form of positive obligation under the Convention to undertake any effort, any form of effort, to try and bring them back to the country? Or is it a question of some situations being more sympathetic than others? Thank you.
text.134: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have a question for the applicants and a question for the government, but both parties can answer both questions if they want. The first question is to the applicants. It's about the applicants' connection with Latvia. We heard from you that there are objective legal ties with Latvia. My question is more about the subjective ties. And I apologize if this is a personal question and if you think that it is not relevant, you can of course tell me. But I would like to know whether the applicants consider themselves Latvians. And we heard about the difficulties to obtain naturalization. But is it possible to say that there is a choice of not acquiring Latvian citizenship? And if so, why did then the applicants prefer not to acquire that Latvian citizenship? My second question is for the government. All the applicants in this case worked for some time outside Latvia, and that's the reason why they didn't get that supplement. But I would like to know whether the difference of treatment extinguishes with the passing away of the applicants, or whether there are further effects, for instance on their children, coming from that situation. Thank you.
text.135: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions to both parties. First question, I'd like to ask about the naturalization in Latvia, whether there were any new trends in this area. And more specifically, are there any differences as regards naturalization between permanently resident non-citizens on one side and foreigners and status persons on the other side? And my second question to the government, but of course the applicants, representatives may also intervene and answer this question. Are there any differences, or do you see any differences in the factual situations of the applicants in the present case that would justify a differentiated approach of our court vis-a-vis their complaints? Thank you.
text.136: Thank you. I have two questions. The first question goes to the Ms. Līce, representative of the government. From the outset, the case was made as concerning the supplements of the pensions, whereas we heard from the representative of the applicants that this concerns these periods of employment concerns the pension itself. So I would like to clarify and comment on the impact on the pension itself that the applicants receive. This is a question to the government representative, but of course also the applicant representatives may comment on it. And the second question goes to applicant representative, and in particular to what Ms. Nikuļceva was saying. I would like to clarify what is the basis for an argument that Latvia must assume responsibility for paying pensions for the periods of employment of permanent resident non-citizens outside the territory of the Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic. So it was mentioned, but I'm not sure I clearly understood it. Of course, representative of the government may comment on this question as well. Thank you.
text.137: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I refer this question to both parties, and it's based on a document published on the website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Latvia entitled, Basic Facts About Citizenship and Language Policy of Latvia and Some Sensitive History-Related Issues. And in it, there is a paragraph which reads as follows, and I quote, Non-citizens enjoy equal protection under the law, both in Latvia and while living or traveling abroad, and are the only group of persons, in addition to citizens, who are granted permanent residence in Latvia ex legae. Non-citizens have the same social guarantees as Latvian citizens, including, for example, with regard to pensions and unemployment benefits. As to political rights, the only significant difference between Latvian citizens and non-citizens is the right to vote and to work in the civil service or occupy posts directly related to national security. I would be interested in the observations of both parties in relation to that very broad statement on equal protection under the law in Latvia. Thank you very much.
text.138: Thank you, Mr. President. I thank the government agent for answering my first question. But I'm afraid my second question may have been wrongly interpreted or misunderstood. My second question was whether you see any differences in the factual situation of the current applicants, of the applicants in the present case, among them, if there are any differences in the factual situation of the applicants that would justify, in your view, a differentiated approach of our court vis-a-vis their complaints. Thank you.
text.139: Thank you very much, Mr. President. The case was referred to the Grand Chamber of the Court based on the applicant's request related to Article 9. I take, however, note that the agent of the Norwegian government, both in the written submissions and now during the hearing this morning, has entered into close to a full-fledged reassessment, also under Article 8, where the chamber unanimously found a violation. I have two closely interconnected questions to the agent of the Norwegian government related to the government's position on the interpretation and application of Article 8 taken in isolation, leaving out now the issues under Article 9. Of course, the representative of the applicant is free to address these questions, too, should she so wish. I read the Norwegian government's written submissions to the effect that it agrees with the Starnloeben principles, as did the Norwegian Supreme Court in its Grand Chamber follow rulings 27 March late and subsequent follow-up rulings from that court since then, in parallel with this court's follow-up judgments. The government's position appears to be confirmed by the oral pleadings this morning. My first question is this. Have I understood the Norwegian government position correctly, that the government agrees with the Starrloeben principles in their full range, and now forcefully ask the Grand Chamber of the court both to guard these principles and to apply them? Assuming that the agent will answer this first question in the affirmative, my second question is whether the Norwegian government also accept this court's reading of Starnloeben, as this reading transpires from the court's application of the Starn Loeben principles in subsequent chamber judgments, such as KO and VM versus Norway, November 2019, AS versus Norway, December 2019, Peterson and others versus Norway, 10 March 2020, and Herne Hult versus Norway, 10 March 2020. I need to expound some more on the context and substance of this second question. I remind you that these four Norwegian chamber judgments are all unanimous in finding a violation of Article 8. They were decided by alternating chamber formations. They all refer to and explicitly state that they apply the Starnloeben principles. And they are all final. After the Grand Chamber panel in September last rejected the Norwegian government's request for having the two of them, Peterson and others, and Herne Hult referred to the Grand Chamber. Apart from the fact that the chamber judgment in the current case is not final, Abdi Ibrahim blends apparently squarely and seamlessly into this group of cases. The same can be said about the most recent judgment against Norway on this issue, namely ML versus Norway, 22 December 2020. In addition, the Starnloeben principles have, of course, been referred to and applied by the court in a number of parallel judgments against other member states. I note here that the government's argument before the Grand Chamber panel in Peterson and others and in Herne Hult was that the chamber judgment in those two cases did not represent a correct application of Starnloeben. Moreover, the Norwegian government's arguments before the Grand Chamber panel in those cases were apparently quite similar to those submitted now before the Grand Chamber in this current case, notably arguments in substance related to a lack of deference to the assessment carried out by the domestic authorities. That is, too little subsidiarity, too little margin of appreciation, too much substantial review. And that the court laid too little emphasis on the best interest of the child, but rather gave priority to the biological parents. I also note that the Norwegian government did not ask for the current case, Abdi Ibrahim, to be referred to the Grand Chamber. Nonetheless, the old argument that the Norwegian chamber judgments following up Starn Loeben are not really in compliance with Starn Loeben, but represent rather an extension, is apparently still alive. The alleged errors in the chamber are in substance not case specific. The core critique is systemic. Going to the court's role and the level and character of the European control mechanism under the convention. Indeed, we recognize the gist of these arguments in the submissions made before the Grand Chamber in the current case by the intervening Danish government in referral also to the Copenhagen Declaration. So finally, here is the real substance of my second question. Taking into account the context that I have now just briefly described, and that in cases like this one, where the family ties are cut completely and permanently over, the threshold under Article 8 is indeed very high. And the court applies, according to Starn Loeben, stricter scrutiny, which will inevitably also narrow the margin of appreciation. Would it at all be possible for the court to not finding a violation of Article 8 in this case, as it now stands, without also in the same vein calling into question not only the bulk of chamber judgments handed down subsequently to Starn Loeben, but also Starn Loeben itself? Is the government not in reality, by the character of its arguments, in fact inviting the Grand Chamber of the court to reopen Starn Loeben as precedence and take one or more steps back? And even if this is not the intention of the government, would there not be a real risk that a Grand Chamber judgment not finding a violation of Article 8, based on the arguments forwarded by the government, would be perceived as watering down the Starn Loeben principles? I apologize for having used so much valuable time. And I thank you for your patience, Mr. President. And I thank the agent for the Norwegian government in advance for his replies to my inquiries.
text.140: Thank you, Mr. President. In paragraph 119 of their submissions, the Norwegian government highlight the fact that Article 2 of Protocol Number 1 did not feature in the application to the court or in the referral request. Presumably because of the former, the chamber didn't address this article. So could the parties explain why Article 2 of Protocol 1 can now be considered to fall within the scope of the case before the Grand Chamber? And is the government in paragraph 119 pointing to a possible exhaustion problem in relation to this article? Thank you very much.
text.141: Thank you very much. I actually have two questions. One is primarily to the government. We have heard both parties arguing extensively on the one hand that the authorities did not do enough to find a family with the same or a similar ethnic, religious or cultural background, or the other party said the authorities did enough. Assuming that indeed it was not possible to find such a family, were there nevertheless other restrictions relating to the choice of a foster family among families that do not have the same characteristics as the applicant? So it's not only, my question is, is there not only a question of trying to find the appropriate family, but also avoiding other families? And how does that work in practice? And the second question is primarily directed to the applicant. I heard when the applicant was arguing about Article 9 that at a given moment, but she did not seem, the lawyer did not seem to develop that, she spoke of the positive obligations under Article 9. Could the applicant explain what the complaint is about? Is it about an interference by the state in freedom of religion or about a failure to fulfill a positive obligation under Article 9? Thank you.
text.142: Merci beaucoup, monsieur le Président. J'ai deux questions, une destinée à la représentante de la requérante et la deuxième destinée à l'agent du gouvernement. Commençons donc par la question destinée à la représentante de la requérante. Si j'ai bien compris, aujourd'hui, pendant votre pléthorie, vous avez demandé la réouverture de la procédure interne en base de l'article 46, si j'ai bien compris. J'aimerais bien que vous le confirmiez. Si tel est le cas, pour autant que j'ai bien compris votre position devant la Chambre, vous n'avez pas demandé telle possibilité. Est-ce que vous pouvez expliquer à quoi est dû ce changement de position et pourquoi introduisez-vous, si tel est le cas, devant la Grande Chambre cette nouvelle prétention? Ma deuxième question se dirige particulièrement à l'agent du gouvernement. Le gouvernement que vous représentez n'a pas effectué aucune demande de renvoi du jugement de la Chambre. Donc, normalement, s'il n'y a pas de pétition de renvoi, cela devrait normalement nous laisser entendre que le gouvernement était d'accord avec le jugement de la Chambre. Or, dans votre mémoire, présentée devant la Grande Chambre le 25 novembre 2020, au niveau de vos conclusions, notamment au niveau du paragraphe 166, vous demandez à ce que la Chambre conclue à la non-violation en solitaire de l'article 8. Pouvez-vous, s'il vous plaît, nous expliquer la raison de cette apparente contradiction? Je vous remercie.
text.143: Merci beaucoup monsieur le Président. Ma première question est plutôt factuelle, elle est un peu liée à la première question du juge Lemmens. Il y a une contradiction entre ce que la récurrente et le gouvernement disent par rapport aux essais que le gouvernement, les autorités norvégiennes ont fait de trouver une famille d'accueil pour le fils de récurrente, une famille qui soit d'origine somalienne ou de croyance musulmane. Donc je voudrais que les deux parties répètent quels sont vraiment ces essais, comment sont passés et j'ai une question subséquente, est-ce que, qui est posée au gouvernement, est-ce que le gouvernement et les autorités norvégiennes ont pensé de trouver aussi une famille séculière vu la position de la récurrente mais aussi les experts dans la croyance musulmane qui expliquent le fait que être né musulman signifie complètement différemment autre chose par rapport à des autres croyances. Ça c'est ma première question. Ma deuxième question est relative à la façon dont les deux parties voient le rapport entre l'article 9 de la convention et l'article 2 du protocole 1 parce qu'il me semble que la récurrente avait fait des propos par rapport à la cour de trouver une violation de l'article 9 en relation avec cet article 2 tandis que le gouvernement nous a dit que l'article 9 sans doute il est plus large. Donc quelle sera la préférence du gouvernement et de la récurrente par rapport au rapport entre ces deux articles? Merci beaucoup.
text.144: Thank you, President. My question echoes questions put by judges Lemmens and Motoc on Article 9, but it goes to the applicant. In your memorial, you relied heavily on the case of Tenenbaum versus Sweden, that concerned decision by the Swedish authorities to place their daughters in a Protestant foster family rather than a Jewish one, although they were Jewish, in which the commission stressed on the principles that the authorities were obliged to take into consideration the applicants' wish to have their children be placed in Jewish foster home. And you rightly say that this applies in the present case as well. However, in the Tenenbaum, the commission declared this complaint inadmissible because, I quote, the social authorities explored the possibilities of placing the children in a Jewish foster home, but their endeavors failed because of the other considerations, such as the difficulty to find, without any unnecessary waste of time, relevant home not far from the parents. In the present case, authorities explored three options of placing the applicant's son to a Muslim family not far from the applicant's home. They all failed before placing him in a Christian foster home. So my question is, where do you see the differences between these two situations that would justify, in your view, departure from the findings in the Tenenbaum case? Thank you.
text.145: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have questions to both parties. One question about the situation that has nothing to do with the Section 6 of the Act of 2017. The second question is specifically about the situation created by Section 6 of that Act. The first situations before and after the amending Act. And I would like to know more about the possibilities for the premature termination of the mandate of a member of the National Council of the Judiciary. What are the grounds for a premature termination? There are a number of grounds that are listed in the Act. I know them. But I'm wondering whether there are possibilities for other, whether there are other grounds for termination relating, for instance, to the fact that the member is not actively participating or that he has been convicted for a crime or something else. Are there possibilities for a premature termination based on an explicit decision to be taken? And if so, who would take such a decision? And would there be a possibility for a member of the NCJ to contest such a decision before it has been taken and or after it has been taken? So I would like to know how that was before the Section 6 Act, before the Act of 2017, and also how it is now. Maybe it's the same situation. Secondly, Section 6 of the Act of 2017 terminates Mr. Grzęda's term of office and of his colleagues' Ekslege. The applicant twice stated and very clearly here before us that there was no possibility to challenge this provision before the Constitutional Court. And I would like to ask the government whether the government fully agrees with that statement. And I have another question relating to this Section 6 of the Act of 2017. We have heard a lot about the applicability of Article 6, paragraph 1. We have heard that for the applicant, there was a dispute about the unconstitutionality of the Act. The applicant states that the Act violated the Article 6 and 187 of the Constitution. He also states that there was a civil right, a right to serve a mandate for four years. All that I understand, and my question is not about that. But there is also a complaint about Article 13. And here I would like to know what is the alleged violation of the applicant's rights and freedoms as set forth in the Convention. In other words, from the point of view of Article 13, we are not dealing with civil rights anymore. What are the rights and freedoms that the applicant would have invoked? And how would these rights and freedoms exactly have been violated by the Act? Thank you.
text.146: Thank you. I have one question for the government, but of course the other party can also comment. In your observations and presentation, you state that the exclusion of the members of the NCJ from the right of access to a court is systematically corroborated on the ground of the act, the acting question. And you provide examples regarding the permanent members of the Council's Bureau. So I would ask if you could elaborate on this argument whether the exclusion is systematically corroborated, but particularly regarding for the judges who are holding the position only as members of the Council, like the applicants. Thank you.
text.147: Thank you, Mr. President. The case before the court, of course, concerns termination of office of the NCJ member. And my distinguished colleagues have already asked questions concerning that. But indirectly, there is another point which the parties have argued before us today, which is the construction of Article 187 of the Polish Constitution of 1997 in the part in which it does not provide, and I'm quoting, I think, the agent of the government, for any particular way of the judge members to be elected. And therefore, this has been argued, this was left under paragraph four of the same article to a statute. And so the statute was changed, and so on and so forth. Now, my question concerns the intention of the founders of this Polish Constitution on 1997. We have not had an occasion of having any reference to, for example, preparatory works. We have read the constitutional court judgments, and there have been arguments by the parties concerning that, some references to doctrine. But in my opinion, it would be very important for the court to know. And so my question is addressed to both parties. What can be objectively found in the preparatory works to the Constitution? There is one mention in the documents before us that there was an inspiration on the constitutions of Italy, France, and Spain. And objectively, seeing this article, in my opinion, and I wish to be corrected if I'm wrong, is very close to the article, if I'm not wrong, 122 of the Spanish Constitution of 1978, which also doesn't tell the body competent to choose those judges. And there's been a sort of little, if I'm not wrong, a little constitutional crisis in Spain when the method was changed. If I'm not wrong, at this time judges choose a list, and it is submitted to Parliament in that country. So my interest is in preparatory works to your Constitution. Thank you.
text.148: Thank you, Mr. President. I have similar questions to both parties, but I will read them separately. A question to the applicant. In your Article 6 complaint, you assert that there had been no national legal provision expressly excluding access to a court for a claim based on the alleged unlawfulness of determination of your mandate as a member of the Council of Judiciary. But at the same time, you allege that there has been a violation of Article 13, so no effective remedy. So how could you reconcile these two assertions? Did you have the right, simply, without much, did you have the right under Polish law to challenge that determination or not? And a very similar but reversed question to the government. Regarding applicant's Article 6 complaint, the government maintains that the Polish law excluded access to court for claims relating to the membership in the National Council of the Judiciary. But you also argue that the remedy had been available for the purposes of Article 13. So how to reconcile these two assertions? Was there a remedy or not? And now, after listening to the discussions, I have one more question. I understand from the submissions of oral, especially oral submissions of the government, that the central or the most crucial significance is attributed to the judgment of the Constitutional Tribunal of 2017. Because it was this judgment which had to be implemented by the follow-up act, statutory amendment, which then had the effect of termination of mandate. So that judgment of the 20th of June of 2017. And the court has been presented with a translation of that judgment. And I would like to cite one paragraph of that judgment, one phrase, actually, of that judgment. But before citing that and asking for a comment on that, I would say that perhaps we all know that there are certain standards, universally accepted, internationally accepted standards, long-standing standards of constitutional interpretation. Such methods are used as method of legislative intent, teleological method, purportive interpretation, linguistic method, systemic methods, historical methods, and so on. So now I will cite that judgment. The constitutional court, in the current composition, does not agree with the constitutional court's position adopted in the judgment of 18th of July 2007, number 25K2507, that the Constitution specifies that judicial members of the NCJ shall be elected by judges. Especially the words, court in the current composition does not agree. Could you please comment? First of all, I ask that to the representative of the government comment on which of the universally accepted standards of constitutional interpretation that thesis relies upon. And I also call for the applicant, the representative of the applicant, to comment on that issue if they wish so. Thank you very much.
text.149: Thank you. I have two questions for the applicant. The first relates to your claim that we're dealing with a civil right in this case. And in making that claim, you seem to rely extensively on the emotional or moral impact of the early termination on the applicant, as there seem to be no financial implications in the ordinary labor law sense of the term. My question is, what is the basis in our case law for your suggestion that the emotional impact is enough to make this a civil right? I suppose a minister fired by the prime minister of parliament would also be quite disappointed, and I assume that's understandable. But I suppose you would not suggest that that would give the minister's civil right in the Article VI sense of the term. My second question relates to the second part of the Eskalinan test, if we get to that point, where, as I understand, you've essentially invited the court to set aside a legislative act of the national legislature because it goes contrary to the rule of law and the systems of checks and balances. But now those are quite broad concepts. Is there a specific rule of law with a small "r" that is universally, or at least in a prevailing way, accepted and applied in the Council of Europe legal space that you can identify that has been violated in the current case? Thank you.
text.150: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. J'ai une batterie de questions à l'attention du requérant, des représentants du requérant. Je leur prie d'être le plus précis possible. Même si ces questions sont dirigées donc au requérant, bien entendu, la réaction du gouvernement serait la bienvenue s'il contesterait les données fournies par le requérant. 3 questions. La 1re est la suivante. Quel était le montant exact de la dernière pension de veuvage perçue par le requérant? 2e question. Quelles étaient les sources de revenus du requérant entre ces 57 ans et l'âge de sa retraite? Et dernière, au moment de l'annulation de sa pension, quelle était la situation de ses enfants? Est-ce que le requérant a réellement subvenu à leur nécessité compte tenu de la pension d'orphelins et d'autres aides publiques qu'elle percevait selon le gouvernement? Je vous remercie.
text.151: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai une question pour le gouvernement sur le fonds de l'article 14, lié de l'article 8. Si la Cour trouverait la requête réservable? Je réfère au paragraphe 10 de la Chambre, qui dit que le tribunal fédéral jugea que la distinction opérée par les articles 23 et 24 de la LAVS était effectivement contraire aux principes d'égalité entre l'homme et la femme consacré par l'article 8 aliénatoire de la Constitution. Donc, ma question, quel est, selon le gouvernement, l'impact de cette conclusion par le tribunal fédéral quant à l'appréciation de notre Cour de l'article 14 lié à l'article 8? Merci beaucoup.
text.152: Thank you, Mr. President. Well, the parties so far have focused in their pleadings on the consequences of the withdrawal of the pension on the applicant's family when their children turned 18 years old. What hasn't been addressed so far is, however, the impact of the regulatory regime on the applicant's family when he took the decision to quit his job and take care of his children. Now, it appears that he had to take a higher risk than widows when they seek to return to the labor market. In other words, if a widower decides to exercise his right to family life by taking care of his minor children, he finds himself in a different situation than widows who count on the continued payment of their widow pension. And my question is as follows. What were the effects of the legal framework on the applicant's organization of his family life when he left his prior employment? And could this be a potential ground for rendering Article 8 applicable in the case for the purpose of Article 814? Thank you.
text.153: Thank you very much. Mr. President, I have three sets of questions which relate to the pension, the legitimate aim relied on, and also a question relating to statistics, which follows up on the question just made by Judge Seibert-Fohr. And I address them to both parties, but principally to the government. As regards the pension system, in your written observations, you've principally emphasized sections 23 and 24. But I think, like Judge Pere Pastor Vilanova, we need to know more about the orphan's pension. And I have a more general question relating to the Social Security benefits paid. Social Security systems are usually integrated, so can you explain which, if any, supplementary benefits paid to the applicant or his children were linked or indexed to the fact that he was paid a widower's pension? For example, could the widow or widower's pension be supplemented if the income of the surviving parent or child is modest? My next question relates to the legitimate aim relied on. According to the well-established case law of this court, references to traditions, general assumptions, and prevailing social attitudes constitute insufficient justification for differential treatment. I therefore turn to the chamber judgment and what the government relied on before the chamber, which was, and I quote, paragraph 71 of the chamber judgment, the legitimate aim relied on is the assumption that a husband provides for the financial maintenance of his wife, particularly where she has children. So I would ask the government to address the legitimate aim they are now relying on in the light of the well-established case law I've just referred to. My final point relates to statistics. And as I said, it links in with the question just asked by Judge Seibert-Fohr. The government has provided us with statistics in their written observations relating to the percentage of men and women in full-time employment and the percentage of women in employment working part-time. However, for the purpose of assessing the withdrawal of the pension when the children reached the age of majority, I'm trying to understand why we don't have statistics for the employment rate of men and women who seek to re-enter the labor market after a substantial number of years, in this case 17 years, after being absent and within less than 10 years from retirement age. The government referred us to a 2012 study which suggests that more widowers than widows exercise their choice to remain economically active. But my question is, does this not point to the likelihood that the re-entry of men who have chosen to stay at home would be particularly difficult in the context of the Swiss labor market? Thank you.
text.154: Merci Monsieur le Président. J'ai trois questions à poser. La première, j'aimerais savoir jusqu'à quel âge les filles du requérant étaient en formation et dorénavant qu'il a dû subvenir à ses besoins. Jusqu'à quel âge elles étaient en formation. Deuxième question, au gouvernement, on a des statistiques des bénéficiaires d'une rente de veuve 1593 en 2019 tandis qu'il y avait une rente de veuve 38378 dans le même temps. Nous savons qu'il y a deux cas de figure de rente de veuve. Une similaire à cette rente de veuve avec des enfants mineurs et l'autre, les veuves qui ont au moment du décès du mari 45 ans ou plus et qu'elle s'était mariée pendant cinq ans. Est-ce que le gouvernement a des statistiques pour les rentes de veuve similaires aux rentes de veuve? Les rentes de veuve avec des enfants mineurs n'est pas l'autre cas de figure de rente de veuve, celle de 45 ans. C'est la première question pour le gouvernement et la deuxième dont la pléthorie, le gouvernement a mentionné une allocation de formation de 250 francs que chacune des filles aurait pu toucher. Est-ce qu'il s'agit avec cette allocation de formation de l'allocation familiale dans le sens de la loi ou est-ce qu'il s'agit d'autre chose? Allocation familiale dans le sens de la loi suisse sont pas allouées aux filles mais aux parents. Ici, aux pères qui auraient pu les utiliser ou auraient dû les utiliser pour subvenir aux besoins des enfants. Est-ce qu'il s'agit de ça? Est-ce qu'il s'agit d'une allocation pour le père pour qu'il peut subvenir aux besoins des enfants? Alléger sa tâche de subvenir aux besoins des enfants pendant la durée de la durée de la formation.
text.155: Thank you, Mr. President. Thanks to the representative of the parties for their clear interventions. I have one question to the government and one question to the applicants. As regards my question to the government, as you have pointed out, the revocation of the license was at the end of an uninterrupted series of sanctions. You submitted that the council had no choice than to apply the harshest sanction. I note that the most severe sanction before revocation that was imposed on NIT was the suspension of the license of five days. My question is, did the council have discretionary power to opt for imposing a sanction with a more deterrent effect, such as, for instance, suspension of the license for one month, two months, or three months, thus being less intrusive than the revocation? And if so, why did it not make use of that power? My question to the applicants is the following. Before the domestic courts, NIT argued that the decision to revoke its license was politically driven. The domestic courts rejected that allegation as being unsubstantiated. Before this court, NIT repeats that allegation. In its written submissions, NIT states that, I quote, the political class by all means wanted to find a judicial solution to put an end to the channel's existence. And the withdrawal of the license was motivated by political revenge of the government. This is a severe allegation. And such an allegation could be accepted, but only when it's supported by at least strong and concrete indications. My question to you is, could you provide the court with concrete facts that support your allegation that the revocation decision taken by the council in 2012 was politically driven? Thank you.
text.156: Thank you very much, Mr. President. My questions are for both parties. The monitoring exercise which led to the revocation decision in this case was commenced on the 29th of March, 2012. The report was communicated to the applicant only two days later, on the 2nd of April. It was discussed by the council with the applicant present on the 5th of April, and the decision was adopted on that same day. And it came into force on the 6th of April. So my question is, is such a rapid administrative procedure normal and in conformity with domestic law? And I ask this because I note that the Supreme Court referred to a normal administrative procedure taking 15 working days. My second question relates to monitoring exercises and their consequences generally. I understand that 13 monitoring exercises took place in the relevant period between 2009 and 2012. This question is particularly directed at the government, but the applicant can, of course, respond. Could the government indicate if sanctions were imposed on other broadcasters during this period? They said in their oral submissions that other broadcasters were monitored. But what I would like to know is where those broadcasters sanctioned. If so, how often and for what? In the file, I could only find one concrete example. That was the public warning given to national television in the decision of the 5th of April, 2012. Thank you very much.
text.157: Thank you very much, Mr. President. My question is for the government, and it relates to the enforcement of the withdrawal decision. And it is a matter of domestic law. My first element would be attached to Article 3810 of the Ordovisual Code. And at the material time, this provision had the following wording, a decision by the Ordovisual Coordinating Council applying a sanction which is not contested within the allocated time limit shall constitute a writ of enforcement. And my question to the government relating to this provision would be if the government could please specify its understanding of that provision at the material time. The second element of my question connected to this relates then to the subsequent change of this provision. End of May 2012, this provision was abolished, and then we had a new provision in 38.8 with the following wording, the decision of the Ordovisual Coordinating Council regarding the application of any sanction will be motivated becoming enforceable from the date of adoption and notification to the broadcasters and distributors of targeted services by registered letter with subsequent publication. My question related to this provision would be what was the motivation behind the adjustment of the text, the changement of the text from the previous article 38.10 to the new 38.8 in May 2012? And the third element of the question relates to the subsequent development. The Constitutional Court, as I understand it, found that the new provision, article 38.8, was in violation of the Constitution, and in particular as to the Constitution's provisions on free speech. And my third element, the question here would be what was the core reasoning in the Constitutional Court's judgments as to this finding? Thank you.
text.158: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions for the government, but of course the applicant is very welcome to address them as well. My first question relates to the formula for the appointment of the audiovisual council. And I refer here to annex 16 of the government's submissions, which include the Council of Europe analysis and comments on a former draft, so pre-final draft of the audiovisual code, and specifically page 29 of this Council of Europe comments related to then-draft Article 42 of the bill. And the third comment by the Council of Europe is that the appointment by a 2 3rd majority of parliament, and I quote here, is to be welcome. It is, however, my understanding that in the final version of the draft, a number of changes were made in line with the Council of Europe recommendations that the 2 3rd majority, which the Council of Europe had welcomed, has been removed altogether from the draft. And I was wondering if you could elucidate a little bit in terms of the legislative history, why was that decision made? And in relation to that, in your submission here today orally, you argued that the council had full independence in law and in fact. And if you could comment on the European Commission's country progress report for 2012, so it's the relevant period, it's a report done annually as part of the European Neighborhood Partnership process of Moldova dated 20 March 2013. There is a single recommendation there on the media scene in the country, and I quote, ensure the full and effective independence of the audiovisual coordinating council. So if you could comment on that, please. And my second question is a little bit of a follow up to Judge Bårdsen third question on the constitutional court ruling of 6 December 2012. And what I would like to know specifically is what do you think the implications of that ruling, again, that it was unconstitutional for two, in particular, two sanctions imposed by the council, temporary suspension of license and final de-licensing, to be immediately enforceable. That is my understanding of the constitutional court decision. What, in your view, are the implications of the decision for the current case? And I don't mean in terms of national administrative law. I mean in terms of national constitutional law and Article 10 of the convention. Thank you.
text.159: Thank you very much. I'm interested in which way the monitoring exercises are organized. Are they organized on the regular basis, few times a year, once a year, for how long? Or they are organized ad hoc? It's just a coincidence that this last monitoring exercise that was the basis for the decision was actually at the time when the demonstrations were organized or were about to be organized. So if you please can answer that. Then what are the parameters that were taken into consideration then when pluralism was measured? Was it just content-based parameter? Or other parameters were taken into consideration because we know there are a number of them, if you could clarify that. And then what caught my eye today during the presentations was the claim that the members of the commission were subjectively and objectively independent. And when I was reading the minutes, what caught my eye was, and I will read the sentence of one of the participants. Moreover, we remember the shows that were made, even regarding me personally, I did not react. It was, I consider, abnormal. So this is something what was reported by the station about him. But as history shows, harmful phenomena leave a mark on what is happening. So if you could comment on conflicts of interest and the possibility of a person to sit in this commission deciding on this case. Thank you.
text.160: Thank you very much. I have a follow-up question to what my colleague O'Leary asked about the time taken by the council to come to its decision. There was a notification of the report to the applicant on the 2nd of April, I think. And on the 5th of April, there was the meeting and the decision. We can also see that during the domestic proceedings, the applicant company complained about the fact that it did not have enough time to prepare its defense for that meeting. Could both parties say something about this, whether it is normal not only to have such a short time for the preparation, but in particular, such a short time for the hearing to be set once the monitoring report is being sent to the broadcasting company concerned? And could the broadcasting company have asked for an adjournment of that meeting? And would it have any chance of being granted? Thank you.
text.161: Do we know in this concrete case who ordered the monitoring and on which basis with which explanation this five days monitoring that was taking place before we got this decision that we are having in front of us?
text.162: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. J'ai 2 questions à formuler aux représentants du gouvernement. Bien entendu, le requérant est libre d'y répondre si tel est son choix. Selon l'exposé des motifs de la loi relative à l'administration fiscale de 2003, la publication des données personnelles des contribuables défaillants doit encourager un comportement respectueux de la loi, mais aussi de faire connaître au tiers la solvabilité des contribuables. Mes questions sont alors les suivantes. Quand une personne physique est débitrice de l'Etat au titre de sa responsabilité civile ou pénale, est-ce que son identité et domicile sont aussi dévoilés publiquement? Si tel n'est pas le cas, pouvez-vous justifier cette éventuelle différence de traitement en faveur du fisc? Plus précisément, est-ce que les personnes condamnées pénalement pour fraude fiscale sont-elles l'objet d'une forme de publicité sur un portail d'Internet libre d'accès? Je vous remercie.
text.163: Thank you, Mr. President. I do have two questions. One is addressed to the government and the other one to the applicant. My question to the government concerns the search interface that was introduced as of the 1st of January 2020 based on the 2017 amendment of the Tax Administration Act. I'm perfectly aware that the government is objecting to the admissibility, arguing that the applicants failed to exhaust domestic remedies. Leave that aside for a second. My question is, in the view of the government, is this search interface more or less intrusive, a more serious or less serious interference with the applicant's rights compared to the Article 55, Paragraph 5 enlist, meaning that this information is not accessible, it doesn't give us the access to the full list, it requires searching, but at the same time, it also includes time-barred tax debts. My question to the applicant concerns the reputation. The applicant is, before the Grand Chamber, heavily relying upon the protection of reputation, arguing that the publication of the tax debt's list touches upon the applicant's reputation or honor. My question concerns what is the legal basis for that argument. Is there any case law supporting that view? And let me explain very briefly why I'm asking that question. We have extensive case law concerning defamation proceedings. If someone disseminates subjective assessments or unproven facts or accusations concerning an individual's moral, ethical, or legal behavior, it may touch upon honor and reputation. On the other hand, dissemination of objective facts about an individual which are factually correct but of a private nature may touch upon private life. So my question is why, in the view of the applicant, does dissemination of objective facts, tax debts, about the applicant which is factually correct, how can it, and on what legal basis, touch upon honor and reputation? Thank you.
text.164: Thank you, Mr. President. I have one question for the government, but of course the other party can also comment. As you said it in your observations and today in the presentation, one of the legitimate aims pursued by the law is to enable potential business partners to be properly informed about the applicant's tax debts. So I would like to understand whether under the national system there are any other means, ways, through which a potential business partner may find information about another person's tax history. Thank you.
text.165: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions which were prompted by the intervention of the representative of the government, so my questions are addressed to Mr. Tallódi, but the other applicant's lawyer may also comment on them. My first question relates to the effectiveness of the measure in question. Unless I misunderstood something, the representative of the government spoke, in fact, against measuring effectiveness of this measure, so my question would be quite theoretical, or maybe from the field of legal sociology. How one can speak about the effectiveness of the measure if that effectiveness cannot be measured? And if it cannot be measured, how it can then be proven, and how it can be asserted? Maybe you still have some data, I don't know, opinion survey, any statistical data proving the effectiveness of the measure, and if the other party wants to answer that question, maybe you have the data to the contrary, not just general considerations, but the concrete data that we could rely upon. My other question is to the representative of the government, but also to the other party, if they want to comment on that. What other publicly available list of, to use the term used already in this hall, of rule breakers, what other lists exist in Hungary that would be publicly available? Just to give several examples, traffic violators, drunk drivers, property misappropriators, domestic violence offenders, sexual offenders, medical malpractitioners, exam cheaters, state secret disclosures, bribe givers or takers, polygamists, whatever, criminals, and if such lists exist, in how many, or in which of them, the home address of a violator of the offender or potential offender is indicated? Thank you very much.
text.166: Three questions, two for the government and the applicant, and the other one for the applicant, but of course the government can comment. The first one is about the taxpayer identification code. The government argued that the applicant had and doesn't have a taxpayer identification code because now you talk about taxpayer identification code, but as far as I understood beforehand, it was another position. What I would like to understand is if the applicant has or not a tax identification code, a tax identification number, because if there is, I would like to understand why it is, as you have just said, more antisocial than the home address. The second question is about the availability in the search interface. I'd like to understand if it is based on the same facts, the same taxes, and the same data. That means the home address and the name and the amount of the debt. The third question is more for the applicant. You said that the tax authority has any control mechanism on the impact or impact assessment, but the government argued that the tax authority is due to the enforcement proceedings, which were unsuccessful due to the applicant's lack of any property or income. I would like to know your opinion, to have a comment on this issue. Thank you very much.
text.167: Thank you. I have one question for both parties and two questions for the government. My question for both the parties is about the circular mentioned in paragraph 13 of the chamber's judgment, a circular issued by the National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information on February 2012 about the illegal publication of tax data of private individual in local authorities. Did the government or the administration or the tax administration follow this circular? And I have two questions for the government. The first, on your observation before the court of last July, you mentioned in paragraph 3 the following, I quote, the attempts of a forced collection against the applicant's property and income were unsuccessful as he had no property and very limited income. Therefore, the tax debts were temporarily declared unrecoverable on 16 November 2015. End of the quotation. My first question is, if this is the case, which were your expectations by publishing the name of the applicant two months later? And my second question, does the law provide any individual assessment of the need of such publication? And if yes, which is the competent organ for this individual assessment? Thank you.
text.168: Thank you very much. In a way, this is the follow-up to the first question by Judge Vilanova. I'm interested if tax evasion would be committed as an offense, and you have criminal record in Hungary. This tax evasion would be recorded in the criminal record. So what are safeguards there for how long this could be kept? And are there any other safeguards in terms who could access, so that we would compare criminal records with the lists that we have in front of us? Thank you.
text.169: Thank you very much, Mr. President. My first question is directed to the applicants who contended that the 2017 Act was not amenable to a constitutional complaint because it essentially contained the same provisions as the 2003 Act. However, from your written submissions and the oral submissions today, it would appear that the creation of the search interface in 2017 was an innovative and new aspect. So leaving aside questions relating to the scope of the case, I would like to understand, was there an effective constitutional complaint remedy available in relation to this new aspect of the 2017 Act? My second question is directed principally at the government. And I will preface the question by emphasizing that this court is not, of course, competent to apply or examine alleged violations of European Union law. However, in the instant case, the content of Hungarian national law on data protection includes, indeed, one could say it's determined previously by the 1995 Data Protection Directive and now by the 2016 GDPR, the Data Protection Regulation, which, of course, is a directly applicable measure of EU law. Given that context, can you explain what, if any, examinations of the 2003 and 2017 Tax Acts occurred in the light of the relevant EU Data Protection Acts, first when Hungary acceded to the European Union, and then subsequently in 2017 when the new legislation was updated and the GDPR was already in existence? In addition, it might be useful if the government, or indeed the applicant, if they had this information, could inform us whether the European Commission in relation to Hungary or any other of the very many EU member states who operate a similar scheme have challenged the compatibility of such schemes in relation to the GDPR. My final question is really addressed to both the applicant and the government, and it is a plea which comes from a non-Hungarian lawyer. The applicant very usefully explained to us that the reliable taxpayers' lists doesn't use a home address. It uses a name and a tax identification code. Now, this follows on, I think, from a previous questioner. But did the applicant have a tax identification code that could have been used? And if so, why was such a code not sufficient for the purposes of one or other of the legitimate aims sought by the publication of the list? In other words, was the tax identification code sufficient to identify him in the eyes of the public? Thank you very much.
text.170: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I come back to the government in relation to the answer to one of my three questions. Now, in the instant case, either because the applicant didn't exhaust any effective remedies or because there were no effective remedies, we have no judicial review of the questions before us. So, parliamentary review becomes quite important. And therefore, I would like to know whether either when Hungary acceded to the European Union or when the GDPR regulation was adopted, which was quite a seismic occurrence throughout all EU member states, was there any review of this tax publication regime? Thank you.
text.171: Merci, M. le Président. A mes questions, le représentant du gouvernement vient de nous dire qu'il y a une publicité en Hongrie en relation, donc, avec les crimes sexuels. text.173: Thank you very much. I have two questions, one for the applicants and one for the government. To the applicants first, because it concerns the exhaustion of domestic remedies, you are certainly aware of our case law in this matter, and more precisely of the Akdivar versus Turkey case. My second question to the government, if agent, if I understood you well, you said in substance that the Norwegian state exercised the role of a mere regulator and supervisor of the activities on the continental shelf. This is, in a nutshell, if I understood you well, your main thesis. Well, you are certainly aware of the articles on state responsibility by the International Law Commission, the UN International Law Commission, codifying this matter, as recognized by a number of actors, including by the International Court of Justice. According to Article 5 of those articles, if an act or omission of a private entity can be attributed to the state if such entity exercises elements of governmental authority, elements of governmental authority. So my question is, do you think that this condition is fulfilled in the present case, elements of governmental authority? Thank you very much.
text.174: Thank you very much. I have just one question to the applicant. My question is the following. text.175: Thank you. text.176: Thank you very much, President. I have a question for the applicant. I'm sorry. text.177: Merci, M. le Président. Ma question s'adresse à la représentante du gouvernement français. Vous nous avez dit qu'à vos yeux, une atteinte portée à l'article 8 était en principe dénuée de conséquences préjudiciables irréversibles. J'ai même cru comprendre, à un moment donné, et je voudrais que vous me confirmiez si j'ai bien compris, que vous estimiez que si de telles conséquences irréversibles devaient être attachées à une atteinte portée à la vie familiale, elle ressortirait alors du champ d'application de l'article 3 plutôt que du champ d'application de l'article 8. Premier aspect de ma question, ai-je bien compris votre pensée ou ai-je tort? Le second volet de ma question est le suivant. Imaginons que dans des circonstances comparables à celles qui ont conduit à l'interpellation de M. de Souza Ribeiro, un étranger en situation irrégulière soit interpellé en Guyane et qu'il fasse valoir, pendant sa rétention administrative, qu'il a charge de famille, qu'il est père de plusieurs enfants en bas âge, qu'il constitue la seule source de revenus avec laquelle ses enfants peuvent vivre et qu'à ses yeux, son éloignement du territoire de la Guyane pourrait constituer une situation dramatique aux conséquences irréversibles. Ma question est alors double. Est-ce que le gouvernement considère que dans une telle situation, il y aurait lieu à un examen particulier qui pourrait conduire, même en l'absence de caractères suspensifs du recours, à faire en sorte que son éloignement n'intervienne pas avant que son recours soit jugé? Et deuxième point, est-ce que le mode de fonctionnement concret du dispositif policier et juridictionnel tel qu'il est établi en Guyane permettrait la prise en compte d'une situation particulière comme celle-ci?
text.178: Le 6 février, ça veut dire à peu près 10 jours après l'éloignement, le récurrent a déposé une requête en référé liberté devant le tribunal administratif de Cayenne en demandant à ce qu'il soit fait injonction au préfet de Guyane d'organiser le retour en France. text.179: Thank you, President. Just a question first to the applicant. The question is, I've seen that indeed there is the right to get a titre de cejour once a person comes of age, once he is 18. text.180: Thank you President, I have two questions to the parties. One is related to the government's statement that the police officer had no way of knowing the situation of the applicant. text.181: Ma question s'adresse à l'État et aussi aux requérants. text.182: I have just a very brief question. It's probably primarily to the applicant. I understand that there is a possibility to lodge a claim for compensation following illegal decisions. text.183: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions to both parties. The first question to the Georgian representative. text.184: I would like to hear the parties additional views on article 38 of the convention and in particular on the circumstances, if any, when a state party to the convention can raise the plea of, say, state secret or official secret or national security in opposition to that article. Thank you.
text.185: Thank you, President. In fact, I have one question to the applicant government and one to the respondent government. The applicant government refers to an administrative practice. text.186: Thank you, President. I have three questions to both parties. I understand that the applicant on 26th of December 2010 was detained on remand on account of the second criminal charge. So I would wish to ask, when was the applicant brought before a judge according to Article 5, Paragraph 3? Namely, where a judge told him first the offense of which he was suspected, and second, where he could explain himself. Third, under Article 5, Paragraph 3, a release from detention may be conditioned by guarantees to appear for trial. I have now heard the submissions of the applicant that 77 members of Parliament and the National Ombudsman offered guarantees for the applicant appearing at trial, apparently to the sum of about 100,000 euros. My question in the present case, in view of these guarantees, was an alternative preventive measure for the applicant adequately considered? Thank you.
text.187: Thank you. I have just one question to the government. The government have pleaded that the arrest was based on the allegation that Mr. Lutsenko had put pressure on the witnesses. text.188: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions. My first question goes to both parties. Thank you.
text.189: I have a number of questions. The first of all, three questions I would like to put to the government. Firstly, is it the government's argument that before an act can be regarded as a manifestation of a religious belief, as opposed to being motivated or inspired by that belief, it must be mandated by the religion in question, or at least form part of the practice of the religion or belief in a generally recognized form? If so, how is this court to determine this question in cases where an applicant asserts and the respondent denies that it is so mandated? Is this rather narrow approach consistent with that adopted by the Grand Chamber in the Leyla Şahin case, where the court did not examine whether the wearing of an Islamic scarf was mandated by the Muslim religion? Secondly, do the government argue that there can be no interference at all with the manifestation of religious belief in the context of employment if the applicant can reconcile that conflict by resigning and seeking employment elsewhere? If so, must the employer do more than merely assert this by showing the genuine possibility of alternative employment? If this is not the government's argument, in what circumstances would the government accept that there could be an interference? And thirdly, in the case of Mrs. Ladele, does it, in the view of the government, make a difference that at the time of her original employment, civil partnerships did not exist and that new requirements were effectively imposed on her when she was asked to perform civil partnership ceremonies? Do you argue that the same approach should be adopted to the claims under Article 9 and under Article 14, whether the employer is a state authority or a private law company or association? If not, how is it suggested that the court's approach should differ when dealing with the positive obligations of the state, as in the two cases in question? I note that reliance is placed, strong reliance is placed in the written observations on this section's judgment in Jakóbski, but that, of course, was a case which clearly involved direct state intervention in the sense it concerned the prison authorities in Poland. Then I have two factual questions. The first addressed to Mrs. Eweida, is it correct that prior to May 2006, Mrs. Eweida wore a cross, but that the cross was not visible over her uniform? text.190: Thank you. My question concerns the Eweida case. text.191: Yes, I would like to ask a factual question in the context of what has been proposed, that employers cannot be forced to accommodate the beliefs of the religious convictions of their employees. My question, and I ask this sincerely out of sheer ignorance of what the position is in England, but is there any law in the United Kingdom which, in the context of hospital services, allows hospital employees, particularly nurses but possibly even doctors, to opt out of certain interventions, operations, whatever, on the grounds of conscientious objection? text.192: Thank you, Mr. President. My question is related to the previous questions of Judge Hirvelä concerning change in British Airways dress code policy, symbol policy. What did it mean? This question is for both parties. Did it mean that British Airways indirectly and tacitly recognized the violation of the applicant's rights? Thank you.
text.193: Thank you, Mr. President. text.194: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two, in fact, three questions. The first one regards the sentencing policy of the state courts compared to the one of the entities courts. And finally, and this question is suggested, has been suggested to me by the arguments presented by the applicants, are there any examples of any sentences of the state court where more lenient sentences were handed out, handed down than the sentences of the entities courts for similar facts? Is there any case where for similar facts, the state court has sentenced the person in a more lenient way than the sentences of the entities courts? Thank you.
text.195: I have a question to the respondent government. text.197: Thank you, President. I have a group of questions to begin with on the conditions of detention. Were all prisoners provided? In fact, could all prisoners be provided with food, bed linen and drinking water in a sufficient quality? text.198: Thank you. I have a question to the government concerning the applicant's complaint under Article 8 of the Convention. I would like to ask you to comment on proportionality and necessity of this measure. Also, had the applicant complained to the administrative court as the government suggested she had to do? Would the administrative court examine not only legality but proportionality of the impugned measure according to relevant legislation and domestic case law? And was this remedy effective in the applicant's situation? And on this latter point, I would like to ask the applicant to comment as well. Thank you.
text.199: Merci, M. le Président. Mes questions s'adresseront à l'agent du gouvernement. Ma première question est une demande de confirmation. Vous nous avez dit, Madame, que l'orientation sexuelle des requérantes n'était pas pertinente dans cette affaire parce que, de toute façon, l'adoption était impossible en raison du refus opposé par le père biologique. Ma question est donc la suivante. Si le père biologique avait donné son accord, la Cour doit-elle comprendre qu'alors l'adoption aurait été possible, quelle que soit l'orientation sexuelle et le sexe des requérantes. Ma seconde question est la suivante. Vous nous avez rappelé que l'intérêt de l'enfant est un principe si important en droit autrichien qu'il a maintenant valeur constitutionnelle. Deuxième point, dans votre mémoire écrite au point 3.3, je lis, ma citation sera brève, des couples homosexuels peuvent être pour l'essentiel personnellement, personnellement en italique, aussi appropriés ou non que des couples hétérosexuels pour adopter des enfants.
