Furthermore, according to section 66, paragraph 6 of the same act, an asylum seeker may, within the time limit of nine months, request the continuation of a request for asylum. Therefore, my question, is it correctly understood that if the applicants had left the border transit zone, the processing of the request would have been discontinued? And are there any examples in practice where the authorities have decided, on the basis of a request from an asylum seeker, to continue the processing of a request that has been discontinued? My last question to the government is the following. The Hungarian authorities relied on Serbia as being a safe third country. According to the government, the authorities did so on the basis of a general assessment of the situation in Serbia, as well as an assessment of the applicant's individual situation. My question is, are there any examples in practice, in particular during the relevant period in 2015, where Hungarian authorities exceptionally have reached the conclusion that Serbia was not a safe third country, or was Serbia, in all cases, regarded as being a safe third country? Thank you, Mr. President.
text.234: Thank you, Mr. President. My question follows the last question of my learned colleague, Judge Kjølbro. And it is directed to the government, but the applicants can, of course, provide information and opinion. The question is, section 2 of the government's decree 191, 2015 provides for a list of countries to be considered safe for purposes of removals of asylum seekers. Then the question is, how safe is this consideration as safe countries, especially if we consider that the Balkan route, including Serbia, was facing very high migrant fluxes in the summer, autumn 2015? I invite you to consider as well paragraph 48 of the EU procedures directive as to the update of this information. The second question, this court in Sufi and Elmi has defined the sources of information for the purpose of qualifying a safe country of destination, being third or original country. In conducting their assessment, should national authorities and eventually this court rely in other sources of information on the country of destination situation, such as, for example, credible media reports? Thank you, Mr. President.
text.235: Thank you, Mr. President. I have short questions, better to say comments. I would like to hear comments of both parties concerning the concept of so-called inherent limitations on personal freedom and liberties introduced by the government, Hungarian government in their written submissions and in the presentation of this morning. More precisely, in the course of the legal qualification of the measures on which applicants had been subjected in the transit zone, government is invoking the concept of inherent limitations of personal liberty. Can you say a little bit more precisely what does it mean, specifically in the context of the court's jurisprudence, court's case law regarding the Article 5 of the convention? Thank you, Mr. President.
text.236: Thank you very much, Mr. President. Just, I have one follow-up question, which is prompted by the pleadings of the government this morning and follows one of the questions posed by my colleague, Judge Kjølbro . There is a crucial element in this case, and that is the implementation by the Hungarian authorities of the safe third country concept. In 2009, the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe issued guidelines on human rights protection in the context of accelerated asylum procedures, where the safe third country concept is developed. One of the criteria mentioned for the appropriate application of that concept is that the third country, in our case, Serbia, will admit the asylum seeker. Now, this seems to be, and now here comes my question, and I would like your comment on this. In section 51A of the Asylum Act of 2007, which was in force at the time of the proceedings, it stated as follows. If the safe country of origin, which we're not dealing with here, or the safe third country refuses to admit or to take back the applicant, the asylum authority shall withdraw its decision and shall continue the procedure. Now, my question is, Mr. Tallódi, you said this morning that the readmission procedure had not been triggered. So may I ask, on what basis were the Hungarian authorities in conformity with 51A of your Asylum Act? To what extent were there assurances made that Serbia would, in fact, readmit the applicants on the facts of this case, and therefore, to what extent, if your answer is that no such readmission was made explicitly by the Serbian government, how that would conform with the implementation of this safe third country concept. Thank you.
text.237: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai une question à l'avocate des requirants. C'est une question concernant un point plutôt formel, mais quand même, vous avez informé la Cour que vous n'avez plus de contact avec vos clients. Et là, mes questions. Est-ce que vos clients, les requirants, ont connaissance de l'arrêt de la Chambre et du renvoi de l'affaire devant la Grande Chambre et du condamne de votre dernier contact avec les requirants? Et dernière question, pourquoi pensez-vous que malgré la perte de contact avec vos clients, la Grande Chambre devait poursuivre l'examen de cette affaire? Et bien sûr, le gouvernement peut aussi se prononcer sur ce point. Merci.
text.238: Oui, j'aurais une question à l'avocate des requérants. Quelles étaient les persécutions concrètes? Vous avez parlé des persécutions des requérants en Serbie. Et quelles étaient vraiment les persécutions concrètes? Et puisque la Serbie est aussi un pays membre du Conseil de l'Europe et de la Convention, pourquoi les requérants n'ont jamais essayé des recours juridiques en Serbie? Merci.
text.239: Thank you, President. I have two questions for the government, but the applicant can also comment if they wish. So in your observation, your government relied on paragraph three of article seven of the Reception of Asylum Seekers Act, which is the only exception to inapplicability of provision for extension of material assistance for Dublin asylum cases. But article three, in fact, allowed this extension on the basis of special circumstances relating to respect for human dignity. Now, in the very detailed instructions issued by FEDASIL in July 2012 on withdrawal of material assistance, we just heard from you that, yes, this instruction was not applicable in 2011. But to the extent this instruction reflects a summary of relevant practice, what was meant under these special circumstances? It is not clear from the instruction. Could you please specify the FEDASIL practice in this respect? What exactly was meant under special circumstances for the purpose of paragraph three of article seven? And my second question, what was the exact legal ground on which FEDASIL finally provided the applicants with accommodation on 5th and then on 7th October 2011? Thank you.
text.240: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. Je vais poser 2 questions. Elles sont destinées principalement aux requérants. Bien entendu, rien n'empêche le gouvernement de donner sa réponse. En ce qui concerne la 1re question, c'est la suivante. Quelle était l'implication exacte du requérant dans l'agression du 29 mai 2006? Je vous prie de donner tous les détails possibles quant à son degré de participation personnelle dans ce délit. Et la 2e question est la suivante. Est-ce que le requérant avait la possibilité d'obtenir la nationalité danoise avant sa condamnation pénale de 2009? Si tel était le cas, pourquoi n'a-t-il pas exercé ce droit? Je vous remercie, M. le Président.
text.241: Thank you, Mr. President. I do have three questions. The first one is addressed to the government. The government is arguing that the Papashvili test, as reflected in paragraph 183, does not apply and cannot be transposed to persons suffering from mental illnesses, as, in the view of the government, it only applies to persons suffering from physical illnesses. Assuming that the government is correct in its assumption, what is or should, in the view of the government, be the relevant test to be performed by the court? Is the protection under Article 3 to be limited to cases where there is a risk of self-harm or suicide? I did not find the government's position very clear on this point. My second question, both parties, as well as all the third parties intervening before this court, have addressed and discussed the test established in paragraph 183 of the Papashvili judgment, including how to apply it to persons suffering from mental illnesses. From some of the interventions, in particular the intervention from the UK government, referring to the judgment from the UK Supreme Court, it transpires that the Papashvili test, as formulated in paragraph 183, may give rise to some uncertainty when it comes to the right interpretation, and therefore also when it comes to the correct application of the test. Therefore, my question is, in the view of the government, is that does the test in practice, or has the test in practice given rise to problems of interpretation and in the affirmative, which elements of the test have given rise to uncertainty? My third and last question is to both parties. In this case, the question of removal or expulsion of a foreigner suffering from an illness arose in the context of criminal proceedings, more specifically when the domestic courts, under section 58 of the Aliens Act, were called upon to assess amending the committal order and at the same time the question of revocation of the expulsion order. In other words, in this case, Article 3 concerns a foreigner with a prior lawful stay in Denmark. However, the issue of removal of a foreigner suffering from an illness, be it physical or mental, may also arise outside the context of criminal proceedings, in particular when assessing requests for residence permits under section 9B of the Aliens Act, based on humanitarian grounds, which, according to the preparatory works as well as domestic practice, would include an assessment in conformity with Article 3 of the Convention, including Pappersville. Now my question, is it correctly understood that whatever the court may say in this case concerning the expulsion of a foreigner with a prior lawful stay would also apply equally to cases concerning requests for residence permits, I'm referring to persons without a prior lawful stay in Denmark? Thank you.
text.242: Thank you very much, Mr. President. Judge Kjølbro's questions related mainly to Article 3. Mine may be of relevance if the court undertakes an analysis of Article 8. In the applicant's case, a permanent ban on reentry was imposed. And my questions are as follows. Is there provision under Danish law for the application of a temporary ban on reentry? And if so, in what circumstances would it be applied? And could the High Court in 2015 have amended the permanent reentry ban imposed by the High Court in 2008 to a temporary one? And if so, on what basis? My second question, and these questions are for both parties, is what was the degree of the applicant's dependence on his family in Denmark when he became an outpatient from 2014? Where did he live? With whom? We know now from the submissions of the Danish government that he continued to receive a disability pension. But was he otherwise socially or financially dependent on his family? And the reason for this question is because I didn't find these factual details elaborated in the decision of the High Court of 2015. Thank you very much.
text.243: Thank you very much. I have two questions which are on a factual nature, which can be addressed to both representatives, both parties. The first question is, the applicant was assigned a curator at Liethem in the domestic proceedings for the revocation of the expulsion order. In domestic law, in this case, did this mean that the court considered he lacked mental and legal capacity to take decisions and to defend himself in these proceedings? The second question concerns some factual discrepancy, which I found in the assessment of the psychiatrists at the first stage during the criminal conviction proceedings and in the revocation proceedings. The psychiatrists in the revocation proceedings concluded that the applicant was suffering from paranoid schizophrenia during the period of commission of the crime. This is in contrast with the report of the medical legal counsel at paragraphs nine and 10 of the chamber judgment, which had been submitted to the court for the purposes of the criminal proceedings leading up to the conviction. The first report had concluded that the applicant did not suffer from a mental disorder at the time of the commission of the crime, that he was mildly mentally retarded, and that his complaints of auditory hallucinations could be regarded as simulation. So my question is this, would it have been possible under Danish law to order the applicant's expulsion had the correct diagnosis of diminished mental capacity been submitted at the stage of the proceedings leading to his conviction? Thank you.
text.244: My thanks to the parties regarding the clarification on the issue of permanent and temporary bans and this new information regarding a 2019 law. Could I ask the representative of the government to develop a little bit on this question of the law permitting differentiation regarding re-entry bans with reference to what criteria or in what circumstances does it permit differentiation? Thank you.
text.245: I just would like to follow up when it was decided to expel Savran outside of Denmark. Would it be possible if he would not be expelled at that time just to leave him and to free him from the institution in Denmark? So whether he was at that stage where he could be released actually from the institution.
text.246: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to add on the question posed by Judge O'Leary and to inquire from the government agent more clarification on whether the change in the laws of 2018 which have been elaborated on by both sides would allow nowadays the applicant to apply nowadays for reconsideration of the length of the ban. Thank you.
text.247: Merci, M. le Président. Je voudrais seulement poser une question aux deux parties concernant leur opinion. Si le récréant a coopéré ou dans quelle mesure il a coopéré dans la réalisation du parcours proposé par les autorités de mois d'août 2017 jusqu'à ce jour, en particulier en ce qui concerne le suivi psychiatrique? Merci.
text.248: Merci. J'aurais trois questions aux requérants, s'il vous plaît. La première question, c'est... Je serais intéressée. Quelle était la souffrance concrète du requérant à cause du fait de ne pas avoir de traitement psychiatrique? Est-ce qu'il y avait des angoisses ou des vraies crises qu'un psychiatre aurait pu soigner? Ou bien était le problème plutôt qu'il n'y avait pas d'espoir ou de préparation pour être libéré? Et la deuxième question, c'est alors pendant ses 14 ans, est-ce qu'on lui a offert un traitement, même en français, qu'il n'a pas accepté? Ou est-ce qu'on n'a jamais essayé à travailler avec lui dans cette langue? Et est-ce que les coûts des tenues étaient alors traités différemment? Et la troisième question, c'est... Est-ce qu'à votre avis, la situation serait différente si M. Roumane ne parlait pas l'allemand, une langue officielle de la Belgique, mais disons l'espagnol? Est-ce qu'il n'y avait pas les mêmes problèmes de traitement et de socialisation? Et est-ce qu'on ne devrait pas accorder les mêmes droits à quelqu'un qui parle une langue non officielle qu'à quelqu'un qui parle une langue officielle? Merci.
text.249: Merci beaucoup, Monsieur le Président. Mes questions sont des questions de suivi à mes collègues, qui sont mises en 2 parties. D'abord, le gouvernement nous dit que M. Romain n'avait pas besoin d'un suivi pharmacologique, mais on a un rapport d'expertise psychiatrique fait par le Dr. R en 2005 qui nous précise que le suivi psychothérapeutique doit suivre le traitement basé par des médicaments psychotropes. Donc, on a ici, quelle est la vérité sur le plan de traitement de M. Romain. Et une deuxième question est toujours liée à ce plan de traitement qui était proposé dès le début par les psychiatres, qui proposait une rééducation cognitive de M. Romain. Et ma question est la suivante. Est-ce qu'une fois qu'on a eu la possibilité d'avoir une interprétation en allemand, et surtout après 2017, est-ce qu'on a exposé à M. Romain ce plan ou est-ce que la psychologue qui est venue, comme le requérant le soutient, elle a mis seulement des questions sans lui exposer le plan qui pourrait aboutir dans certaines conditions à son élibération? Merci beaucoup.
text.250: Merci, M. le Président. Je voudrais poser une question au gouvernement. Vous avez parlé, madame, du lien entre le motif de la détention et la maladie du requérant. Bien évidemment, ce lien est évident. Moi, je me demande si l'on peut parler du lien entre la régularité de la détention et du but de la détention. Est-ce que vous pensez que le but de la détention est seulement un but social préventif ou aussi un but médical thérapeutique? Merci.
text.251: Thank you very much. I would have one question to the applicants and two questions to the government. The question to the applicants, if I see correctly the timeline, on 19th of July 1997 there was an application for a bankruptcy procedure but it failed because the money was not paid. Two years later on 1st July 1999 the Fokker came into force and after that on 22nd of November 2000 there was a confirmation in court that the claim, that there was a final judgment concerning the claim by the railway company and only one year later there was a strike off. So at the moment when the judgment of the court concerning this claim from the railway company was handed down, what was the expectation of the applicant, what would happen to this final judgment? Because I understand the hope or the expectation that there would be ex-offizio bankruptcy procedures was not possible anymore because Fokker had entered into force at that time. So what was the expectation, what would happen with this final judgment? And now concerning the government, my first question is, you have argued that it was impossible to serve the decision about the striking off to the individual company members. But if it's impossible, the whole system is built on the idea that later on enforcement procedures would be directed against the individual members of the company. So if it's impossible to serve already the striking off, how do you then expect it to function within the enforcement procedure? And my second question to the government is, I understand that you treat in the same way minority shareholders and majority shareholders. So if somebody has 11% as the applicant or has 100%, there would always be this personal liability. So do I understand it correctly that if a company has just one member who has 100%, a creditor would get one debtor? And if the company has, let's say, 10 minority members, then the creditor would immediately get 10 debtors. So is that the system? Have I understood it correctly? Thank you.
text.252: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I want to begin with a question to the applicant, and it's prompted by the pleadings by the government here today, where the agent for the government refers to the pleading made at paragraph 100 of your observations, where the applicant says he does not contend that a shareholder's personal liability for the outstanding debts of the company is per se incompatible with the convention. Now, that prompts the question on how would the applicant invite the court to draw the line? What are the parameters for convention compliant application of FOCA and non-convention compliant application of the FOCA? And in particular, is it the applicant's view that member states are precluded for imposing personal liability on shareholders in limited liability companies outside the context of abusive conduct? Could you clarify where you think the line under the convention should be drawn? My second question, if I could just get a clarification, and it goes somewhat to the question just posed by Vice President Nußberger, that is the one year vacatio legis on the facts of this case. Now, it seems undisputed that the applicant could have within that period proceeded with triggering bankruptcy proceedings or the winding up. Could you explain your view on the argument presented by the government on that issue? One question to the government, which is a related one. The government says that paragraph 76 of your observations, and I think here is a crucial point in light of your submissions. The point here is that only persons who had rights to manage or participate in the management of the company at the time when the company was struck off without liquidation could be held liable. What do you mean by rights to manage or participate in the management of the company? Are you limiting this view to those that actually hold board member status or director status like the applicant? Because the issue of who has the rights to manage can be dealt with in different ways. Could you clarify what you mean by this term? And are you including there minority shareholders who indeed have rights, for example, to call a general meeting? But as the constitutional court in your own country states in its judgment of 9 October 2002 at paragraph 43, minority shareholders do not have an obligation to influence or have a view on day-to-day regular operations in limited liability companies. Could you clarify what you mean by rights to manage or participate in the management of a company? Thank you very much.
text.253: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai une seule question factuelle qui se pose depuis la plaidoirie de la partie requérante, de son premier intervenant, mais la question s'adresse également au gouvernement. Si j'ai bien compris, l'avocat du requérant a dit que la responsabilité personnelle des associés a été introduite par la loi de 1999 appelée FOCA. Selon mes notes personnelles, mais là, je peux me tromper, et vous pouvez alors me corriger, moi, j'avais noté qu'en 1993, la loi sur les sociétés... Il y a une nouvelle loi sur les sociétés avec une possibilité pour les associés disposant de plus de 10 % des parts de demander la dissolution et la mise en faillite en cas d'insolvabilité avec, en cas d'omission, responsabilité personnelle. Donc est-ce que cette responsabilité personnelle a été introduite en 1999 ou est-ce qu'elle existait déjà dans la loi de 1993? Merci beaucoup. Merci.
text.254: Thank you very much. I have two questions to the applicant and to the applicant's representatives. The first regards the factual background of the personal involvement of the applicant in the outcome of this procedure. First, why did the applicant not himself lodge an action before the competent court to be dissolved under the Companies Act of 1993? Secondly, why did the applicant not withdraw from the company, as provided again by the Companies Act of 1993? Third, why did not he profit from the adversarial procedure by appealing the court procedure? And finally, why did he not lodge a constitutional complaint against the strike of decision immediately after the decision, but only a year later? My second question to the representatives or applicant regards this reference to the two erasure, so to say two erasure procedures in the history of Slovenia. First, the erasure of the former Yugoslav citizenship, and the second, the erasure of the companies. And here, the representative or applicant referred to the Kuric versus Slovenia case. How can you explain to us the difference between the decisions of the Constitutional Court regarding the erasure of citizens and the erasure of the companies? Because basically, at the same time, the same composition of the Constitutional Court found unconstitutional the citizenship law, and also the government acknowledged its illegality. Most at the same time, the Constitutional Court upheld the FOCA law. And so I would like to have an explanation for that. My question is to the government. First, because here we have heard that the 2.5% of the population was affected by the FOCA law. Are there perhaps any statistical data on that? How many persons have been held liable? How many persons have been held liable under this veil of the lifting of the corporate fur for debts of struck-off companies when the FOCA law was in force regarding this issue? My second question to the government would return to an issue that was raised during the deliberation by the applicant's representative, and this is the retroactive application of the FOCA law. If you could elaborate on that question, I would be very curious whether it was retroactive or not. Thank you very much.
text.255: Thank you very much. I would like to ask two questions, one primarily to the applicant. The applicant has argued extensively about the fact that he was not informed of the hearing relating to the strike of proceedings, nor about the decision that had been taken by the court. My question is, what would have been the possibility for the applicant to argue before the court or on appeal? And that has something to do with the text of Article 25 of the FOCA. Is there any possibility for the court, or was there any possibility for the court to come to an other decision, taking into account that for 12 consecutive months, there had not been any payments by the company? That's the first question. The second one relates somewhat to what the government said at the very end of its argument. We know what the situation is of the applicant, but there were also other shareholders who have also been held personally liable in the proceedings against the railway company. Was it possible, is it possible for the applicant to turn to the fellow shareholders or to their heirs and obtain some part from them, the part of what he had to pay to the railway company? And if so, how would then the individual responsibility of each of the shareholders be determined in the proceedings between them? Thank you.
text.256: Thank you, Mr. President. I would have two questions for both parties and one question just for the government. And the first question concerns the so-called irregularities or respect or disrespect of the principle of good corporate governance. And this is a disputed issue between the parties since the applicant says in his observations of 15 December that the applicant did avoid committing any irregularity under the company law and that he also behaved with the diligence required to a private individual who is a minority shareholder of a limited liability company. In paragraph 197 of the observations, the applicant even says that not even the government claimed that the applicant actually committed any irregularity in the management of the company. But on the other side, the government in its observations of 15 December denies that by saying that it has drawn attention to how the applicant should have and could have acted. Separately from the element of active membership, which is, in my opinion, a relevant element for the assessment of proportionality, eventual irregularities or serious professional misconduct are relevant, too, for the assessment of proportionality of interference in the light of the Institute of Lifting the Corporate Whale. For example, the chamber's judgment in this respect in paragraphs 125 and 126 mentions rather very broad elements, such as inadequate capitalization, failure to observe the law and good business practices, prolonged state of insolvency, inactivity of the part of the company's management, and in much more concrete terms, the chamber's judgment mentioned the failure to institute bankruptcy proceedings. So my question is, what were the concrete specific, although the most important, irregularities or serious professional misconduct caused by the management of the company before the strike-off proceedings were initiated? And my second question, which is related to the first one, is, what could the applicant do in order to avoid liability for the debt of the company? Apart from bankruptcy, missed opportunity for the bankruptcy proceedings, is it correct to say that the applicant could simply have withdrawn from the company? And by doing so, he would have avoided liability, as this is claimed by the government in its observations from 15 December under paragraph 76. In this respect, in the paragraph 76 on page 30 of the government's observation, the government relies on a decision of Ljubljana High Court mentioned in the footnote 86. But this decision relates to a legal situation under the law which was enforced in 2009, while the applicant's company was strike-off in 2001. So my second question is, what could the applicant do to avoid being liable for a company's debt? And this is relevant, in my opinion, from the standpoint of the standard of excessive burden, as this being part of the proportionality test. And finally, I have a very short question only for the government. Was there any particular reason that legislator did not introduced the model of somehow limited liability of the members of the company? Because it seems that the law introduced unlimited liability of the members of the company.
text.257: Thank you, Mr. President. I have several questions for the government. My first question is why the applicant was put in custody in December 2003, for the first time when she was put in custody, and why she was kept for several days in custody for identity verification. Is that a regular procedure when you perform identity verification to keep someone in custody for several days? Second question, what happened to the remaining 15 videotapes, and why they never heard at the trial? And third question, how it's possible, how come that the police failed to test the applicant's hand for residue? As far as I know, that is a standard procedure to prove connection between subject and object. And why witnesses of her search in a police station were never heard at the trial before the court? Thank you.
text.258: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question for the applicant. In paragraph 48 of applicant's observations to the grand chamber, it stated the following. I quote, the applicant's motion to examine witness A. as the trial was not dismissed by the trial court. Please explain the grounds for this statement. Thank you.
text.259: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question for both sides. What were the procedural mechanisms available to the defense to ensure presence of witness A. at trial and his examination? And did the defense make use of all these mechanisms?
text.260: Thank you, Mr. President. My question is addressed to the government, but of course the applicant may also comment on it. I would like to know why the fingerprints on the packages, alleged packages of explosives were not taken. It seems that these packages and the alleged explosives were destroyed, no sample was taken. So is it a practice that the material evidence is destroyed by police before the trial takes place? Why is it that witnesses B. and K. were not included in the list of witnesses to be summoned to the trial? They were not even included in the list of witnesses to be summoned to the trial hearing. Is this the practice that these so-called attesting witnesses are not even called to the court? And the final point is the one that was raised by the applicant with regard to the interpretation in the light of the Russian case law, the Russian Supreme Court's case law of Article 281. If I understood correctly, I'm not sure that I understood correctly what was proposed to us by the applicant, but if I understood correctly, he was arguing or she was arguing, the applicant, that Article 281 was not even applicable because the witnesses were not even summoned. So for the purposes of this article, they could not and should not even be considered as absent because they were not even summoned. Is this so? Is this in line with the Russian Supreme Court's case law? Because then we are talking about a totally different legal scenario. So these are my questions. Thank you very much.
text.261: Thank you very much. I have one question to the applicant. Apart from the fact that Mr. A, according to your submissions, organized video surveillance of the applicant, what other his actions, if any, could qualify his role as agent provocateur? Thank you.
text.262: Thank you very much. This is a question to the applicant. The government in its written observations to the Grand Chamber in paragraphs 41 and 44, and again in paragraph 104, suggested that the record shows that the acceptance by the applicant's lawyers and by the applicant herself for the record of the statement of witness A. to be read amounts to a waiver. Are there any further submissions you want to make in response of that? And also address the point why the Grand Chamber should not take as a point of admissibility and therefore declare this case inadmissible? Thank you.
text.263: Thank you. I have just one factual, well, legal question to ask either party or both parties. As the law stood in 2008-2009, was there a time limit within which the prosecutor's decision, like the decision of 7 August, could be overruled by a higher public prosecutor? Was there a time limit within which this could be done, or was it open-ended? There may be the information in the submissions, but if there is, I have missed it out completely. So that is why I put this question for clarification. Thank you.
text.264: Merci beaucoup, Monsieur le Président. J'ai une question à poser au requérant. Parmi les arguments, il a invoqué l'affaire Kossowski de la Cour de justice de l'Union européenne. Ma question est la suivante. Est-ce que le but et la nature du principe néo-byzantinisme dans les deux cours est similaire ou différente? Et dans quel respect? Merci beaucoup.
text.265: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai une question en partie. L'ouverture des poursuites prévues par les articles 270 et 273 du Code de procédure pénale, tel qu'en vigueur à l'époque des faits, constitue-t-elle un recours dont il faut tenir compte pour décider si une décision est définitive? Merci.
text.266: Merci beaucoup, Monsieur le Président. Je voudrais poser une question à le gouvernement. Peut-être que je n'ai pas bien compris, mais dans vos plaidoiries, et aussi dans vos observations en écrit, vous parlez toujours d'une décision qui, à votre avis, n'était pas finale. Ma question est donc, est-ce que la Cour sera justifiée de procéder sur la base d'une affirmation du gouvernement que la décision est une condamnation? Vous êtes d'accord avec le récréant que la décision est bel et bien une condamnation, mais votre désaccord est limité à la question de savoir si ce condamnation était finale. Merci beaucoup.
text.267: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have a question, I think, primarily for the government, but the applicants can also, of course, reply to it. Which are the categories of persons of which the passports can be taken, and what are the circumstances in which passports are returned to them? Thank you.
text.268: Thank you. My question follows Judge Lehman's question, whether the passport was claimed back by the applicants and whether the authorities refused to do that. I also would like to clarify that. I would thank both parties for their very valuable information was given to us regarding the domestic law, especially. My question is about the domestic law. The applicants' representative mentioned about the 24 hours rule when the person, when he illegally entered the territory of the Russian Federation. He should apply for this. But isn't you apply this rule or refuse to apply this rule for the present case in a mechanical way, I would say, or formalistically. I would ask you what would be the consequences that if the applicants would not comply with this rule, would not apply within 24 hours. Whether we can use this provision of the domestic law in this situation, because they were in the urgent situation, for example, as a criterion which could be used. The second question is about the difference. Would you provide the example that the Syrian family was granted asylum and provided the opportunity to have access to social services and so on, which was provided by the Russian authorities in 2015. But can you accept that there is a difference between the situations of the applicants in this case and those Syrian family? And my question is about whether the applicants arrived in the Russian border with their families or not. And the last question is about the application in the third countries. And my question is whether there is a requirement under the domestic asylum procedure, for example, when the person apply for asylum, should the authorities question about his previous experience and application in third countries, whether the applicant should provide any documents. And if not, if the documents are not provided, whether this failure to inform the country authorities about the third country's application, it leads to the delay in examination of the application of the asylum seeker in that case, in this case, in the Russian Federation. So I mean, the question is whether there is, there are any circumstances that could prove that the delay was also provoked by the applicants themselves. Thank you.
text.269: Thank you, Mr. President. I also have some questions to the government, but the applicants' representative is most welcome to also address them if they so wish. The first question is also a follow-up to the question by Judge Lemmens and Dedov concerning the passports. According to the applicants, the Russian authorities seized their passports. In their observations, the government have argued to the contrary. Therefore, my question is, were the applicants' passports seized at any time by the authorities? And if so, what was the legal basis for doing so? And what was the purpose of the measure? More specifically, was it a precautious measure to ensure the necessary traveling documents at the moment the applicants would have to leave Russian territory? Furthermore, did the seizure in practice prevent the applicants from leaving the country in case they should so have wished to do? My second question to the government concerns the distinction between genuine asylum seekers and ordinary migrants, which is one of the core arguments of the government. And the government argues that the applicants were accepted for assessment under marriage and were dismissed after rather lengthy proceedings. Therefore, in view of the government, can the state's obligation under Article 3 and under Article 5 be depending upon the outcome of the asylum proceedings, more specifically as regards material conditions for the stay in the airport zone? The government is arguing that it had no positive obligations under Article 3 to meet the applicants' basic needs during this period as they were not genuine asylum seekers. However, whether they were entitled to international protection or not was exactly what Russian authorities had undertaken to assess. So once again, my question is, can the state's obligations towards asylum seekers depend upon the outcome of the asylum procedure? My last question also to the government concerns the open door argument. Under Article 5, the government is emphasizing the fact that the applicants were free to leave Russia at any time and that nothing prevented them from leaving Russian territory earlier. In other words, the government is invoking an open door argument. However, my question is, how realistic is this suggestion in view of the fact that the applicants claimed that they risked ill treatment in a country of origin, a claim which the Russian authorities accepted to examine under marriage, and apparently no other country was willing to accept them? Furthermore, no steps to facilitate such an acceptance would appear to have been undertaken by Russian authorities. Thank you.
text.270: I would have two questions. First one to the government. Which concrete measures the authorities could have taken if the risk of serious disturbance of public order and the danger to the safety of individuals had persisted for a longer period than only some hours? Let's say, for example, during a sports event or a political demonstration lasting two days. Is there any possibility under Danish law for persons causing such a risk or danger who are not willing to keep the peace to be detained for one or two days if they have not yet committed any criminal offense? And a second question to both parties. According to the government, all applicants before the events of 10th October 2009 had been arrested several times in connection with other football unrest. How often have they actually been arrested and under which circumstances?
text.271: Thank you very much, Mr. President. The government in this case argues that either Article 5, Paragraph 1b or c or both are applicable. The applicant seems to argue in the first place that none is applicable, leaving aside that issue of applicability or not, and assuming for a moment, as the government argues, that either Paragraph 1b or c is applicable, and so that preventive detention in the circumstances of this case of a crowd control is possible. I would like to ask the parties to come back to an issue that they both have discussed. And I would like specifically to ask the parties what they would think of two issues. What are the risks against arbitrary action in this respect? And the guarantees against, I'm sorry, what are the guarantees against arbitrarily singling out specific individuals? And secondly, I know that both parties have discussed this, but I would like to hear it again. What about the guarantees of judicial control in a situation of a preventive detention? Should it be something automatic? Should it be something that is possible within a very short time? What is the time limit for the court to decide? And how to organize all that in a practical way? Thank you.
text.272: I would like to ask the government to explain how the authorities determined the time when the applicants should be released. The government said that they were released when the risk was minimized. I see from the facts that the last disturbance took place at 10.51 and especially at 11.21 p.m. and the first applicant was released at exactly after this, at 11.27. I mean that the concrete circumstances should be taken into account by the authorities, not the general assumption. So my question is what was the concrete circumstances which allowed the authorities to conclude that the risk, the imminent risk exists and the concrete persons, namely the applicants in the present case, would like to participate in the disturbance and the disorder. Thank you.
text.273: Thank you, President. I just wanted to follow up on Judge Ranzoni's question. We have heard that the applicants had been arrested before in other circumstances. Was this registered? text.274: Thank you very much. I would like to pose three questions or questions on three different aspects of the case. The first one relates to interception. Now, I understand that in order for this interception to, bulk interception to operate, there must be in place a permanent technical facility or gateway which is installed in the fiber optic cable system, which permits the intelligence services to access transmission flows in a direct manner. And of course, we understand that this interception facility may be activated on the basis of a warrant. What I would like to ask is who controls the actual, let's say, activation or deactivation of the connection to the interception facility? That is to say, who activates and deactivates the actual flow of communications toward interception? Are the intelligence services themselves directly in charge of, let's say, turning the interception facility on and off? Or is there some other intervening body at this stage? The second question regarding the interceptions phase that I would like to pose concerns cloud services. So is it correct to assume that documents, photos, et cetera, which are saved in a cloud service that is based outside the UK would be regarded as an external communication for the purposes of the RIPA regime, RIPA 8.4 regime? My second line of questions is about the interception and my questions concern the warrant and the certificate that are required for the 8.4, the RIPA 8.4 regime. Now, I note that the applicants in their joint submissions, paragraphs 120 to 122, argue that, in fact, there is a rolling program of indefinite authorization in place. And this argument is based on two things. The first point is that the bulk interception warrant can be renewed without any limits. It has a limited duration, but it can be renewed without any definite limits. And the second point they make is that the ISC has reported that only a single certificate has ever been issued, a single certificate expressed in very general terms. In other words, what the applicants, as I understand, contend is that there is, in fact, sort of a continuous recycling of a standard kind of warrant and a standard kind of certificate. Now, I would like to know if the government is able to confirm or refute this or to offer any other comments. And the third issue I would like to address are the safeguards that are applicable after the interception. Now, we understand that the data which will be included in the index of documents that will be available, potentially available for examination by a human analyst, that data is identified through the application of simple selectors and more complex search terms. We also note, however, that in a report from 2015, the Intelligence and Security Committee of the Parliament noted that from the evidence we have taken, it appears that neither ministers nor the commissioners have any significant visibility on the selection and the application of the simple selectors or the search terms that are deployed. And I also understand that it is the case that the selection for human examination of the content of communications is carried out by the analysts themselves, who will be in charge of conducting the examination. That is to say that the analysts themselves are also in charge of determining the criteria for selection. Now, I would like to raise two questions in this context. Would it be possible to explain to us which are the safeguards that are in place in relation to the selection and the application of the selectors and the search terms that are applied to the data once it has been intercepted? And also, secondly, what are the safeguards in place to ensure that data which is not selected for examination and is due to be discarded, that such data might be subject to analysis with a view to identifying potential communication patterns, which could be of intelligence value? So which are safeguards applying to the data which is retained but not selected for human examination? In this context, I also note that or assume that as regards the filtering criteria and the selectors, there is a possibility for the commissioner and possibly the other supervisory organs to conduct an exposed review or supervision. But is there any body that is empowered to issue any binding instructions or orders regarding the selectors or filtering mechanisms that are used or may not be used? So is there any sort of more robust regime for controlling the kind of selectors that are, in fact, applied, given that in the first place, it is a matter for the analysts to determine the selectors? So these would be my questions. Thank you very much.
text.275: Thank you, Mr. President. I have one question, which is addressed to the government. When considering the general safeguards in relation to the destruction of intercepted material, as soon as it is no longer, I am quoting, necessary for any of the authorized purposes provided by the section 15.3 of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act, and section 15.4 provides the relevant definition of the term necessary for the authorized purpose. This includes the rather broad reference to retention being necessary if, and again I quote, it is likely to become necessary. What safeguards, if any, are there to limit and or supervise the application of this criteria? Thank you.
text.276: Thank you, Mr. President. I have three questions. The first is turning to the safeguards relating to related communications data intercepted under a Section 8-4 warrant, which Mr. Eadie explained again this morning. And of course, the submission is, as I understand it, that they don't apply, at least in part, because if they were to apply, it would be more difficult or impossible to make the Section 16 safeguards work for content data, in that it would make it more difficult or impossible to determine whether material was, in fact, referable to an individual known to be in the British Isles. If one, however, looks at the definition of communications data set out in Chapter 2 of the 2015 Acquisition and Disclosure of Communications Data Code of Practice, can the government explain to us why any other than the most basic traffic data would be required in order to ensure that the Section 16 safeguards can be applied effectively? And secondly, what safeguards are there to ensure that any communications data are not necessary for this purpose? And I'm thinking particularly of service use information or subscriber information, insofar as that's captured, is, in fact, discarded and or is only otherwise used in a manner compatible with the requirements of the Convention. The second question relates really to a factual clarification, I hope, of the reading of the Interception Code of Practice, the 2016 version. Looking at the protection of journalistic sources under Article 10, could you confirm whether paragraphs 4.28 to 4.31 of that code are said also to apply to confidential journalistic material, despite the clear distinction drawn in paragraph 4.26 between confidential journalistic material on the one hand and confidential personal information on the other, and the apparent limitation of those paragraphs to, I quote, confidential personal information, end quote, or quote, confidential information, close quote? And finally, the applicants made no oral submissions this morning in relation to the complaint under chapter 2, in relation to chapter 2, section 22 of RIPA. Could I just ask for confirmation whether that continues to be pursued? Thank you very much.
text.277: I have a question for the government. Staying briefly with Chapter 12 of the Interception Code, is it the government's case that paragraph 12.5 of the 2016 Code addresses the concern expressed by the IPT in paragraph 53 of its December 2014 judgments, and I quote from the judgment, there ought to be introduced a procedure whereby any such request, a request in absence of a RIPA warrant, if made when referred to the Secretary of State, must address the issue of Section 16.3? Thank you.
text.278: I would like to ask a question related to acquisition of communications data that is regulated in Chapter 2 of RIPA, which sets out the framework under which public authorities may acquire communications data from CSPS. And I'm asking that question to the government. The three questions related to that issue that were not sufficiently dealt with in submissions and are related to how the regime that is envisaged in Chapter 2 is actually satisfying the requirements of being in accordance with the law and or necessity. In particular, when we consider the large number of relevant public authorities and or purposes, the lack of independence of the designated person, and the apparent absence of any guidance related to the examination disclosure other than to the third states, acquisition and or destruction of communications data. This is the question related to Chapter 2, as I have said. Also in terms of the admissibility, the government is proposing that we should deviate from the conclusions that we have taken, that the Court has taken in the Kennedy judgment, suggesting that IPT proceedings now represent sufficient remedy. Kennedy judgment was based on burden versus UK. Is the government suggesting that IPT is representing better guarantees than the regular courts in the UK? Or is the government suggesting that in general we should not adhere to burden versus UK anymore? And could government substantiate in more details why we should do that? How many times IPT made suggestions to the Parliament and the Parliament followed that? And could you explain, is this what you are suggesting in accordance with the sovereignty of the Parliament and is following that doctrine? So we have heard the question related to the warrant and for how long the warrant and whether the warrant could be actually extended indefinitely. The same question goes for the retention of data. There are limits for the retention of data, but it seems that the retention could be prolonged indefinitely. So how that could be justified. And then, I don't know whether you can say that, but actually all the connections that are going on under the surveillance or we know that some of the connections are not under the surveillance through which internet is going. And then, if the warrant is issued for national security purposes, could the data later on be reviewed for other purposes that are identified in law? And is the purpose of economic well-being in accordance with the Convention standards? Thank you.
text.279: Thank you, Mr. President. I have four questions. The first one is addressed to both parties and concerns the repartition of the burden of proof and the standard of proof. I would like to hear the view of both parties on the issue of the burden of proof in this case and of the standard of proof applicable to this case. My second question is also addressed to both parties and concerns the judgments of the Czech Constitutional Court, which recognize the right to conscientious objection in respect of vaccination. Are these judgments self-executing, or do they require implementing legislation? I would like to hear the view of both parties on this issue, whether this right can be asserted without implementing legislation, or does it require legislation which would enable to assert this right to conscientious objection. Now, the third question is also addressed to both parties. The policies in respect of vaccination vary from one state to another. There are states which introduce mandatory vaccinations. There are states which base their policies upon positive incitements and recommendations. Are there any statistical data which would enable us to evaluate the efficiency of both approaches and the spread of the different diseases in the context of mandatory vaccinations and the context of the opposite policy based upon incitements and recommendations? And finally, the fourth question, which is addressed mainly to the government, maybe the applicants would also like to comment on this issue. What are the precise targets concerning the immunization level among the population in percentage to eradicate the nine diseases which are on the list of diseases in respect of which there is an obligation to vaccinate? Are there precise numbers concerning the level of herd immunity which is necessary to be reached in order to eradicate the disease? And are there differences among the nine diseases which are concerned by this obligation to vaccinate? Thank you.
text.280: Thank you, Mr. President. I have one question for the government, one question for the applicants, and one question for both. The first question, in its judgment, the Constitutional Court of Czech Republic, in its judgment of 3rd February 2011, decided that the protection of individual autonomy requires that, exceptionally, the persons concerned not be forced to undergo compulsory vaccination. My question is follow. Have there been any concrete cases in which children were admitted to preschool facilities without having vaccinated according to existing law? And the second question, it relates to Article 9 of the convention. Had the children been vaccinated, what repercussions would this have had on their, on children's and their parents' beliefs under the Article 9 of the convention? And third question, you all know that vaccination could provoke some health complications. Who would be responsible for the costs of the treatment necessary in relation to those complications? Thank you.
text.281: Thank you, Mr. President. So I have two questions. One already my colleague, Judge Wojtyczek, asked. And I think, I hope that my questions for government and particularly for Mr. Prymula, maybe he as a medical expert will be able to spread the light on this. First, of course, I would like, it will be interesting for me to know if there is some research comparing the situation in both situation, the countries where it is a mandatory duty in vaccination and in the countries where it is not mandatory. Whether we have a research-based statistical data so that the mandatory duty in mandatory duty country, the situation is better. And what is the result of that? And the second question, if how the children who are not vaccinated can infect the ones who are already vaccinated and they have immunity? Because when we are speaking about the interest of children who have to be vaccinated and the interest of others. So I would like to know you as a medical expert, can you explain us? If they are vaccinated and already they have immunity, how the other ones who are not vaccinated can be dangerous for them? Thank you.
text.282: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to address both parties, the government and the applicant, concerning two issues. The one is, the first one is about the best interest of the child, and the second one is about the question of necessity that you have already dealt with. Now, with regard to the best interest of the child, I was wondering who decides on what is the best interest of the child. The question means, to what extent do parents' rights play a role over here? On the other hand, what happens if the parents' attitudes divert from scientific evidence, including recommendations given by the World Health Organization? Now, let me turn to the question of necessity, which is also relevant to both parties. I was wondering, if I go through all of the different vaccinations, they have different mechanisms, and I'm sure that the expert will be able to elaborate on that. I would like to ask the question, why is vaccination of young children against hepatitis B necessary or not? After all, it seems to be transmitted via blood contact, a risk that does not seem to be that high in preschool. So I would like to appreciate your comments on that, especially since the expert, Mr. Primolov,has referred to measles and pertussis. However, we have seen that we have nine vaccinations over here, so I would be interested in hearing what are the reasons for the mandatory vaccination of tetanus and diphtheria. To what extent does it protect the health of others? You have referred extensively to herd immunity, so you may want to elaborate a little bit on to what extent the single vaccinations contribute to herd immunity. Now, with respect to the applicant, you have made the argument that the mandatory regime does not provide for any kind of exceptions. I would like to hear... You were questioning the necessity with regard to all vaccinations. So let's turn to poliomyelitis, for example, or measles. To what extent would allowing exception be contrary to the aim of providing protection against these kinds of diseases? Thank you very much.
text.283: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have two questions for the government, but of course the applicants are very welcome to comment on this if they so wish. My first question refers to the list of compulsory vaccinations, namely how is this list actually drawn up? In particular, I'm interested in hearing what are the criteria to include or not to include a specific vaccination on the list. In this particular respect, my question is a little bit similar or continues the question of my colleague, Judge Seibert-Fohr. In this particular respect, I'm also interested in the procedure of drawing up such a list. In particular, what is the role of experts? How is their independence from conflict of interest guaranteed? And how are any critical views taken into account when drawing up such a list? My second question pertains to the issue of compensation of those children who suffer certain negative consequences from compulsory vaccinations. It is my understanding that up to a certain point, the Czech law, the Czech legislation provided for such compensation. Later on, this was no longer the case. However, if I understand correctly, there have been some very recent developments which, according to the applicants, set very high threshold for such compensation. I would like to hear from the government, but of course the applicants are also welcome to comment, what are or what were the reasons to first abolish such compensation in case of such consequences, to reintroduce it again, and what are the reasons to put a specific threshold in this particular respect? Thank you so much.
text.284: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. J'ai 3 questions. La 1re dirigée à l'avocat qui représente M. Pavlichka, après, donc, une question dirigée au gouvernement et, finalement, donc, une question qui intéresse les 2 parties. Ceci n'obstant, rien n'empêche, donc, qu'il y ait des répliques, donc, à la question posée et aux requérants et au gouvernement. Donc, venons-en, donc, à la 1re question, qui est celle dirigée, donc, aux requérants. Pour autant que je sache, et ça intéresse, une fois de plus, M. Pavlichka, il s'oppose, donc, à faire vacciner ses enfants contre 3 vaccins, la poliomyélite, l'hépatite B et le tétanos. Or, il apparaît que M. Pavlichka a, dans le passé, fait vacciner ses enfants. Est-ce qu'on connaît le pourcentage d'effets secondaires graves, j'insiste, graves, dans le cadre de la vaccination obligatoire? Et enfin, donc, une question dont je veux agréer aux 2 parties. Est-ce que, à votre avis, la vaccination constitue une intervention médicale au sens de la Convention d'Oviedo? Je vous remercie.
text.285: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have a question primarily for the government, but of course the applicant can, or the applicants can also reply. It refers to what the Constitutional Court held in its judgment of 2015, where it stated that vaccination represents an act of social solidarity, and each individual must undergo vaccinations in order to protect the health of society as a whole. And you ended your pleading by referring to this statement of the Constitutional Court and by adding that there is a shared responsibility, that is, including an individual responsibility. I have two questions. The first one is the following. The Convention protects individual rights. That's the system of the Convention. Now how does social solidarity or a shared responsibility relate to those rights in the Convention system? And the second related question is how far does such an individual responsibility or an individual solidarity go? What are limitations, if any, to such a responsibility of citizens in society? And you could apply that to what is at stake here. Can individuals be expected or even be required to contribute to a system of general prevention of diseases? Thank you.
text.286: Merci beaucoup, M. le président. C'est une question que je veux... Une question que je voudrais reposer à l'expert de la République tchèque. A ma question de savoir quel était, plus ou moins, le pourcentage d'accidents graves alliçant donc avec la vaccination obligatoire... Pouvez-vous donc confirmer ce chiffre-là? Pouvez-vous également dire qu'est-ce que vous entendez par accidents graves? Et également, c'était ma question principale, le pourcentage, donc 226 cas par an, mais par rapport à quel nombre approximatif de personnes vaccinées. Le pourcentage, et qu'est-ce que vous entendez exactement par accidents graves? Je vous remercie.
text.287: Merci, M. le Président. Je voudrais poser une question aux requérants. Je voudrais poser une question aux requérants et plus particulièrement à M. Riza. M. Riza, vous avez présenté l'affaire comme un cas banal, quotidien, de coopération entre agents de police. You said, I'm quoting you in English, a trivial case of cooperation between police officers. Thats what you said. Est-ce que le transfert... Ma question, maintenant. Est-ce que le transfert... Pas de problème. Je disais, M. Riza, que vous avez présenté l'affaire comme un cas banal, comme un cas quotidien de coopération entre agents de police. Merci M. le president.
text.288: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have a question essentially for the Turkish government, but of course both the Cypriot government and the representative of the applicants are welcome to comment as well. Both in their observations before the Grand Chamber and also today during the hearing, the Turkish government asserted that there was no valid request for extradition of the suspects.
