If the course of events in respect of that extradition request renders that request invalid in the eyes of the Turkish government, I would like to ask what would be a proper diplomatic channel under the circumstances. Thank you very much.
text.289: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have one more question of clarification, which is prompted by an argument intimated by Mrs. Montgomery just now. And it is mainly to Mrs. Montgomery and also to the government of Turkey, Mr. Talmon, but I would invite Mr. Riza also to comment. In your pleadings, Mrs. Montgomery, you referred to the issue of Rasyon-i-Loki of Turkey and you mentioned that in your view, the jurisdictional link was clear, and I quote, based on the Markovitsch principles. Might I ask you to clarify, because that element I don't see from your written observations, I assume you're referring to the Grand Chamber judgment in Markovitsch and others versus Italy of 2006. Could you explain in your view how that case comes in to the equation of a possible recognition of jurisdiction by Turkey? I would also invite Mr. Talmon,, because Markovitsch and others is only referenced in footnote 45 of your written observations. If I'm not incorrect, there is no further reference. Could you explain what bearing that case, and in particular, paragraphs 53 and 54 of the Grand Chamber judgment on the jurisdictional link, of course, mutatis mutandis, would have in this case, considering the fact that Turkey indeed, or the TRNC indeed, instituted an investigation? The question arises, does that suffice to trigger the jurisdictional link under the Markovitsch principles? I would ask Mr. Riza if you have a view on this as well. It would be very useful, thank you.
text.290: Merci, M. le Président. J'aurais 2 questions. La 1re pour la requérante. Maître, lors de votre plaidoirie de ce matin, vous avez évoqué la nécessité d'un régime de surveillance plus restrictif dans le cas d'Antonio Rosset, étant donné notamment sa tentative de suicide du 1er avril et de l'intoxication alcoolique du 25 avril. Avez-vous présenté cet argument précis devant les juridictions nationales? Si oui, devant quelles juridictions? Avez-vous plaidé durant la procédure interne la nécessité de réévaluation de la situation d'Antonio lors de son retour à l'hôpital psychiatrique le 25 avril de l'an 2000? La 2e question va au gouvernement. Vous avez évoqué, Mme, je vous cite, qu'il n'y avait aucun risque de suicide. Et vous avez dit que la Chambre a présenté sa version des faits de façon différente par rapport à celle des juridictions nationales. Je vois que le tribunal administratif de Coimbra a considéré que malgré le risque de suicide d'une personne chez qui on a diagnostiqué une maladie mentale comme celle du fils de la requérante, au cours des derniers jours, ayant précédé son décès, l'intéressé n'avait montré ni comportement ni humeur susceptible d'amener le personnel de l'hôpital à penser que le 27 avril 2000 serait différent des jours précédents. Est-ce qu'il s'agit d'une version des faits différente ou d'une évaluation différente du degré de gravité de la situation ou du degré de risque de suicide? S'agit-il donc d'une version ou d'une sorte de dénaturation des faits ou d'une évaluation différente des faits établie par les juridictions nationales? Merci.
text.291: Thank you, President. I would be interested in the security measures taken. It's not only possible to commit suicide with a train, but there are many different possibilities or dangers. So I would be interested to understand better the security regime of the hospital. In general, for example, with belts, were belts prohibited? We hear that there was a pavilion, but perhaps there were windows where there was a danger of people throwing themselves out. So I would like to know, were there general other security measures in place to prevent suicides from happening? And the second question goes to both parties, also concerning security measures. The first suicide attempt was on 1st of April, and after that, on 21st of April, he was allowed to go home. And as I understand, he himself wanted to go home and the family accepted him coming home, and the hospital also accepted it. Were there any security measures taken allowing him to go home? Because there were a lot of dangers, possible dangers for him already during that period without any surveillance to commit suicide. Thank you.
text.292: Thank you, President. I have two questions for the government and one question for the applicant. For the government, I listened carefully to the oral pleadings of the government and I was expecting a response to the first question and the fourth question. The first question of the supplementary questions put recently refers to the regulatory framework compelling hospitals to adopt appropriate measures for the protection of patients' lives. And the question is related, of course, to the regime applicable to this person. Today we have listened to the government saying that it was en regime ouvert. The government said le régime therapeutique a été suivi, la prise de médicaments et l'accompagnement par une équipe pluridisciplinaire en régime ouvert. So it's clear for the government, this is my question, that on the 27th it was en régime ouvert. This is the first question. But the government also says that ça ne signifie pas que les autorités reconnaissaient le risque de suicide des patients. En effet, l'hôpital sous Bréaucid disposait de procédés spécifiques pour protéger la vie des patients contre le risque réel et accentué de suicide. Dans ces conditions extrêmes, un régime de contention pourrait même être suivi avec une vindication adéquate, une surveillance renforcée ou même l'isolement. My question, which repeats the first question put in the supplementary questions list, is the following. What is the legal basis of this régime de contention? What is the legal basis of this régime de contention which includes l'isolement? Is the government aware of the 2011 guidelines of the Director General on Health, Francisco Jorge, which determines the measures that can be taken in all Portuguese psychiatric hospitals, all hospitals in fact, not only the psychiatric but also other hospitals, in order to prevent the risk for life, any serious risk for the patients who put their own safety or the safety of others at risk? These guidelines provide in paragraph 9 that each hospital should have its own internal guidelines. I read each health care institution should define within the scope of this orientation a standard of internal performance on the use of restraint measures in accordance with the specificities of the care it provides. And of course it refers to what is stated in subparagraph K with regard to environmental restraint, meaning the use of changes that control the mobility of the patient. It could, for instance, include confinement to a room, a closed or limited space where the patient can wander safely with clinical supervision. So the question is very clearly, what is the legal basis for this regime de contention? Is the government aware of these guidelines from 2011 which refer to this regime de contention? The second question to the government refers to the explanation, it's the fourth question of the supplementary questions. The question was stated as follows. Is there any explanation as to why there is no clinical record from 4 p.m. on the 26th of April to 8 a.m. on the 27th of April in the medical file? Now I'm particularly interested in the fact that there is no risk assessment. There is a column in the medical file which refers to grau de dependencia, degree of dependence. This is the risk assessment made by the medical doctors. The most recent risk assessment that we have is from the 2nd and the 3rd of September, 1999, and it refers to a degree of dependence level three, which means the most serious, the most imminent risk. Can you provide any explanation as to why there is no clinical record during this period of time, especially after the 25th of April, regarding the risk assessment of this patient? Now my question to the applicant, you refer to a document authored by Professor Carlos Fernandes, which you say that has been joined to this file, to the file of the court. Well we went through the file and we don't find this document. If Professor Carlos Fernandes, who I believe is here, would be so kind as to inform the court of the content of this document and what happened to this document. Was it taken into account at the national level or not? Because we don't know. We know nothing about this document. It seems that it's an expertise, but we don't know the content and we don't know the destiny that was given to this report, to this document. If you would be so kind as to explain, to summarize for the court the content of this document, we would appreciate it. Thank you very much.
text.293: Thank you, Mr. President. Not to prolong the proceedings too much, but I have one question which was prompted by the pleadings this morning and to some extent by the question posed by my colleague, Judge Sicilianos. One of the questions presented to the parties in this case, a crucial question, is how would you invite the court to assess the facts as established by the domestic courts? In other words, in what position is this court at this point to call into question or interpret differently the factual findings by the domestic? And it's on that basis that I want to pose this question. I present it first and foremost to the applicant, but I would invite the government to answer as well. We have two judgments in this case, the first instance court in Cumbra and then the Supreme Administrative Court. I will cite, and I want your reaction to this finding of the Supreme Administrative Court in the language as translated for us by the government. And this is on the second to last page of the Supreme Administrative Court's judgment. There the court says, despite the possibility of suicide being permanently part of mental disorders such as those that were diagnosed to Antonio Jose, in the days preceding the fateful one, there was no attitude, no behavior, or mood on his part which could arise the suspicion that that day would be different from others. Indeed, as has been already mentioned, the episode of drunkenness occurred on 25th April 2000 was merely an irresponsible behavior, which was normal and in line to Antonio Jose's alcohol addiction. Therefore, it is not possible to conclude that the suicide was at that time present in Antonio Jose's mind. I want you now to put aside your arguments as regards to the preventive issues, the fencing. They do not deal with this part of the judgment. Can you present to me as succinctly as possible, what do you consider to be the factual elements which the domestic court is overlooking, which they are not giving enough weight, and which would then allow this court to call into question this finding? As succinctly as possible, just so I can clarify it in my mind. Thank you.
text.294: Thank you very much. I would like to ask the applicant to clarify something which is mentioned in the observations to the Grand Chamber. And this is in paragraph 57, where the applicant states that it is imperative that patients, such as her son, must have specific care with measures of containment and personal surveillance without guards or electronic bracelets. I'm curious to know, could you please explain what this means in concrete terms? So there should be no guards, there should be no electronic bracelets, but there should be containment and personal surveillance. What exactly do you mean? And following from that, if the position is, as it may seem to be, that there should have been physical obstacles preventing the patients from leaving the hospital premises, this again seems to suggest that, according to the applicant, her son should have been kept in a closed institution. And this, in turn, raises the question of consent. Now, the government is arguing that the conditions for compulsory care were not met. So could the applicant explain on what basis, then, her son could and should have been put under conditions of deprivation of liberty regardless of his consent, even if conditions of compulsory care were not met? And how do you reconcile such a position with the requirements and the case law concerning Article 5 of the Convention? Thank you.
text.295: Thank you, Mr. President. In the context of differential treatment on the basis of gender, so male convicts compared to female convicts, both parties address one of the possible scenarios where the violation of Article 14 in conjunction with Article 5 may be established. And the question for both parties will be in this context. So the government in their observations in paragraph 29 states that, I quote, such finding of a violation would call for worsening of the situation of a great mess of other people not involved in the proceedings before the court. May I kindly ask to explain how and why the situation of other people would necessarily be made worse and whether the government doesn't see a way of complying with such a possible ruling without worsening the situation of other people in line with the European Convention of Human Rights. As to the applicants, applicants in their observations in paragraphs 52, 53, refer to the individualization of punishment as the best solution and a general principle in sentencing policy that should be applied. And I would kindly ask to clarify whether the applicants mean the characteristics which are listed in Article 60 of the Russian Criminal Code, namely, which have to be taken into account when the punishment is inflicted, namely the convict's personality, influence on the rehabilitation and impact on living conditions of the convict's family, or you mean extension of the same article to female offenders or maybe both. Thank you.
text.296: Thank you, Mr. President. My question is addressed to the government, but of course the applicants can also take a position on this question. In fact, it's a group of three different points that I would like to raise. There is scientific evidence that demonstrates that the suicide rate and the insanity rate among prisoners sentenced for life is higher than among prisoners sentenced for prison terms of fixed duration, and much higher among men than among women. Male prisoners sentenced for life tend to commit suicide or become insane more often than women sentenced for life, and much more often than people in freedom. Male offenders between 18 and 65 commit more often suicide and become more often insane than women, minors and seniors. And this occurs especially when they are serving life or indeterminate prison terms. My question to the government, do you have any statistical data in Russia to contradict this evidence? Second question, is there any scientific evidence in Russia of a correlation between the sex and age of the offender and the gravity of the offense? Can you prove to this court that men, and particularly men aged between 18 and 65, commit more serious crimes than women offenders or male offenders under 18 or male offenders over 65? Final question, is there any scientific evidence, statistical evidence in Russia of a correlation between life imprisonment and lower crime rates, or at least lower violent crime rates? Can you prove to this court that this Russian life imprisonment sentencing policy has produced lower crime rates and particularly lower violent crime rates? Can you prove to this court that the prohibition of life sentence to female, juvenile and senior offenders has caused lower crime rates among the Russian female, juvenile and senior population? Thank you very much.
text.297: Just a brief question to the government. The government states in its observation that the Russian criminal code provides for only 19 types of crimes punishable by life imprisonment. And then the government states that life imprisonment is not imposed in a person automatically for the commission of the above crimes. I think I understand it means that there is the life imprisonment is not mandatory. It's not mandatory in any of these 19 cases. I would like the government to confirm this statement if really this is the case. I think it's an important point. Thank you.
text.298: Thank you. I would like to ask the applicants to clarify to the court what kind of measures the authorities would have to implement to restore the rights of the applicants, I would say to avoid discrimination in case we find a violation of Article 14 in conjunction with Article 5 of the convention. Thank you.
text.299: Just a short question. We have heard that the conditions for life prisoners are much worse than for others. And I just would like to understand better why is it not only the time that is different, but also the conditions? Because that means that for women, you have basically always different conditions. Thank you.
text.300: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. Je voudrais poser 2 questions au parti. L'une pour le gouvernement, l'autre pour les requérants. Pour le gouvernement, tout d'abord. Le requérant prétend que les frais d'épargne ont été calculés par les juridictions compétentes sur la base de la valeur modifiée de l'objet de mitiges, c'est-à-dire 105 000 kounas. Et il décède là une certaine contradiction entre le fait de calculer ces dépenses sur la base de la valeur modifiée, d'une part, et d'autre part, de rejeter cette même modification. Je voudrais avoir votre réaction sur cet argument. Pour le requérant, le gouvernement prétend, contrairement à ce que vous venez de dire, que l'avocat de Montenegro qui avait représenté le prédécesseur de la requérante avait bien le droit de le faire et que le code de procédure civile de Montenegro et de la Croatie avait essentiellement le même contenu et que, par conséquent, l'avocat du prédécesseur de la requérante connaissait bien les conséquences de son choix de préciser l'objet de litige à une valeur de 10 000 kounas. J'aimerais votre commentaire sur cette prétention de gouvernement. Merci beaucoup.
text.301: I have a question to the government. It's a point raised by the applicant, which I believe the government has not addressed, at least until now. It's about the clarity of the legal framework in Croatia on the admissibility criteria for an appeal before the Supreme Court. The point made by the applicant is that the situation is not entirely clear. There is some contradiction between the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Court. There are contradictory positions on this precise topic. I would like the government to elaborate on this argument, on this alleged contradiction between Supreme Court case law and the Constitutional Court case law. Thank you.
text.302: Just one question that caught my eye while the government was presenting, stating that actually the applicants only asked for the power of attorney to be given to the court and did not challenge the power of attorney. And I will read from the Croatian file how it is stated. The power of attorney in the file is given two submissions. The first one, which asks for the power of attorney to be challenged, states that Vukasin Zubac allegedly gave his opponent Kosi Zubac for the termination of the contract for the replacement of the property. And after that, it continues to ask for it to be put in the file. I would like to know if the government can comment on this.
text.303: Thank you, President. I would have two questions to the Russian government. First, I would like to understand the decision-making process when the riot police intervenes and disperses demonstrations. I guess there is some general strategy how to act. Who elaborates this strategy? On which level is it done? And then, when the police officers of the OMON, of the riot police, intervene, do they do it spontaneously? Do they ask the headquarter who takes the respective orders? That would be my first question. And my second question is for interpretation of Russian law. I understand that in every modern society it's sometimes necessary to queue up somewhere before an entrance of a theater or shop, wherever. It was a court building, you queue up. And how do you then differentiate between queuing up – there might be many people – and between what you consider an assembly? Thank you.
text.304: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have one question that I would like to pose to the applicant. As you're aware, one of the questions posed for the hearing and one of the issues the Grand Chamber is considering is the issue under Article 18. We have now a recent Grand Chamber judgment in a case called Metabishvili versus Georgia, where the court consolidates its case law on this issue. And one of the issues mentioned here today is the finding by the court that under Article 18, the so-called predominant purpose has to be or appeared to be the fundamental aspect of the case. So it is on that basis. And because there is an argument made by the government which hasn't been addressed here today or in your written pleadings, the government says in their observations, and I refer here to the observations of the 18th of December lodged with the court, in paragraph 13, the government says, in particular, Article 18 of the convention was expressly invoked by the applicant in only two out of his five applications. And those two applications relate to the first two episodes. Article 18 was not expressed, according to the government, was not expressly invoked by the applicant for the five last episodes. And the reference to political reasons or persecutions is not to be found in the initial application. Mr. Navalnyy said here today Article 18 is the key issue in the case. Could I then ask the applicant to elaborate, why is in Article 18, why didn't it form part of the initial pleadings by the applicant and an argumentation made already at the state of original applications within the court? And how would you answer the government's contention on this issue? Because, after all, that's one of the elements that we need to consider. Thank you.
text.305: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai une question au gouvernement. Est-ce qu'en Russie, d'une manière générale, je me permets d'insister sur la notion de généralité et non sur le cas individuel dont la Corée saisit, les autorités font preuve de sévérité à l'égard de tous les manifestants dès lors qu'elles considèrent qu'une manifestation est illégale? Merci.
text.306: Thank you M. president. I have three blocks of questions. The first addresses the question of admissibility. The first two elements of that go to the applicant. The government in paragraphs 11 to 15 of its observation to the Grand Chamber raises an objection of admissibility of the Article 5 complaint in relation to six out of the seven arrests complained of. How does the applicant respond to that objection, which might of course go to the court's jurisdiction to consider these complaints, and how, if at all, do you say the court should deal with that objection now? The same question arises in relation to Article 11, where the government in paragraphs 32 and 33 of its observation also expressly asserts, and they did again so today, that the applicant denied participating in a public assembly and did not raise the substance of the Article 11 complaint in the domestic courts. There is, of course, then for the government the procedurally prior question, what you say is the adequate and effective remedy you say the applicant should have exhausted, and what evidence is there that confirms its adequacy and effectiveness. The second block of question goes to Article 11 and deals with, again, the first element of it is addressed to the applicant. The government's assertion, both in writing and today, that the applicant denied participating in a public assembly leads me to the question to ask, on what basis do you say, especially in relation to the solo picket on 27 October 2012 and the arrest while waiting outside the courthouse on 24 February 2014, that Article 11 was in fact engaged at all? After all, as this court held in Tata and Farber v. Hungary, the term assembly under Article 11 has an autonomous meaning, I pause here to query whether waiting outside a court building is even an expression, and that fits into Judge Nussberg's question, occurs in the public space, does not necessarily turn such event into an assembly. Now that, of course, then leads me to the follow-up question for the government. In that same case, this court reasoned that such an autonomous meaning serves the interests of the protection of the right against improper classification in national law. The example the court gives in that case may well be pertinent to the present case. It is this. By relying on the domestic law on assemblies and by implication of the court's case law in the context of Article 11, which accepts in principle that the imposition of prior notification may be justified, the authorities in that case were said to seek to create a prior restraint on the freedom of expression, which is incompatible with the free communication of ideas and might undermine freedom of expression. The question for the government is this. Would you accept that reliance on the law of assemblies to justify the applicant's arrest, at least in relation to the two incidents identified, amount or might amount to an improper classification by the domestic authorities and or the courts, and or is capable of providing evidence relevant to the assessment of the applicant's complaint of bad faith or ulterior motives, which is currently pleaded under Article 18? And finally, in relation to that complaint about bad faith and ulterior motive, of course, the government in its further observations in paragraph 28 relies on Article 17, abuse of rights in relation to an aspect of the applicant's claim. The question I have is the case on bad faith and ulterior motives is, of course, currently pleaded and responded to under Article 18 of the Convention, limitation on the use of rights, on the restriction on rights. Questions of both parties is this. Is there any reason why the court should be limited to considering this complaint solely by reference to Article 18 and why it could not also be classified as an abuse of rights under Article 17, an article which I said you raise, the government raises in relation to the applicant's complaint? After all, in so far as relevant, that article provides that nothing in this Convention may be interpreted as implying for any state any right to engage in any activity or perform any act aimed at the destruction of any of the rights and freedoms set forth therein or, perhaps importantly in this case, at their limitation to a greater extent than is provided for in the Convention. Thank you very much. Thank you.
text.307: Thank you Mr. President. My question goes to the applicant. The agent of the government just presented some statistical data concerning the rallies organized by the applicant or by your movement saying that many of them have been authorized, regularly authorized. Do you contest or confirm such affirmation? Thank you very much.
text.308: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. J'ai une question qui est dirigée aux deux parties. La question est la suivante. Comment s'est déroulée, dans le détail, l'exécution de la mesure d'urgence du 17 octobre 2008 par laquelle X fut confié à une famille d'accueil? Je vous remercie.
text.309: Thank you very much, Mr. President. This case is centered by the parties very much around what is the role of this court in cases of this nature. And Mr. Sajistad, you said three things during your pleadings which prompt my question. The first is you said we need to assess the situation at the point in time when the decision in question, the forced adoption decision was taken in 2012. You accepted that the court must apply strict scrutiny and therefore assess whether there were relevant and sufficient reasons. I want to proceed on the basis that that is something the court will agree with you with. That remains to be seen. But my question is on that basis. In this case, we have a court judgment, the city court judgment of February 2012, where the applicant presents a claim that the situation at that point in time had changed. She was married. She had another child. And I want your view on how we and I should understand the city court's judgment in relation to that claim made by the applicant at that point. The city court's judgment, this is page 11 of the judgment, the court says the court agrees with the county social welfare board that the mother has not changed in such a way as to indicate it is now highly probable that she will be able to provide X with proper care. The court endorses the county social welfare board's grounds. In the court's view, the mother's clear limitations as a caregiver cannot be mitigated by an adapted transitional scheme, assistance measures, or support from the mother's network. Then the court says, and here is what I would like your input on, and I would also ask Mr. Diodone if he has a view. The court will not discuss the other arguments regarding the mother's ability to provide care in more detail as returning X is in any case not an option due to the serious problems it would cause X to be moved from the foster home. So my question is, Mr. Syestad, should I read the city court's judgment as taking a clear position on the applicant's central claim as regards the situation in 2012 that her situation as regards marriage and her caregiving of another child was not examined as such, at least in the reasoning there is no reference to that? Or is there another way to read the judgment? I also draw attention to your observations, paragraph 165, where the government makes its own assessment where it says, it would not have been correct to set the assessments with regard to exercise with reference to vague descriptions of the first applicant's care for her daughter. May I ask, why were they vague? Was there a lack of information at that point in the file which would clarify the nature of that role and in the global assessment by the Drammenkurt? So just a clarification on how I should read the Drammenkurt's judgment on that. Just a second question, which is the issue in relation to the legal test we're applying. The government refers to the two-limb child best interest test. Now as you said, and my question is prompted by another part of your pleading, you said, the test presumes first that the child should remain with the biological family unless the parent is considered particularly unfit. Then we would go to the second limb of the test, which is the stability of the environment. May I ask this question? If this court were to consider that the fitness assessment, the first limb, might be called into question because of lack of relevant and sufficient reasons, would you still consider that under the second limb there would be an adequate justification for the measure in question? In other words, if the first limb of the child best interest test under the court's case law is not met, is there a violation already there? Or would you defend the claim further and say, even though it is not clear that she was particularly unfit, in any event, your argument would be there would be no violation under the second limb. Could you clarify the relationship between the two? And I would also ask Mr. Diudonne to comment, if he so wishes. Thank you.
text.310: Thank you, Mr. President. I will have a very small factual question. It's perhaps difficult for the representative of the government. The question is addressed to the government to answer, but I will nevertheless try. Why didn't the assistant midwife who made an assessment at the moment when the applicant left the hospital, when the child was three weeks old, why didn't she appear in further procedures whereas others did? She disappeared after having given her assessment when the child was three weeks old, and others appeared further on, but she didn't. Is there a reason for that? Thank you very much.
text.311: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have one question to the government and one to the applicant, which are prompted by the pleadings this morning. To the government, I noticed from the observations of the government that on the Article 6 complaint and the merits of the Article 6 complaint dealing with the independence and impartiality of the organs deciding the case at domestic level, we have renditions of reasoning in paragraph 62 to 65, which do not make any reference to a case called Alexander Volkov versus Ukraine. May I ask the government to comment on whether it considers the merits issue under Article 6 to be distinguishable in this case from the case of Alexander Volkov, and then explain, if so, to what extent? So our assessment can be based on that argumentation by the government. To the applicant, I have one question as well. There are basically two core arguments presented by the applicant why there has been an interference with Article 8, why Article 8 is applicable in this case. The first is in paragraph 99 of your observations, which are basically issues going to the damage to the applicant's reputation. And in paragraph 100, there is a reference to financial consequences. I want to turn to the first, the damage to the applicant's reputation. May I ask, because it is not addressed in your written observations, it was not addressed here orally, the court has held that Article 8 cannot be relied upon to complain of a loss of reputation, which is the foreseeable consequence of one's own actions. This has primarily been directed to criminal offenses, but it is not only limited to criminal offenses. May I ask the applicant to comment, why should not the court apply that doctrine on the facts of a case which deals with the underperformance of a civil servant, and thus dismissal being the consequence of that underperformance? Is it the view of the applicant that this part of the court's case law is simply inapplicable in a situation like this, thus being the basis upon which we could not rely upon potential damage to the applicant's reputation? I just want to ask you this, and I want you to put aside, for the sake of argument, the case of Ermeni versus Hungary. Let's assume that Ermeni versus Hungary has not been decided by this court. So don't rely on that case in your answer, but give me your own principled answer to the question. Thank you.
text.312: Merci, M. le Président. Je voudrais poser ma question en français, si possible. Merci beaucoup. Ma question s'adresse au requérant et elle se situe dans le prolongement de la question qui a été posée tout à l'heure par mon collègue, le président Spano. Elle concerne notamment le paragraphe 100 de vos observations. Là, il y a une allusion, mais une allusion seulement à des choses que vous avez évoquées aujourd'hui. Vous dites, les vraies raisons de ma révocation n'étaient pas connues que d'un petit nombre de personnes. Les vraies raisons. Mais ces vraies raisons n'ont jamais été évoquées ou en tout cas pas clairement dans vos observations. Et aujourd'hui, on a entendu une démonstration qui était fondée, entre autres, sur l'article 18 de la Convention, une disposition qui, jusqu'à maintenant, n'a pas été évoquée. Et on a cru comprendre que votre argumentation tourne essentiellement autour de l'idée suivant laquelle le requérant a été révoqué de ses fonctions dans le contexte d'une certaine persécution politique. Il y a là un décalage assez évident, me semble-t-il, entre les observations écrites et vos observations orales de tout à l'heure. Et on aimerait peut-être avoir un peu plus d'éléments sur ce point. Merci beaucoup.
text.313: Thank you very much, Mr. President. My question concerns the applicant and his complaint under Article 8. You mentioned today in your oral pleading for the first time, it was not included in your observation, a letter which was written on the 2nd February 2010 by Mr. Bondik addressed to every judge in Ukraine and which contained accusations against the applicant. Now could you please explain us what exactly was the correlation between this letter from 2010, then the applicant's dismissal from 2011, and his private life under Article 8? Thank you.
text.314: Thank you very much, President. Well, I would have a question to the government first. In your memorial, you wrote on page eight, I quote, only if the claimants had denounced the breach of data legislation committed by the company could the Data Protection Agency have studied and protected their rights. Now in your pleadings, you have explained that they could have had access to the data as collected, they could have asked for erasure, and you also said that there could have been a heavy fine against the enterprise. I would like to know if there's jurisprudence that enterprises have been fined for similar violations of data protection law, and more importantly, could the applicant themselves have claimed damages under the data protection law or under civil law? I don't know. And in this context, a question to the applicants. When the applicants learned about the existence of the recordings and the breach of the data protection law, why didn't you appeal to the Data Protection Agency? And my last question, also more to the government, why did the employer not inform? I understand that there was a workers council in this enterprise. And so I want to know why the employer did not inform the workers council before installing the video surveillance. Why didn't they inform at least them, if not the worker themselves? Thank you.
text.315: Thank you, Mr. President. I have some questions for the two parties about facts. I start by the applicants, but when the first question, it can be answered also for the government if they know. I would like to know the number of employees in this supermarket of Mercadona at the time when the facts occurred, the number of employees, and the exact number of cashiers, if you have this data. Well, a second question for the applicants. text.338: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions, one to both parties, in relation to the question raised before by judges Wojtyczek, Spano, and López Guerra. And I would like to know what was the exact status of the applicant under the law applicable at the relevant time. Was he a civil servant, technically speaking? The second question goes to the government. The relevant report of the intelligence service was classified as reserved. So apparently, it had a low level of classification. So in view of this, I am wondering whether it was possible to disclose the report in a redacted form, so as to protect the interests of the national security, while at the same time give a sense to the applicants, so as for him to prepare his defense. Thank you very much.
text.339: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai des questions qui doublent les cas échéants, celles déjà posées par mes collègues, et c'est des questions et aussi des demandes de clarification parce que les représentants ont déjà abordé les questions. Ma première question s'adresse plutôt au gouvernement. Est-ce que le gouvernement peut préciser la relation entre le retrait de l'attestation de sécurité et les poursuites pénales engagées dans la suite contre le requérant? Et plus précisément, ces poursuites sont-elles la conséquence de l'enquête menée par les services secrets ayant donné lieu au retrait de l'attestation de sécurité? J'ai une question ensuite aux deux partis, et qui sont dans la ligne de ce que mes collègues ont chaque fois abordé. Est-ce que les partis peuvent confirmer que sous l'empire de la législation, en vigueur au moment des faits ayant donné lieu aux présents litiges, il n'existait pas un droit de chèque de fonction publique au sens traditionnel ou technique du terme, avec des droits et obligations particuliers pour les fonctionnaires, et que le statut des agents travaillant dans la fonction publique relevait du droit privé? Y avait-il néanmoins des obligations particulières pesant sur les agents travaillant pour des entités de droit public, et notamment découlant des spécificités de leurs fonctions? La troisième question s'adresse au requérant. Est-ce que le requérant peut fournir, et elle est aussi dans la ligne de ce que mon collègue Spano a dit, est-ce que le requérant peut fournir des détails sur l'évolution de la carrière, et surtout la fin de celle-ci? Peut-il en particulier livrer des explications sur ses soucis de santé qui l'ont empêché de continuer à travailler dans la fonction publique? Peut-il confirmer ou infirmer qu'après le retrait de l'attestation de sécurité, le ministère a cherché à lui trouver un autre emploi dans l'administration gouvernementale? Et que s'est-il passé au juste entre le retrait de l'attestation de sécurité et la résiliation d'un commun accord de la relation de travail? Car il y a eu une certaine période entre ces deux événements. Je vous remercie. Merci.
text.340: Merci, M. le Président. Tout d'abord, 2 questions adressées au gouvernement. Le gouvernement a insisté à maintes fois en relation avec la gravité du comportement de M. Regner. Ma question est la suivante. Pourquoi est-ce qu'il n'a jamais été suspendu, voire licencié? 2e question, également destinée au gouvernement. Est-ce que le juge instructeur ou l'autorité juridictionnelle compétente en République tchèque, est-ce qu'il a jamais déclaré le secret de l'instruction? Et 3e question, donc dirigée aux 2 partis. Quel est l'état actuel de la procédure pénale? Merci beaucoup, M. le Président.
text.341: Merci, M. le Président. J'aurais plusieurs questions. La 1re s'adresse aux 2 parties. Par un arrêt du 21 mars 2012, la Cour suprême portugaise s'est prononcée sur la demande de révision du procès introduite par la requérante. Je voudrais savoir, à cette date du 21 mars 2012, quels étaient les effets pratiques de la condamnation? Où en était la procédure d'exécution de la peine? 2e question, elle s'adresse aussi aux 2 parties. La condamnation de la réclairante figure-t-elle encore au casier judiciaire? Quand va-t-elle être effacée? Si ce n'est pas déjà le cas. La 3e question s'adresse aussi aux 2 parties. Je voudrais avoir un peu plus de précision sur les mesures qui ont été entreprises pour exécuter l'arrêt du 5 juillet 2011 de notre Cour dans l'affaire introduite par la requérante. Enfin, la dernière question s'adresse au gouvernement. Je voudrais savoir si le gouvernement estime que notre arrêt en date du 5 juillet 2011 a été exécuté ou si cet arrêt exige encore d'autres mesures d'exécution. Je vous remercie.
text.342: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. Mes questions sont liées aux questions qui ont été mises par le juge Wojtyczek. D'abord, dans l'arrêt de 2012 de la Cour suprême portugaise qui vient d'être citée, vous avez la Cour en vogue le cas de Öcalan versus la Turquie. Je voulais exactement savoir comment est-ce que vous interprétez cet arrêt et comment est-ce que, surtout, vous interprétez le mot qui existe là-bas en principe? C'est ma première question. Deuxième question qui s'adresse également au gouvernement. Elle est liée aussi à une question qui a été prise auparavant. Elle vise le plan d'action concernant l'exécution de l'arrêt de la Cour européenne des droits de l'homme dans l'affaire Francelina Moreira Ferreira contre le Portugal. Et dans ce plan d'action, il est dit que cette proposition sera examinée dans le cadre d'une nouvelle révision du dite code dont les travaux devront débuter en principe dès le mois de septembre prochain. Donc, je voulais savoir exactement ce plan d'action, où il est en ce moment et comment c'est marqué à l'époque par votre gouvernement devant le comité de ministre. Je vous remercie beaucoup, M. le Président.
text.343: M. le Président, je voudrais poser une question à la représentation de la requérante pour une certaine clarification. Parce que j'ai quelques doutes sur quel est exactement le contenu de la plainte de la requérante devant cette grande chambre. C'est-à-dire, devant la chambre, la plainte était basée sur la violation de l'article 6.1 de la Convention parce que la requérante n'avait pas été entendue en personne par la Cour d'appel. Alors la chambre a apprécié qu'il y avait une violation et la requérante a posé une demande de révision devant la Cour suprême. La Cour suprême de Portugal l'a rejetée. Maintenant, devant cette grande chambre, la plainte contre cet arrêt de la Cour suprême est basée aussi, fondée aussi, sur une nouvelle violation de l'article 6.1 de la Convention. Mais mon demande, c'est quelle est la cause exacte de la violation? C'est-à-dire, la cause, le fondement, c'est le même que dans la requête devant la chambre, c'est-à-dire que la requérante n'avait pas été entendue ou la raison de la violation maintenant est une autre. Je ne sais pas quelle est la décision que l'arrêt de la Cour suprême a fait arbitraire ou enraisonnée, mais quelle est exactement la cause de la violation de l'article 6.1 qui se pose devant cette grande chambre?
text.344: Thank you, Madam President. I have several questions that I want to pose to the government and also to the applicants. Just to put my questions in context, there are three issues that are before the court for us to examine. Number one, was a CIA detention site operated in Romania in 2003 to 2005? And if so, was the applicant detained during that period? And thirdly, if both of those questions are answered affirmatively, can the applicant's detention and treatment in Romania be attributed to the Romanian government? So my first question goes to the government's arguments in the papers and also today during the pleadings as regards the Romanian authorities and government's awareness, assuming the first two questions were answered affirmatively. In other words, a detention site was there and that Mr. Al Nashiri was detained. I want to draw the government's attention to paragraph 441, subparagraph 4, of the Al Nashiri versus Poland judgment, which puts the awareness issue in a chronological context. There, the court found that already between January 2002 and August 2003, remember the allegation here is that the detention site in Romania was operational from 2003 to 2005, numerous public sources were consistently reporting ill treatment and abuse to which captured terrorist suspects were subjected in US custody in different places. Moreover, in the 2003 PACE resolution adopted in June 2003, of which Poland as any other contracting state, among them, of course, Romania, the parliamentary assembly of the Council of Europe was, and I quote, deeply concerned at the conditions of detention of captured unlawful combatants held in the custody of the US authorities. And the court found all these sources reported practices resorted to or tolerated by the US authorities that were manifestly contrary to the principles of the convention. Consequently, there were good reasons to believe that a person in US custody under the HVD program could be exposed to a serious risk of treatment contrary to those principles. My question to the Polish government is this, assuming, Romanian government is this, assuming that the first two questions that I mentioned were answered in the affirmative, how would you invite the court to distinguish your case and the circumstances in Romania as regards governmental awareness from the judicial facts found as regards to the situation in 2002 and 2003 in paragraph 441 of the Al Nashir versus Poland judgment? My second question goes to the issue, again, of awareness. And I want to draw the Romanian government's attention to two documents which I want clarification of, because they were not mentioned during your pleadings here today. On 13 December, 2014, an online version of Der Spiegel rendered, publishes an article which deals with information provided by the former Romanian chief of operations Ioan Talpeş. In this article, in the verbatim English translation, it is stated that Mr. Talpeş said that there were one or two locations in Romania at which the CIA, and I quote, probably held persons who were subjected to inhuman treatment. Talpeş had previously confirmed the existence of, and I quote, a CIA transit camp, as he calls them in the Bucharest daily Adevarul. On June 8 of this year, the European Parliament issued a resolution. In this resolution, in paragraph 13, it is stated, the parliament recalls that the former director of the Romanian secret services, Ioan Talpeş, admitted on record to the European Parliament delegation that he had been fully aware of the CIA's presence on Romanian territory, acknowledging that he had given permission to lease, I quote, lease a government building to the CIA. May I please ask the Romanian government to comment on the substance of these two documents and the relevance in the court's assessment? My third question goes to the effectiveness of the criminal investigation. And my question has two limbs. Firstly, may I ask, is it the contention of the Romanian government that the parliamentary inquiry itself concluded in 2008 that in and of itself was effective for the purposes of Article 3? In other words, the fact that we have a pending criminal complaint is not necessary for the resolution of the Article 3. In other words, if no criminal complaint would have all been invoked or established, then the parliamentary inquiry would itself be enough for Romania to have sufficiently exercised or sufficiently dealt with the issue under Article 3. And may I ask in that context, did the parliamentary inquiry have access to classified documents in its analysis? I know there is some issue on this in the papers, but please clarify. As regards to the criminal investigation, which was based on the applicant's criminal complaint of 29 May 2012, may I receive clarification of what is the status under statutory Romanian law of the applicant? Is he a formal victim under Romanian criminal procedural law? And if so, you mentioned that he had a right to be notified of procedural decisions and he had a right to be present during witness questioning. Could you please clarify what is the extent of his possible victim status position? My last question goes to both parties. And it deals with assuming that the applicant, Mr. Al Nashiri, was present on Romanian territory as a CIA detainee. May I draw the attention of both parties to page 73 of the US Senate report? On that page, it is stated, and I quote, in October 2004, 21 months after the final documented use of the CIA's enhanced interrogation techniques against Al nashiri, an assessment by CIA contract interrogator Dunbar and other CIA interrogator concluded that Al Nashiri provided, and I quote, essentially no actionable information. And I quote, the probability that he has much more to contribute is low. There is then a reference in a footnote, 372, stating that in June 2005, the detention site Black, which the allegation is the Romanian site, chief of base suspended even these debriefings because it was, and I quote, the very, very rare moment that Alnashiri would recognize a photograph and because the debriefings often were the catalyst for his outbursts. May I, on this basis, ask both parties to comment on what they consider to be proven as the application of the EITs, the enhanced interrogation techniques, if the court were to conclude that Mr. Al Nashiri was indeed detained in that period, the reason I ask this is because it matters for the qualification by the court of an eventual assessment under Article 3 of the nature of the treatment that the applicant was subjected to. Thank you, Mr. President.
text.345: Merci beaucoup, Madame la Présidente. C'est une question qui concerne le gouvernement, mais qui pourrait, le cas échéant, être aussi commentée par les requérants. J'ai entendu avec beaucoup d'intérêt les éléments fournis par l'agent du gouvernement au sujet des articles sur la responsabilité des Etats adoptés par la Commission d'ordre international des Nations Unies en 2001 et plus particulièrement au sujet des dispositions de ces articles concernant le problème, la question de l'attribution à l'Etat. Et il ne fait pas de doute que ces articles, du moins ceux qui codifient, qui concernent l'attribution, codifient l'état actuel du droit international général. La Cour internationale de justice l'a affirmé au moins à trois reprises. Mais de notre côté, le rapport du Sénat américain de 2014 avance et répète constamment que tous les sites de détention de la CIA en Europe et ailleurs ont pu fonctionner dans le respect de la souveraineté de l'Etat concerné, dans le respect de la souveraineté de l'Etat concerné. Et j'aimerais savoir comment est-ce que vous comprenez cette affirmation au regard des règles applicables en matière d'attribution que vous avez mentionnées. Merci beaucoup.
text.346: Merci beaucoup. J'ai deux questions. La première adressée au gouvernement, la deuxième adressée aux représentants du requérant. En ce qui concerne la question posée au gouvernement, j'aimerais revenir un petit peu sur les statuts de vol qui ont atterri, notamment sur l'aéroport de Bonaissa, le gouvernement a soutenu dans ses observations écrites et aussi aujourd'hui dans sa plaidoirie, que ces vols n'avaient pas un statut spécial en ce qui concerne l'immunité pour les personnes se trouvant au bord de ces avions, ni à part le fait qu'en général on a soutenu qu'il s'agissait tout simplement des scales techniques. Vu ces affirmations, j'invite le gouvernement à préciser sa position à l'égard de l'incident souffert le 6 décembre 2004, incident impliquant l'un de ces avions et à l'égard duquel le rapport rédigé par le Parlement européen fait mentionner le fait que les personnes se trouvant au bord de cet avion sont tout simplement disparues sans avoir pu être vérifiées, sans avoir pu être enregistrées par la police de frontière. Donc j'aimerais avoir la position, le commentaire du gouvernement à l'égard de cette affirmation-là. La deuxième question, adressé au representant du requérant, dans la mesure où, supposons que les requérants aient été détenus sur le territoire roumain, d'après les représentants du requérant, quel a été le pays tiers vers lequel le requérant a été transféré après sa détention en Roumanie et savoir si ce transfert vers ce pays tiers a aggravé de quelque façon que ce soit la situation juridique ou personnelle du requérant, ça veut dire à l'égard de son statut juridique, à l'égard du régime de détention, à l'égard des sanctions applicables, etc. Merci.
text.347: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai quelques questions factuelles qui s'adressent aux deux parties, mais en fait, plutôt à l'employeur qui n'est pas présent. Et il ne s'agit pas à proprement parler de questions, mais plutôt également de confirmations. Dans le mémoire du gouvernement, il est dit, et je cite, le 13 juillet 2007, dans le cadre de la procédure disciplinaire engagée par son employeur, le requérant lui-même déclara avoir ouvert le compte de massagerie pour fournir des conseils techniques aux clients de l'entreprise. Alors, ma question, qui était à l'initiative de la création des comptes Yahoo, professionnels et privés au sein de l'entreprise? Le requérant l'a-t-il fait de sa propre initiative ou y a-t-il été encouragé par l'employeur? Et dans cette suite, l'employeur était-il au courant de l'ouverture par le requérant de deux comptes dont l'un était privé et l'autre était professionnel, mais les deux fonctionnaient sur le matériel informatique de l'entreprise? Ca, c'est ma première question. La deuxième question, je me réfère au règlement d'ordre intérieur qui a été cité en partie dans le jugement, où il est dit, il est strictement interdit de troubler l'ordre et la discipline dans les cours de l'entreprise, et en particulier d'utiliser les ordinateurs, photocopieurs, téléphones, téléscripteurs, etc. à des fins personnelles. Par ailleurs, dans la note d'information circulée le 3 juillet 2007, il est dit, le temps passé dans l'entreprise doit être de qualité pour tout le monde. Venez au travail pour vous occuper des problèmes de la société, de votre travail, et non pas des problèmes privés. Ne passez pas votre temps à occuper les lignes Internet, téléphone, etc. Est-ce que les interdictions se rapportaient seulement à l'usage du matériel mis à disposition par l'employeur? Ou est-ce que l'interdiction a été générale, dans le sens qu'on ne devait même pas l'utiliser pendant les heures de travail, ses propres moyens de communication, si tant est qu'il en existait en 2007, comme des portables privés, etc.? Dans ce contexte, l'usage du compte personnel était-il autorisé ou toléré par l'employeur? Une dernière question qui était... Je crois qu'elle a déjà été répondue, mais une confirmation serait la bienvenue. Quel est le moment exact auquel l'employeur a imprimé les messages qu'il avait préalablement enregistrés avant ou après la déclaration du salarié qu'il s'agissait de messages professionnels? Merci.
text.348: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. J'ai aussi une question factuelle. Le gouvernement a précisé que le requérant, lui-même a diffusé le contenu des messages pendant le procès, c'était pas l'employeur. Mais est-ce que les transcriptions des communications privées du requérant ont été rendues publiques déjà, je dirais, par l'employeur? C'est-à-dire, est-ce qu'il a divulgué ces communications aux collègues, aux salariés au sein de l'entreprise? Parce que le requérant a ce griffé au paragraphe 82 de ses observations, mais là, il manque de détails, il n'y a pas assez de précisions. Donc, moi, je dirais que, comme le gouvernement a dit, il y a une différence, bien sûr, entre l'enregistrement, l'examen et la vérification, et l'examen des messages par l'employeur, mais je dirais qu'il existe aussi une grande différence, une grande, importante différence entre la vérification et l'examen et la divulgation des messages au sein de l'article 8. Et donc, par rapport à ça, j'aimerais aussi savoir, et surtout par le requérant, est-ce que ce griffé a été soulevé devant les juridictions internes? Voila, merci beaucoup.
text.349: Thank you very much. I also would have a factual question. I understand that on 3rd July 2007, as is said in the observations of the government, paragraph 11, a company-wide notice was registered with the Bucharest office. And then it was signed one by one by the employees. I would like to understand the communication policy in this respect. What does it mean it was registered? And was it only a paper version that was given from hand to hand, one by the other? Or was it also communicated electronically? Or was it even put on the blackboard in the enterprise? So how could the employees take notice of this note, just to understand, because we don't know this exactly when he knew it, between this period of 3rd July to 13th July. And the second question I would have, as my colleague Judge Ravarani has said, we have these two parallel accounts, the personal account and the professional account. And as they were parallel, I would like to understand the way of using it on the side of the employee. Did he make a difference in using the personal account and the professional account? And also for the employer, did the employer make a difference in monitoring the personal account and the professional account? Thank you.
text.350: Merci, Monsieur le Président. Pour ma part, je voudrais revenir sur un argument présenté par le gouvernement défendeur et dont il nous dit qu'il est inspiré par les informations données par la Confédération européenne des syndicats parties tierces intervenantes. Si j'ai bien compris la position du gouvernement sur ce point, il y aurait trois niveaux d'intensité dans la surveillance qu'un employeur peut exercer à l'égard des communications passées par un employé. Le premier niveau, le plus bas, serait celui d'un simple contrôle des flux. Le nombre de communications, le temps passé dans ces communications, leur durée. Un niveau intermédiaire serait celui de l'interception de ces communications, mais sans accès à leur contenu, ces communications étant alors conservées, notamment pour réserver une preuve si nécessaire dans un contentieux ultérieur, ou pour interroger le salarié lui-même sur le caractère privé ou professionnel de ces conversations interceptées, mais non ouvertes. Le troisième niveau, le niveau ultime, serait celui de l'interception avec accès immédiat au contenu de ces échanges. Le gouvernement, si j'ai bien compris sa position, nous dit que, en réalité, dans cette affaire, l'employeur aurait pratiqué le niveau de surveillance intermédiaire, c'est-à-dire qu'il aurait noté que le flux des communications était, je mets des guillemets, suspect, qu'il aurait alors intercepté ces communications, ces messages, mais sans avoir accès à leur contenu, qu'il aurait ensuite interrogé le salarié, le requérant, sur leur nature professionnelle ou privée, et que ce n'est que parce que le requérant aurait répondu que ces communications étaient professionnelles, qu'il n'avait que des communications professionnelles, qu'il aurait alors accédé au contenu de ces informations. Je voudrais, d'une part, que le gouvernement me dise si j'ai bien compris cette argumentation et si elle est soutenue factuellement comme étant soit établie, soit probable, soit hypothétique. Et je voudrais que les conseils du requérant nous disent, sur le plan factuel, ce qu'ils pensent de cette analyse, et sur le plan juridique, à supposer qu'il en soit ainsi, comment réagissent-ils. Voilà ma question, Monsieur le Président.
text.351: Thank you very much, I'd like to ask a first very simple question to the government, the government mentioned that there were some remedies that could have been exhausted by the applicant, does that mean that there is now a formal objection to the admissibility of the application based of non-exhaustion of these remedies. And the second question is to both parties and it is of a factual nature and it is somewhat in the line of what my colleague Mr. Potocki has asked. If I can see, or the government attached to its observations the charge showing the internet traffic. And it shows that the applicant has had much more, made much more use of the internet than some other employees. I don't know whether these are all the employees. I see that there are in total seven employees mentioned. My question is, this actually prompted the disciplinary proceedings by the employer. Was there also a rule on the excessive use of internet and in particular on the excessive use of Yahoo messenger by the employees? Whether private or professional. Was the use of the Yahoo messenger in itself something suspect within the firm? Was this high use of the Yahoo messenger an indication that it was being used for private purposes? And then I come a bit to the situation or the questions raised by my colleague. If the high use of the Yahoo messenger was already an indication of a private use, why then still ask the applicant whether he used it for professional purposes? I would like to, it's not, it's in fact a question to the employer, but I would like to know whether the parties have something to say about this. Thank you.
text.352: I have a question to both parties. You both said about legitimate expectations, and I understand both parties had legitimate expectations in this case. And can we, and can you say that it is possible, instead of legitimate expectations of privacy, in some circumstances, or in the context of this case, this particular case, there could be legitimate expectations that the privacy could be limited, or even monitored? And the second question is about the proportionality, whether the use of Internet for private correspondence was too much. So it's not a quick question between the relatives, just the call for emergency, or that we have 45 pages of correspondence. Isn't it too much for using, enjoying privacy in a working environment? And the question to the government, whether there was also no proportionality enjoyed by the employer when monitoring without or with any cause, just because it was the equipment belonging to the company, that's all, or there was any cause for monitoring. Or it is the case that we call as a mass surveillance case within the limits of working environment. Thank you.
text.353: Thank you very much, Mr. President. Actually, I have a couple of questions to both parties in regard to their recent observations. And I will start first with the government observations. At paragraph 6 of your observations, you say that on October 1999, when the applicant was arrested, the authorities conducted a series of investigative measures. They interviewed the applicants, accomplished witnesses, friends of the suspects, and anyone who could in some manner relate to the events. Evidential material was gathered in a systematic manner, and I underline the word systematic. In paragraph 9, you say that on 3rd of October, based on the applicant's submissions – and I don't know what submissions you mean – and the investigators' detention order of the 4th of October, he was taken to a police arrest and then to the Sofia Investigative Detention Facility. On paragraph 10, you say that on the 4th of October, the investigator in Berkas, the one in charge of the case, issued an order for the applicant's detention for 24 hours. On paragraph 11, you say that the applicant was examined by the doctor and a forensic doctor. In paragraph 13, you admit that there was an investigation file. But despite the above, you say that there was no trace of any interview of the applicants during these three days. My first question is, how do you explain this? And the second question is, in relation to this period, do you say categorically that there is no record proving that the applicant was asked any question whatsoever, even to state his name? And how do you explain the investigator of Berkas to issue an order for detention on 4th of October without the applicant being asked any question? Now, in relation to – the second question refers to the applicant. In paragraph 42 of the observations, the applicant argues that it may be that the assistance of a lawyer during the first three days of interrogation would not have resulted in his acquittal. On the other hand, the government, at paragraph 38 of their observation, underline that the applicant does not argue that any particular statements made by him between the 3rd and the 6th of October were later used in the criminal proceedings. Based on the above statements, and with a retrospective look, could the applicant be more specific? I know that you answered the question, but could you be more specific how the lack of a lawyer between the 3rd and the 6th of October had any effect whatsoever on the subsequent proceedings before the domestic courts, on any of the applicant's substantive or procedural rights and on the fairness of the trial as a whole? Thank you very much.
text.354: Thank you very much. I would like to ask a question to both parties. It has been argued by the applicant that when the applicant saw a lawyer on the 6th of October, that was Mr. Todorov, the appointed lawyer, that he was not able to meet that lawyer before the interrogation by the investigator. And I quote from paragraph 33 of the submissions of the applicant, that indeed, all his meetings with lawyers during the pre-trial proceedings were conducted in the office of the investigator, with the latter always being present. End of quote. I would like to ask whether, according to the parties, this is indeed part of the complaint, because we are now on the 6th of October for the first time in interrogation with a lawyer. And if so, whether the government has something to say about the presence of other people during the conversation between the applicant and his lawyer. There's something unclear about what this statement means in the context of the whole case. And I would like to ask the parties to clarify this. Thank you.
text.355: My question is for counsel for the applicant, but the government might comment if they wish so, of course. My question is with respect to the argument that the right to access to a lawyer should not necessarily be linked to the overall assessment of the fairness of the trial. What would then be the remedy of a finding of a violation, is my question. And more specifically, with respect to the reopening of the proceedings, what would be the possible standards in more general terms for reopening and in the specific circumstances of the present case? Thank you.
text.356: Just some information from the government. The applicant was arrested the 3rd of October. He remained arrested for the 3rd, the 4th, the 5th, the 6th of October. No lawyer was appointed. It seems that no evidence was gathered during these two or three days. No case paper shows that the applicant was questioned by the police. He was not involved in any other investigative measure. No investigation parade or any kind of other biological sampling or anything. My question is, what was the reason for this negative situation? Why the government decided, or the police decided, to have the applicant arrested? Was there any reason for not doing any kind of these investigation activities, appointing him a lawyer or something like that? Was there any reason for this lack of activity by the police?
text.357: Thank you. My first question concerns the government. The Bulgarian legislation provides and provided already in 1999 the assistance of a lawyer from the moment of the arrest of a suspect. text.362: Thank you, Mr. President. I have also a number of questions. I think some of them are similar to what my colleague has just asked.
