text.383: Thank you, Madam President. I have one question for the applicants and two more technical questions for the government. The applicant has been arguing in both their submissions in writing and today that we should use the reasonable suspicion standard as a basis for allowing bulk interception. Reasonable suspicion, however, is intrinsically linked to the concept of a crime. Bulk interception, on the other hand, is also a tool for intelligence gathering that implies more general national security risks. How does the applicant suggest that we use reasonable suspicion in this foreign intelligence context? And how would that differ from the standard applied by the government at present, which is necessary and proportionate for avoiding national security risks? My questions to the government. We understand from the government submissions that the Secretary of State warrant does indicate the content that has to be intercepted. The applicant has, in their pleadings, claimed that the warrant of the Secretary of State, however, does not specify the bearer to be intercepted. Would you agree with that description? Is it correct? And if yes, what is the process of selecting the individual bearers for interception? And my second question to the government is related to the intelligence sharing. Do I understand correct that as the warrant of the Secretary of State does not specify individuals, whenever a request is made that uses strong selectors indicating an individual, that would be included in a certificate that is being issued? Thank you.
text.384: Thank you. I have two questions for the government, but the applicant may feel free to comment as well. The first relates to the data retention periods. Now, we've heard today, and I think from the submissions as well, there's conflicting claims. The applicant, the counsel for the applicants said today that the agencies, they keep old data for up to two years. I think Mr. Eadie referred to several months, and the submissions talk about exceptions. So they talk about several weeks in some cases, several months, up to two years, but in all instances, there seem to be exceptions that would allow for even longer retention periods. So this is the first part of the question, and the second part is not so much as a matter of law, what the law allows, but as a matter of practice and the scope of this retention. Do UK agencies retain for considerable periods, by which I mean more than a few days or a few weeks, communications pertaining at any given time to large numbers of individuals, by which I mean in the scale of millions? So communications held of large numbers of individuals for considerable amounts of time, what is the scale, and by communications, I mean both content and communications data or metadata, and if you could factor into that response the intelligence received through sharing by third parties. And I'd appreciate if you're not in a position today to provide a response if you'd be willing to provide that in writing to the court. My second question is, as a matter of convention law, how in the view of the government is bulk surveillance involving the use of strong selectors, such as an individual's known or suspected email address or telephone number, how is that different as a matter of convention law from targeted surveillance of the same individual, let's say old-fashioned telephone tapping for purposes of reasonable suspicion, if the court found that to be applicable? I note here that your system applies both to foreign intelligence, but also to purposes of serious crime and also possibly prior judicial or some other prior form of authorization. Thank you.
text.385: I have some questions to the parties. Both parties can intervene. In Liberty, the court stated, and I'm quoting the court, that it does not consider that there is any ground to apply different principles concerning the accessibility and clarity of the rules governing the interception of individual communications on the one end and more general programs of surveillance on the other. This is Liberty, paragraph 63. My question to the government and to the parties is this one. Is the government proposing to depart from Liberty from this principle? In Zakharov and in Szábo, this principle was confirmed. In fact, in Szábo, in Zakharov, the criteria, the Weber criteria, were restated. And my question is, from the perspective of the government and, again, the applicants, do the Zakharov criteria, paragraph 231, apply to both surveillance? This is, for instance, the position of the French government in this case, as third party. My second question is related to the changes in the investigatory power set, 2016. What was the rationale behind the introduction of the ex ante judicial authorization in this act of 2016? Is there any reason not to trust the Secretary of State or to trust more the judges in terms of ex ante control of the proportionality of this interference? The third question relates to the legal status of the interception of communications commissioner. Is he not appointed and freely dismissed by the prime minister? Is this a part time job for the commissioner? Who provides for his staff, for the staff of the commissioner? The fourth question relates to the intelligence sharing. In the framework of intelligence sharing with non-council of Europe states, is there a legal obligation to check whether the foreign data recipient or data sender offers minimum safeguards equivalent to those of the convention? I note this, and this is a question that is related, of course, to the conclusion of the Intelligence and Security Committee of the Parliament, of Parliament, which has concluded in its 2016 report that there was a legal vacuum in this regard. So I would like you to comment on this. And final question, is there a legal obligation and final question, if this court, the European Court of Human Rights, sends a confidential message to a lawyer in London, can the respondent government guarantee that it would not be caught, our message from this court to a lawyer in London would not be caught and examined by the British intelligence? And this assuming that, of course, this message is strictly confidential. It's between the court and the lawyer in London. Thank you very much.
text.386: Thank you very much, Madam President. One, I have two or three questions. One is a question of clarification. Mr. Jaffey referred to the Human Rights Watch judgment of the IPT, which, as I understood him, is suggested to have tightened access to that tribunal. Can I just clarify whether he's referring to the 2016 Human Rights Watch judgment in which it was dealing with, I think, 660 applications? The second question related to that is, and it also relates to the question posed by my colleague, Judge De Gaetano, is, if I recall rightly, in that judgment, the tribunal was confronted with the question of whether applicants who were located outside the territorial jurisdiction of the United Kingdom were in fact within its jurisdiction for the purposes of its Human Rights Act jurisdiction. Now, I appreciate in this case, the government hasn't raised territorial jurisdiction. The chamber assumed it. But as we're in the Grand Chamber and we're invited to consider the scheme afresh, I wonder whether both parties could reflect on the question whether, in fact, our approach in the Bletchley judgment, where we said that the scope of the court's jurisdiction is determined by the convention and not by the party's submissions in a particular case, and the mere absence of a plea of incompatibility cannot extend jurisdiction, whether that means that, in fact, there is an issue here about jurisdiction which the court should concern itself with, whether, one, by way of admissibility, or two, and this reflects the question of my colleague, Judge De Gaetano, whether, in fact, the focus of our analysis needs to be in relation to those who are within the jurisdiction, and external communication insofar as it concerns those who are outside the jurisdiction is not within the scope of the case before us. And the third question, again, equally going to principle, is, of course, our case law so far has largely focused on the question of this issue, interception in the context of the right to respect for private life under Article 8, but, of course, a large number of the applicants are, in fact, corporate bodies, and I don't mean corporate in the commercial sense, but corporate in the non-natural person sense, and I would therefore ask both parties to reflect on the question whether, in fact, those applicants can have a right to respect for private life, and if they cannot, whether this falls, for example, under the heading of correspondence, and if so, whether the same tests apply. Thank you very much.
text.387: Thank you. Thank you, Mr. President. Let me first ask whether acting through the companies was ever considered seriously by the shareholders, and if so, why it was discarded. That would be my first question. My second question concerns the imperatives for the legislative reform that took place that has been described. Now, we have been informed of events taking place in Hungary and a national interest in the reform, but we have also had references to EU legislation making requirements on the legislation. Could you please elaborate upon the proportions of these two imperatives? To what extent was this defending a national interest? To what extent was it EU compliance? Thank you.
text.388: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions, one for the applicant and second for the government. The first question for applicant, in your application, you complained about the violation of your rights under Article 1, Protocol Number 1, as shareholders of “Kinizsi” Bank and “Mohácsi” Bank, but not as representatives of your banks. Is it correct? I'm asking it because formally, the decision to remain in the new scheme was the decision was made by the banks. And it is necessary to make distinction between the bank as a legal entity and shareholders of this bank. Second question to the government, you mentioned in your communication that the cooperative credit institutions had a choice to remain in the new scheme, new system, or to leave it, to exit the system. The applicant contested it because the exit was not realistic. And my question is, how realistic was the option of exit? And do you have information about the banks who did apply this right to exit from the new scheme? Thank you.
text.389: Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, I would like to ask the applicants to clarify their victim status, because they did not raise this issue. And the second question is to the government. The question is very simple. Whether the government apply the Basel principles of the prudential supervision. And if yes, and I think that the government surely apply this principle, because they're very recognized and known principles. Do these principles include the corporate control over the financial institutions? And if not, why the government choose to go further and to have this control in addition to these principles and requirements for the capital of the financial institutions? Thank you.
text.390: Thank you. I have a question for the applicant, but the government, of course, may feel welcome to comment as well. My question relates to one of your submissions with respect to when you discovered the possibility of the banks themselves as corporate entities bringing this case, you argued that they were under various forms of pressure and specifically that there was pressure exerted on them after their filing a petition with the Constitutional Court of Hungary. And so I'd be grateful if you could elaborate a little bit on that, on the specifics of what happened after the filing of the petition with the Constitutional Court. Thank you.
text.391: Thank you, Madam President. I have one question. It is addressed to the government, and it concerns the applicability of Article 4. The government is, in their observations, recognizing that human trafficking, as well as forced prostitution, fall under Article 4, and that in such cases, the state has positive and procedural obligations. That is how I understand the government's position. But then, in the specific case, the government is arguing that Article 4, in the specific circumstance of this case, is not applicable. And in doing so, the government is relying on the outcome of the criminal proceedings, saying that after the assessment of all the evidence, the domestic courts reached the conclusion that there was no exploitation, force, abuse. Therefore, Article 4 is not applicable. That seems to be the logic. But my question, then, to the government is, can the applicability of Article 4 depend upon the outcome of the domestic proceedings, or does it rather depend upon the allegations made by the applicant or the victim when he or she comes to domestic authorities? In other words, in the view of the government, if we were to rely upon the allegations or the complaint made by the applicant to the domestic authorities, would Article 4 then be applicable, or to put it in another word, would there at least be an arguable complaint that this would fall in within the ambit of Article 4? Thank you.
text.392: You have mentioned that in Croatia, 170 judges have gone through education. I'm interested whether you have the information whether the particular judges and particular prosecutors and policemen who were involved in this case went through education prior working on this case. Thank you.
text.393: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I want to ask one small question to the applicant and later another to the government. To the applicant, just to show or to demonstrate that there is a forced prostitution, because we know, as the government said, that prostitution itself is not prohibited. But we are talking about forced prostitution. Then in her observations, the applicant, she said that she did not want to take proactive actions because of the fear she felt. My question is, could you please explain in which manner she has received these threats from TM? And also, if she could offer proofs of it or not of these threats? And to the government, only a very concrete question, why during the process the national authorities not call more to more witnesses? Or for instance, the applicant has shown that there were other groups like whip-ons or condoms in the possession of TM. And why in the court, domestic courts, they don't use it as proof or evidences? That is my question. Thank you.
text.394: Thank you very much. In her application form, the applicant referred to the fact that she had been recognized as a victim of human trafficking. And during the course of proceedings, significance was attached to this recognition by the applicant in the chamber judgment and today by the applicant's representative. And I would like to ask both parties to address this issue, address it from a factual point of view, explaining to us the procedure which took place in Croatia and from a legal point of view. I'll start with the legal aspect. In paragraph 115 of J and others against Austria, the court said that it does not consider that the elements of the offense of human trafficking had been fulfilled merely because the Austrian authorities treated the applicants as potential victims of human trafficking. Such special treatment did not presuppose official confirmation that the offense had been established and was independent of the authorities' duty to investigate. Indeed potential victims need support even before the offense of human trafficking is formally established. Otherwise this would run counter to the purpose of victim protection. And of course, with a criminal trial pending, questions of presumption of innocence arise. So I would like both parties to address the significance that can or cannot be attached to recognition by an administrative authority of the status of human trafficking in this case. The factual aspect of my question relates to the case itself. As far as I understand, this victim status is recognized by the Minister of the Interior or by an operative team of the National Board for the Suppression of Human Trafficking. As far as the information that I have available, this is a multidisciplinary body. So it has representatives of the State Attorney's Office and the police, if I'm not mistaken, but please clarify that if possible. And on what basis does this body take its decision? At whose initiative? Is this on the basis of information passed by the police, the investigating authority, to the specialized body, or is it not? But we need some clarification on this question. And crucially in this case, I'd like you to address a temporal issue. The applicant brought her complaint in September. TM was questioned, the applicant was questioned, and the other key witness, MI, was questioned. The indictment was laid on the 6th of November, 2012. But the victim status was recognized only on the 21st of December. So are we looking at a situation here that the investigating authorities acted too quickly? Because they investigated her allegations brought to them in the police station, and they laid down the indictment before she was recognized as having this status of a potential victim of human trafficking? Or what actually is the significance of this recognition in a case such as this and in this particular case? And I'd like both parties to answer these questions.
text.395: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai une question au gouvernement belge. Dans le paragraphe 11 des observations du gouvernement, il est mentionné qu'en Belgique, le scrutin est encadré par une législation précise laquelle est conforme aux recommandations de la Commission du Venice. Et la référence, en ce sens, est faite au point 30.2 du code des bons conduites en matière électorale élaboré par cette commission. A cet égard, je voudrais connaître le point de vue du gouvernement concernant les exigences mentionnées au point 3.3 du même code, selon laquel l'instance de recours en matière électorale, je cite, doit être soit une commission électorale, soit un tribunal. Un recours devant le Parlement peut être prévu en dernière instance en ce qui concerne les élections du Parlement. Dans tous les cas, un recours devant un tribunal doit être possible en dernière instance. Vous pouvez trouver la référence à cette norme à la page 7 de l'avis de la Commission du Venice dans la ferme d'aujourd'hui. Merci.
text.396: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I want to thank both parties for invoking Montesquieu in their pleadings. It has created an unusual philosophical flair to this hearing. I'm not going to ask a question on Montesquieu, however. One question that I want to pose is basically an informative question about Belgian constitutional doctrine. To what extent is it understood that Parliament, either at the federal level or at the regional level, is itself entitled, when it decides on the procedures for the verification of credentials, to create an internal system which, for example, would require a supermajority of parliamentarians to decide, or even the inverse, that the commission, in this case the Commission on Verification, would itself have binding decision-making authority? So could Parliament itself internally delegate the decision on validation to a small group chosen in particular on the basis of certain formal criteria so as to minimize the risk of impartiality, excluding certain parliamentarians from certain constituencies which would be implicated by, or would that kind of internal procedure not be in conformity with the Constitution, with Article 48 or the special laws as they are now formed? I have a second question, if I may, to the applicants. The applicants' core argument, as I understand it is, Article 3 of Protocol 1 in principle excludes that Parliament itself validates credentials. There must be an external remedy. And I understood your argument, the core argument to be that this remedy should necessarily be judicial. You may correct me if I'm wrong. So I want you in that respect, and the government may also comment on this, none of the pleadings in this case bring forward an issue which I want to ask you about. Ever since 1997, this Court has said the right to stand for elections is a political right. Therefore a parliamentarian does not have a right to access a court under Article 6. There is a particular reason for that. May I ask you, is it then the argument of the applicants that although the Court has excluded judicial review under Article 6, which is the actual provision on right of access to court, that the Court can in any event interpret into Article 3 of Protocol 1 that same right to access a court or have access to a court, to invoke the same political right, which the Court has considered not to allow or permit or access courts under Article 6? Could I ask you just to comment a bit on this interplay and how you see that playing out in a case like this? Thank you very much.
text.397: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. Je remercie beaucoup les deux parties pour leur intervention. J'ai une question récurrente, mais le gouvernement aussi peut commenter. J'ai deux ou trois questions, en fait. La première question vise le moment où vous étiez choisi en tant qu'avocat par les partis devant la haute cour de cassation et justice. En ce moment-là, comme vous le dites vous-même, vous savez que vous n'avez pas le certificat ORNISS . Comme vous le dites vous-même, vous pensez que demander un certificat ORNISS  sera compliqué, ça va déterminer des ajournements, même si le gouvernement a déposé des arrêts où la cour a donné cet ajournement. Mais en même temps, vous savez qu'il y a des avocats qui ont le certificat ORNISS. Parce que même si ces avocats ne sont pas listés pour des considérations que le baron aussi encourage de manière sur Internet ou sur d'autres sources, vous connaissez vous-même en tant qu'avocat, ou vous pouvez demander en tant qu'avocat, qui sont les avocats avec le certificat ORNISS. Et ma question était la suivante. Pourquoi est-ce qu'au moment où vous vous étiez nommé et que vous étiez conscient que vous n'aviez pas accès aux informations vu que vous n'avez pas le certificat ORNISS, vous n'avez pas demandé un ajournement pour demander à un collègue qui a un certificat ORNISS de se présenter dans ce cas et d'avoir accès à ces informations? Deuxième question que je vais mettre. Votre collègue, maître Dumitru, a fait référence à un certain moment à une tendance claire. Elle dit une tendance claire dans les normes européennes. Et ma question, elle est un peu plus générale parce que parfois on utilise tendance claire, parfois on parle de consensus européen. Qu'est-ce que vous pensez de cet équilibre qui est requis par l'article 1, par le paragraphe 7, au moment 2012 au niveau des normes européennes, ce qu'on appelle, nous, le consensus européen? Quelles étaient les demandes qui, à ce moment-là, on faisait au gouvernement et où est-ce que le gouvernement et les instances se trouvaient de point de vue du garantie qui sont requises, comme vous dites, dans l'article 1, par le paragraphe 7? Et ça, c'est aussi une question que j'adresse au gouvernement. Une troisième question vise le rapport que vous avez ici invoqué entre l'article 11 et l'article 20 de la Constitution en disant que, finalement, les instances internes n'ont pas respecté l'article 20 de la Constitution. Est-ce qu'il y avait un précédent dans la Cour qui pouvait être invoqué à ce moment-là? Comment est-ce que vous appréciez, et ça c'est aux deux parties, le cas Regner par rapport à ce cas? Merci, Monsieur le Président.
text.398: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai 2 questions. Mon 1re question est directée au gouvernement. Juste pour avoir une certaine clarité en ce qui concerne les faits. Je comprends le dossier d'une façon suivante. Alors, on a cette communiquée de presse qui a été publiée le 6 décembre 2012. Devant la haute cour de cassation, est-ce que cette communiquée de presse a été ajoutée formellement par le procureur? Ca veut dire que ça a été ajouté comme un document formel devant la procédure de la haute cour de cassation. Et j'invite les Mme Les maîres aussi de donner une réponse, si vous avez une réponse. Ma 2e question est liée... Ou le 1er est directée aux Mmes et les maîtres. Est-ce que vous pensez que les éléments contenus dans la communiquée de presse, si on imagine que l'information factuelle dans la communiquée de presse a été initialement dans le document de procureur soumis à la cour d'appel, est-ce que vous pensez que ça a été suffisantes?
text.399: Thank you, Mr. President. Well, first, I have some questions for the government and later for the applicants. Then, related to the government, my question is related to the facts and proofs. Did the Court of Appeal provide the applicants with sufficient factual information of the accusations against them, or what minimum information? Or the only information they have is through this communique of press? My question is very concrete. Then, going to the proofs in order to have a guarantee in the process, what kind of proof, maybe even if they are top secret or confidential, but are there some proofs about that the applicants, the two applicants supported a fundamental Islamic group linked to an ideologically Al-Qaeda group? And now, my questions for the lawyers of the applicants. They are also related to facts related to the curriculum, I would say, or the profile of the two applicants. We have received the information that now the first applicant, Mr. Adeel Muhammad, is now living in Dubai in United Arab Emirates. I want to know if it is like that. And if it is possible to know what he's now doing, studying, or they are working, or why he has not come back to Pakistan, well, if it is possible to have some information. And also, in relation with the two applicants, well, we know in the file that there were two of them in Romania with a student's visa, the Erasmus Mundus with an Erasmus Mundus scholarship. Then, I don't know if it is possible to know, but I see that they have met in their university in Romania. But I don't know if they know each other before or not, if we have this data. Only that. Thank you very much.
text.400: Merci beaucoup, Monsieur le Président. Sur une question au gouvernement qui est liée à la question de mon collègue, juge Spano, et qui concerne le communiqué de presse. On comprend qu'il n'y avait plus d'informations données au public général qu'aux recoeurants pendant la procédure. Et je m'intéresserais de savoir pourquoi. Est-ce que c'était intentionnel ou non? Est-ce qu'il y avait une certaine coordination entre le service de presse et le parquet? Et ma deuxième question, c'est comment se déroule-t-il un procès s'il y a un avocat qui a un certificat ORNISS? Alors, est-ce qu'un tel avocat peut plaider librement, basé sur les informations qu'il aurait dans ces circonstances? Et à ce moment, est-ce que les recoeurants seraient exclus? Est-ce que ce serait un procès à huis clos? Merci beaucoup.
text.401: Thank you, President. My first question is a kind of continuation of the question by my colleague Judge Motac because it appears that the parties disagree on interpretation of legislation. The government in their presentation mentioned a recent case before High Court of Justice where the hearing were adjourned, as you said, twice in order to allow a lawyer to obtain ORNISS certificate. At the same time, Article 86 of Emergency Ordinance 194 of 2002 is very clear. The High Court gives a decision within five days from the date when the appeal is deposited. And that is something the applicants argued because apparently to obtain the ORNISS certificate at least 30 days are necessary, if I understand correctly. So my question is, can still the High Court circumvent the strict term of five days provided for in Article 86? And my second very exact factual question is to the applicants. At which exact moment the applicants were explained their defense rights, including a necessity to have a lawyer with ORNISS certificate? Thank you.
text.402: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions for the government. There are certain elements in our file that indicate that in support of his application, the prosecutor filed documents, in plural, describing relevant activities of the applicants. However, according to some other information in our file, the prosecutor filed one single document, unécrit, in this respect. So I would kindly ask you to clarify on this particular point. My second question is connected, to a certain extent, to my first question, namely whether in addition to or apart from describing activities of the applicants, alleged activities of the applicants, the document or the documents contained anything else apart from the description of their activities. Thank you.
text.403: Thank you. I would like to pose two questions to the government primarily. The first one relates also to the press release which was already raised by my colleagues. I would like to know on what basis it was lawful or considered lawful and justified to provide more details to the general public than to the applicants. And the second question has to do with the time frame of the proceedings. I understand that the request from the SRE was filed on the 4th of December. The prosecutor's application to the Court of Appeal was made the same day and the applicants were summoned in the evening of that day to appear at a hearing the following morning and the judgment was given that same day. So the time frame was very accelerated it seems. Is this usual practice or was it because of reasons related to this case? So why this accelerated time frame?
text.404: Merci beaucoup, Monsieur le Président. Donc, j'ai une question à poser au récurrent. Vous avez dit que finalement, ces avocats qui ont le certificat hors Nice ne sont pas sur une liste publique à cause de la concurrence. Ça, on le connaît bien. Mais est-ce que vous avez des preuves éventuellement écrites que vous avez demandé au barreau qu'il vous… que vous avez une aide de la part d'un avocat avec un certificat hors Nice? Ça, c'est ma question. Parce que ça, on arrive un peu à une conclusion ad absurde. Ça veut dire que ces avocats qui ont le certificat hors Nice, ils ne sont pas connus publiquement à cause de leur liste, mais aussi, ils ne peuvent pas être connus par des gens qui adressent le bureau, le barreau des avocats. Donc, à ma connaissance, le barreau des avocats, il a le devoir de communiquer le nom de ces personnes. Sinon, ça veut dire que ces avocats ne trouvent pas aucune place dans la société. Ça, c'est ma première question. Si vous avez quelque chose d'écrit que le barreau vous a refusé dans ce respect. Deuxième question, dans ce qui est une question de suivi à ce que mes collègues le juge Spano et la juge Nussberger avaient mis. Devant la haute cour de justice et de cassation, le office rouman pour immigration, il a demandé que votre question soit rejetée vu qu'ils ont précisé cette question. Le litige porte à l'objet la saisine faite par la cour d'appel de Bucarest et que rélevant sont les inscrits et pas ce qui est ressorti du communiqué de presse du service rouman de l'information. Et ça, c'est à mon avis ce que c'est retenu. Si vous pensez que finalement, ça c'était ce que c'est retenu dans la décision de la haute cour de cassation et que finalement, la base était les informations secrètes et pas ce qui est ressorti du communiqué de presse. Troisième chose, vous avez affirmé que le service rouman de l'information procède par ses communiqués de presse à plusieurs reprises, mais moi, je n'ai pas vu au dossier les preuves dans ce sens. J'ai vu seulement des décisions des hautes cours qui vont dans notre direction, mais je ne connais pas d'après les preuves que vous avez mises à dossier une pratique constante du service d'information rouman dans ce sens. Merci beaucoup.
text.405: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. J'ai deux questions adressées aux deux partis et qui se focalisent notamment sur l'article 7 de la Convention. En ce qui intéresse, la première, la voilà. Le fait que l'article 223 du Code de procédure pénale ne prévoit aucune limite à l'amende imposée, peut-il poser un problème au titre du principe fondamental de l'état de droit, notamment celui de la séparation des pouvoirs? Et en ce qui concerne la deuxième question, c'est la suivante. En matière purement pénale, est-ce que les peines, qu'il s'agisse de prison ou d'amende, sont-elles fixées clairement dans la loi islandaise au titre de la jurisprudence de la Grande Chambre établie dans Del Río Prada? Je vous remercie, Monsieur le Président.
text.406: Thank you very much. I would just have a question concerning the foreseeability of the sanction. And I wanted to know, is this fine or what is fine fix in relation to the potential gain of the lawyers in the case or in relation to the real gain? Or in relation to other factors? I understand that you mentioned also the complexity of the case or perhaps also the potential damages caused by the delay. In which relation was the sanction fixed? Thank you.
text.407: Thank you. I have a question for the applicant with respect to the third angle criterion. Now, if I understood correctly, your submission today was that in terms of the severity of the fine, the fact that it is unlimited in theory is sufficient to bring the criminal limbo of Article VI into play. And my question there is that our case law tends to judge the severity of a sanction based on the actual fine, not the theoretical possibility of a fine. And secondly, if you could address the government's submission that in at least some similar cases, with respect to the actual fine applied in this case, the court has found that even higher amounts do not necessarily or automatically trigger the criminal limbo of Article VI. Thank you. And of course, the government, if they wish to comment, might do so.
text.408: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a follow-up question to the question which were already posed by the colleagues Pastor Vilanova and Nußberger. It concerns Article 7. One of the complaints by the applicants was that the amount of the fine imposed had not been foreseeable, as no maximum amount was stipulated in domestic law, moderate and statute law, or case law. As you know, in many European countries, maximum penalties are set in law as a guarantee against arbitrary punishment. And making it foreseeable that punishment will never exceed that maximum. text.409: I have a question on Article 6 first. On Article 6, I have a question whether under the domestic criminal procedure, there are any regulations that are defining trial in absentia. text.412: Thank you very much, Madam President. text.413: Thank you. I have one question. Could you explain what is, pressure for the government, what is external communication for the purposes of collection of intelligence data? text.414: Thank you. Basically, I'm posing some of the questions that I raised this morning to both parties. text.415: Thank you so much, Mr. President. I have just three questions. First of all, I'm coming back on a subject touched in the hearing, just to resume definitively. text.417: Thank you, President. I'm interested in the status of parliamentarians in Turkey. And so let me just quote Article 83, Paragraph 1 of the Constitution. text.418: Thank you very much, Mr. President. Just one quick follow-up question, in a sense, to the questions asked by my colleague, Judge Nußberger. text.419: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions, one for applicants and one for government. text.420: Merci, M. le Président. Je voudrais revenir un instant sur les questions qui ont été posées par Mme la juge Nußberger et par M. le juge Eicke. text.421: I just would like to follow up to the question of Judge Eicke, who asked to explain how the terrorist organization is understood, and this is actually a follow-up to what we have heard by the Commissioner. text.422: Yes, thank you very much. text.424: Merci, Mme la Présidente. Mes premières questions concernent l'épuisement des voies de recours internes et s'adressent au recoeurant. Ces questions s'adressent aux deux parties. Et concernant les circonstances de l'espèce, existent-il des raisons de penser que le recoeurant est soupçonné par les autorités algériennes d'infractions liées au terrorisme en Algérie? Et existent-il des raisons de penser, des indices que le requérant est actuellement recherché hors procédure judiciaire par des services de sécurité, notamment par le DSS, la Direction des services de sécurité? text.425: Merci beaucoup, Madame la Présidente. J'ai plusieurs questions sur la récivilité et aussi sur le fond. Les deux premières questions, ce sont pour le gouvernement, à l'égard de l'épuisement. Le gouvernement défendeur soutient-il qu'une demande d'asile, dans un cas comme celui-ci, c'est-à-dire où une ITF est suivie plusieurs années plus tard par un arrêté fixant le pays de destination, est la seule voie de recours effective ou s'agit-il d'une voie effective parmi d'autres? Dans ce même contexte, une deuxième question pour le gouvernement, est-ce que cette répartition de compétences qu'on voit dans ce dossier entre le juge judiciaire qui impose l'ITF mais ne peut pas l'examiner à l'aune de l'article 3 de la Convention et le juge administratif qui peut entamer un tel examen, mais seulement lorsqu'une décision administrative fixant le pays de renvoi est prise, est-ce que cette répartition de compétences ne crée pas un vrai imbroglio? Et, sauf erreur de ma part, le Conseil d'État aurait pu également statuer avant son renvoi programmé en Algérie. J'ai deux questions sur le fond. Les deux parties sont invitées à répondre. Je reprends un point soulévé par le gouvernement défendeur d'abord. Le juge de référer liberté, l'OFPRA, la Cour nationale du droit d'asile, le tribunal administratif de Lille ont tous statué dans le même sens, à savoir en refusant les recours du requérant en l'absence du risque allégué par lui. Alors, ma question est très simple. Pourquoi la Cour devrait-elle aujourd'hui statuer autrement compte tenu des principes établis dans sa jurisprudence? Et je cite entre autres l'arrêt Saadi, l'arrêt Géquet contre Suède, voire même l'arrêt Douadie contre France. Et j'invite les deux parties à prendre position sur le fait qu'à la différence de la présente affaire, dans l'affaire Douadie contre France, la CN2A, sauf erreur de ma part, a bien constaté l'existence du risque allégué par le récréant. Dernière question. Compte tenu de la puissance des moteurs de recherche comme Google aujourd'hui, quelle est la valeur lors de l'appréciation globale entamée par la Cour du critère relatif à la médiatisation de la situation du récréant dont vous avez tous les deux parlé? Je vous remercie.
text.426: Merci, Madame la Présidente. Merci aux partis qui nous ont donné, par l'intermédiaire de leurs représentants, des explications particulièrement riches et intéressantes qui nourriront notre délibéré. Permettez-moi de réagir de façon assez spontanée à certains des débats qui se sont exprimés devant nous. Tout d'abord, s'agissant de la recevabilité, je dois dire que j'ai été un peu surpris par les termes utilisés par le représentant du requérant qui qualifiait le recours à la demande d'asile d'une conception théorique d'un recours. Est-ce qu'on ne pourrait pas dire au contraire que, théoriquement, ce n'est pas fait pour ça, mais qu'au fond, pratiquement, cela sert le plus souvent à cela d'abord? Et notamment, est-ce qu'on peut considérer qu'il est purement théorique de soumettre son cas à l'OFPRA alors qu'on sait, comme l'a rappelé le gouvernement, que l'OFPRA examine notamment le risque de violation de l'article 3 en cas de renvoi et que s'il constate, comme c'est le cas assez souvent, que ce risque existe, même s'il ne peut accorder l'asile, le mécanisme ou l'énoncé de l'article L5132 du CEDESA empêche le renvoi de cet étranger? Je respecterais beaucoup ce sens de la cohérence, mais je ne suis pas sûr que lorsque l'on craint d'être menacé de torture, le pragmatisme ne l'emporte pas sur ce souci de cohérence. Enfin, je ne comprends pas très bien pourquoi en détention, il serait beaucoup plus difficile de demander l'asile que de saisir la cour d'une demande de mesures provisoires fondée sur l'article 39 de son règlement. Lorsque l'on a un avocat averti, ne peut-il pas, dans l'un et l'autre cas, fournir les informations et l'aide nécessaires pour présenter ces deux types de voies de droit? Donc, comme vous l'avez compris, cette question s'adressait essentiellement aux représentants du requérant. Je me tourne cette fois-ci vers le gouvernement. Cette question des garanties diplomatiques a été très présente dans vos exposés l'un et l'autre, aussi bien pour le gouvernement que pour le requérant. Nous comprenons que, malgré ces efforts, le gouvernement français n'a pas réussi à obtenir de telles garanties du gouvernement algérien. Ça me conduit à deux interrogations que je vous livre. Première interrogation, au fond, pourquoi? Qu'est-ce qui s'oppose à cela, quand on y réfléchit? J'entends bien, et ça fait partie de la position de chacun, que les représentants du requérant sous-entendent. S'il n'y a pas de garantie, c'est parce que la réalité de la situation ne permettrait pas de les donner, car la lutte contre le terrorisme, contre la torture, pardon, ne serait pas suffisamment réelle, crédible. Mais, au fond, qu'est-ce qui s'y oppose? Je sais bien qu'il est délicat en matière de diplomatie, de discerner les ressorts des décisions ou des refus, mais néanmoins, il pourrait être éclairant pour la Cour de le comprendre. Deuxième question, si des engagements, des garanties diplomatiques formelles, avec tout ce que cela représente, sont difficiles, est-ce qu'il est envisageable, comme la Cour a pu le constater dans d'autres dossiers, que des engagements ou des accords interviennent à des niveaux moins élevés que les niveaux ministériels, dans des formes moins solennelles, mais dont la portée pourrait être aussi concrète et réelle que les engagements diplomatiques? Est-ce envisageable? Voilà ma seconde question et je vous remercie.
text.427: Merci beaucoup, Madame la Présidente. Il ne s'agit pas du tout de relancer le débat de façon interminable, mais simplement de revenir sur un point très concret que vous venez d'évoquer. text.428: Comme M. le juge Potocki, je ne voudrais pas rendre le débat interminable, mais je voudrais creuser un point avec le gouvernement français, qui a clarifié cette question. Effectivement, la demande d'asile constitue dans ce type d'affaires la seule voie de recours effective. Et vous vous fondez sur l'arrêt MX contre France, qui est bien sûr devenu M.A. contre France. text.429: Merci, monsieur le président. J'ai 2 petites questions que vous avez éclairées, mais pas complètement pendant votre plaidoirie. Alors, tout d'abord, à l'égard des personnes qui avaient été internées lorsque la loi de défense sociale de 1930 était en vigueur, les requérants ont indiqué, et il me semble que ça n'a pas été contesté par le gouvernement, que la CDS de Gand a adopté une approche différente de celle de la CDS d'Anvers. text.456: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to ask a question relating to Article 14, and it is a little bit prompted by what Mr. Chablais said at the end. Assuming that there are here comparable situations, assuming that there is a legitimate aim for the difference in treatment, the question arises whether the means to create this difference in treatment are relevant for the aims pursued. Mr. Braad said that the reasons for the 2015 amendments were, on the one hand, to offer protection as long as needed, and on the other hand, to ensure that the return is possible when there is no longer a need for protection. So then my question comes, to what extent is this specific difference in treatment based on the waiting period for the right to family reunification? To what extent is it relevant for the aims pursued? Thank you.
text.457: Thank you, Mr. President. I have one question, and it is directed to the government, and it concerns the choice for the duration of the waiting period. I understand the pleadings of the applicant to be that the applicant is not, as such, calling into question the legitimacy of introducing a waiting period. And in his observations, a waiting period of one year would have been reasonable, but he's challenging the three-year waiting period. My question is, when it was introduced in 2015, it was one year. When it was amended in 2016, it became three years. I assume that the government has been must have reflected on whether it should be one year, two years, three years, or four years. And therefore, my question is, why did the government opt for three years? One year would have been the recommendation of the Commissioner of Human Rights. Two years would have been the EU Family Reunification Directive from 2003. Three years seems to be the legislation in Sweden and other places. But could you shed some light on why the government opted for three years, or to ask in a more direct way, was it to have as long a period as possible, which was still compatible with international obligations? Thank you.
text.458: Thank you very much. Just two questions. I don't know whether I understood properly, but now apparently there is the law that applies three years to all the groups. So could you explain what was the reason to extend to all the groups? And the second question, am I wrong? I don't know. Maybe I'm wrong. And then the second question is, we heard today a couple of times that different groups are affected differently. I would be interested whether you have data whether such legislation affects women comparatively much more than men. Thank you very much.
text.459: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. J'ai trois questions à poser aux partis, une au gouvernement, une au requérant et, finalement, une troisième commune aux deux partis. La première, donc, est dirigée au gouvernement. Combien d'affaires similaires à celles du requérant sont actuellement pendantes devant les juridictions islandaises? Je vous demande un chiffre approximatif, bien entendu. Une question, donc, dirigée au requérant. Devant les juridictions nationales, le requérant a demandé à être rejugé. Il me semble que cette prétention n'a pas été formulée devant la Chambre. Par conséquent, je voudrais savoir si le requérant demande à la Grande Chambre à être rejugé en Islande, en plus, bien entendu, de la réparation pécuniaire de 5 000 euros qu'il formule au titre de l'article 41 de la Convention. Et enfin, une dernière question commune aux deux partis. À l'époque des faits de l'espèce, quels étaient les liens entre la ministre de la Justice, Mme Andersen, la police et les procureurs? Je vous remercie, M. le Président.
text.460: Thank you, President. I have three questions. One for the applicant, one for the government, and the third one for both parties. Now, the applicant accuses the Minister of Justice of this most abject, backstage, horse-trading deal between members of the same party. There would have been a deal between the former Minister of Justice and candidate BN to Reykjavik, according to which Judge AE, who is the wife of BN, would go to the Court of Appeal if BN would step down in favor of the Minister. So there is, in your view, clear quid pro quo, a deal, and personal political gain of the former Minister of Justice. And you even said that there is bad faith bordering intent. My question is, was there any criminal investigation or prosecution launched against the former Minister of Justice on this basis, alleged abuse of power or corruption? You have mentioned the deficiencies of the Supreme Court's oversight over this entire procedure. You have pointed out the fact that the Supreme Court did not address this argument in its judgment of May 2018. The Supreme Court said there was no nullity, no major defect in the appointment procedure, confirming its judgment of December 2017. My question is the following. Is it your view that the Supreme Court should have annulled the Minister's decision in its judgment of December 2017? I would like to recall the passage of the Supreme Court's decision with regard to the request of annulment of the Minister's decision. The Supreme Court said the following, and I'm quoting the Supreme Court, it is not in the power of the courts to decide who should be appointed to the office of judge of the Court of Appeal. Bearing this in mind and having received the appellant's explanation as to the nature of their claim, which will serve as a basis here, the appellants have not demonstrated that they have a lawful interest in obtaining a court ruling on the invalidity of decisions by the Minister of Justice. This is the decision of the Supreme Court upholding the district court's judgments insofar as they concern the request of annulment of the Minister's decision. Is it your position that this is wrong in law and the Supreme Court did not exercise full jurisdiction over the Minister's decision and should have done so? With regard to the government, after the delivery of the chamber judgment, the Minister of Justice resigned from office. Why so? If the judgment of the chamber is wrong, there is no reason to resign. The only reason to resign is if the judgment of the chamber is right. But then the question might be raised, why is the government appealing the decision of the chamber if it is right? Final question addressed to both parties. In the criminal proceedings against the applicant, the Court of Appeal rejected the applicant's motion for AE to withdraw from his case. But it decided so with the participation of AE. AE intervened in the judgment itself where the impartiality was at stake. Would you comment on this? Thank you very much.
text.461: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a legal question to both parties. It's true that during their pleadings they touched upon it indirectly, but I think for the sake of clarity I will ask it again. Do you think that the requirements for a fair hearing, establishment by law, independence, and impartiality are self-standing requirements or if they are interrelated? And if interrelated, is there a hierarchy between them? Thank you.
text.462: Thank you, Mr. President. I do have one question, which at the same time is addressed to both parties. And the question is concerned the link between a possible finding of a violation of Article VI established by law and the possible consequences to be drawn from such a finding, meaning the link between Article VI and Article 46 of the convention. The applicant is arguing that there has been a violation of Article VI and that there has to be a reopening. The government, on the other hand, is arguing there has been no violation of Article VI and obviously no need to reopen. My question is more in general. To what extent, and could the parties elaborate on, to what extent will a finding of a violation of Article VI necessitate a reopening or whether it would necessitate the court to indicate reopening? Or in other words, which kinds of violations of Article VI would necessitate the reopening? Is the threshold under Article VI, the threshold for finding a violation of Article VI established by law, is it necessarily the same threshold which the court should apply under Article 46 when deciding whether or not to indicate as an individual measure the reopening of the procedures? So if both parties could clarify their view on that question. Thank you.
text.463: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have three questions. I'd like to follow up and repeat the question asked by my colleague, Judge Ravarani, concerning the interrelationship in Article 6.1 fair trial assessments by this court of the criteria related to establishment by law, independence, and impartiality. And I repeat the question not for the sake of it, but rather to leave both parties in no doubt that the bench wants an answer to this question. My second question is also addressed to both parties, but particularly to the applicant. Both parties have examined in detail and in general terms questions relating to the irregularities recognized by the Icelandic Supreme Court in the appointment of court of appeal judges. But I'd like to ask both parties to return their focus to the applicant's individual case. The respondent government addressed this in their submissions, but in my view, the applicant could address it a little bit more. According to the constant case law of this court, our primary concern in examining an Article 6.1 complaint is, and I quote, to evaluate the overall fairness of the applicant's criminal proceedings. So could both parties please tell us or repeat how the criminal proceedings involving the applicant heard at district court level, at which stage the applicant pleaded guilty, heard on appeal by the court of appeal, and then again at Supreme Court level. In what way were these proceedings unfair due to the irregular appointment of four out of 15 court of appeal judges? And of course, here I'm asking you not just to address questions as of consequence, but rather questions of cause and effect. And my third question is a follow-on question from Judge Pinto de Albuquerque, and I apologize to him in advance if I've misunderstood his question, and I apologize in particular to both parties if I misunderstand Icelandic law, but I'm not an Icelandic judge. And the question relates to Judge Pinto de Albuquerque's question about the Supreme Court's jurisdiction to annul the ministerial decision. Now, what I haven't understood is whether he is referring to the Supreme Court decisions in the damages cases brought by the candidates whose names had been removed from the list, or to the Supreme Court judgment in the applicant's case. But in either or both cases under Icelandic law, did the Supreme Court have any jurisdiction whatsoever in the context of those proceedings to annul the ministerial decision? And particularly, did the Supreme Court have jurisdiction to act in that way in the context of the applicant's case, which was, of course, an appeal from the Court of Appeal and on from the District Court concerning the commission of traffic offenses driving under the influence of narcotics and without a license? Thank you very much.
text.464: Thank you, Mr. President. I have some factual questions, first of all, to the representatives of the government, but I invite also the representative of the applicant to comment if he wishes so. My first question refers to the 15 candidates on their lists as amended by the minister, as exchanged by the minister. We see that in that list, we had candidates number 7, 11, 12, and 14 removed and replaced by candidates numbers 17, 18, 23, and the 30th. I would like to understand the criteria. Why these numbers? Why wasn't it the 12, the 13, the 14, and the 15, and then the 16, 17, and so on? Was there any logic in that, especially in the light of, my question is in the light of the applicant's representative remark that a female judge, who was numbered 22, was not selected to the new composition, and she was not selected to the new composition. But a female judge, who was number 30, was selected. So was there any logic? Were there any objective criteria or justifiable criteria which the minister employed when changing the list of candidates? That's my one question. My other question relates to the statement of facts. And in the statement of facts, we have a letter of the chairman of the evaluation committee who provided that letter to the Minister of Justice on the 28th of May, 2017. That is one day before the amended or modified list of candidates was presented to the parliament on the eve of that presentation. And in that letter, the chairman of the committee, of the evaluation committee, objected to the changing of weightings and, by extension, to the recomposition of the group of candidates which was already in place. And I just quote that, according to the chairman, changing the weightings after the composition of the group of candidates for the benefit of particular candidates and to the disadvantage of others had to be avoided. I put emphasis on the word particular, benefit of particular candidates. Could you please shed some light on what was meant by the word particular candidates? The chairman of the committee used plural. What was meant by particular candidates? Or at least what the minister from that letter could understand or ought to have understood by the word particular? And my third question, also a factual question, will be very straightforward. And that was partly prompted by Judge Paulo Pinto de Albuquerque's question about this alleged swap of services or horse trading. He used the term horse trading. The chairman of the parliamentary committee giving his place on the party's constituency list to the minister just not long after the nomination of an appointment of his wife to that judicial position. My question would be very straightforward, maybe unusually straightforward. But could you please tell whether that was a coincidence, a lack of judgment, or a quid pro quo? Plainly, thank you.
text.465: Thank you very much. I would just like to expand a little bit on the question that was asked by Judge Kjølbro. And this is the relationship between Article 6 and finding a violation and the consequences. And not just the reopening, because it seems to me that we have something intermediary, and this is annulment of the judgment. So are you pleading for the automatic annulment of the judgment? Or there could be instances where automatic and under which conditions automatic annulment then would not be required. And what is then the consequence of that for the reopening? In other words, could reopening be mandated by the court? And or at the domestic level, could reopening be requested not only by the applicant, but by the government? Because in a case like this, the applicant might not have an incentive to ask for the reopening. At the domestic level, annulment of the judgment, how it is connected to "ne bis in idem", and how it is connected to statute of limitation. Would in this particular case statute of limitation be there if the judgment would be annulled? Thank you.
text.466: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. J'avais demandé au... Je me dirige au requérant. J'avais demandé au requérant expressément s'il souhaitait, en plus du dédommagement de l'article 41, s'il souhaitait la réouverture de son procès dans l'hypothèse, bien entendu, que la Cour conclue en violation de l'article 6. La réponse... On n'a pas besoin d'avoir une réponse écrite. C'est oui ou non. Et je crois que je suis suffisamment fondé pour vous exiger une réponse claire tout de suite à ce sujet-là. Merci.
text.467: Thank you, President. I have two questions concerning the incident of 14th December, 2013. And my first question goes to the applicant. In your submissions, you state that this alleged incident was related to questioning the applicant about two issues. First, death of Mr. Zhvania in 2005, and situation with bank accounts of Mr. Saakashvili. Why you consider that it was important for the authorities to obtain this information at that particular moment? And my second question is for the government, but the applicant might comment as well, in respect of the effectiveness of investigation into this incident of 14th December, 2013, to which extent the applicant himself was involved into this investigation. Thank you very much.
text.468: Merci, Monsieur le Président. Je voudrais poser une question au gouvernement et une autre question au requérant. Bien évidemment, chaque parti pourrait commenter sur ces questions. La question au gouvernement. Le requérant vient de nous dire que parmi les personnes détenues avec lui à la Facilité spéciale de Straubing, la majorité ne souffre pas de troubles mentaux. Le gouvernement, pour sa part, vient de dire que la grande majorité de ces personnes, la grande majorité, mais pas tous, souffre de différentes formes de troubles mentaux. Ma question est la suivante. Dans le système allemand, tel que modifié depuis 2011, la détention préventive est-elle associée uniquement avec l'existence de troubles mentaux ou bien elle peut être ordonnée également à l'égard de condamnés dangereux qui ne souffrent pas d'une maladie mentale? Ma deuxième question va au requérant. Elle concerne l'article 5, paragraphe 4 de la Convention. Vous vous plaignez notamment de la durée de la procédure devant la Cour constitutionnelle. Vous avez relevé aussi le rôle particulier de la Cour constitutionnelle allemande. Ma question est la suivante. Aviez-vous la possibilité d'obtenir un nouveau contrôle de l'ordonnance de placement d'étention devant les juridictions ordinaires alors même que la procédure antérieure était toujours pendante devant la Cour constitutionnelle? Merci Mr. le President.
text.469: Thank you very much, Mr. President. My questions are addressed to the government, but of course the applicant can comment on them. I would like the government to elaborate on the concept that is enshrined in the Therapy Detention Act, the "Therapie Unterbringungsgesetz", the concept of "psychische Störung", mental disorder. Does it extend to non-pathological disorders or any other social deviance behavior? Ultimately, who has the final saying with regard to these mental disorders? Is the judge competent or the psychologists or psychiatrists who has the final saying in characterizing this mental disorder? My second question regards the preventive detention itself foreseen by this Therapy Detention Act. Can you explain the nature of this measure in the light of the classic dualism between penalties and security measures in German law? If it is not a penalty, a "Strafe", is it a "Massregel der Besserung"? Is it a measure of prevention? Or not even a measure of criminal law? But then why is it applied on the basis of a criminal conviction of mentally ill, of mentally sane persons? And in this particular case, in our case, by a criminal chamber? It seems that the Therapy Detention Act foresaw the competence of civil chambers, not criminal chambers. That leads me to my third point, which refers to an issue raised by the government themselves. What is the difference between the internment in a psychiatric hospital under Article 63 of the "Strafgesetzbuch" and the internment in preventive detention centers under the "Therapie Unterbringungsgesetz"? The government used a word, a very peculiar word. It's approximate. The regimes are approximate. What does this mean in terms of the classic dualism between penalties and security measures in German law? Thank you very much.
text.470: Thank you, Mr. President. Can you hear me? Yes, now I'm on. I have a question to the government. The government said that it would be irresponsible to release this person. And I wonder if this implies that the applicant, if released or no longer detained under criminal law, could not be detained under the Bavarian legislation on the detention of dangerous persons of unsound mind where a criminal conviction is not a precondition. Thank you.
text.471: Merci beaucoup, Monsieur le requérant. Monsieur le Président, mes questions s'adressent au Récurrent, au gouvernement, et en même temps, ils visent le problème de l'âge très jeune, jeune du Récurrent au moment où il avait commis l'infraction. Donc, une partie importante de la défense du requérant se base sur cet âge très jeune. Le requérant nous avait dit que les experts n'étaient pas vraiment qualifiés pour faire des expertises sur les jeunes adultes ou sur les mineurs. Cette affirmation, maintenant, a été contredite par le gouvernement qui nous avait dit qu'en fait, ces experts avaient cette qualification, mais le gouvernement avait ajouté que, même si à l'époque où l'ordonnance de mise en attention a été formulée, le requérant n'était plus mineur. Donc, je voulais exactement savoir comment est-ce que le jeune âge du requérant, il a joué pendant cette expertise qui a été faite pendant l'ordonnance, et comment est-ce que cet âge jeune joue aussi par rapport à cette mesure préventive qui est appliquée. Merci beaucoup.
text.472: Thank you. I have questions to both parties about the psychiatric treatment. I see that both parties mentioned today that the applicant was subject to the psychological treatment. And this is what I see from the observation of the government and the government mentioned that today that there is a sociopedagogical group measures. However, according to the psychiatric standards, ICD-10, the European standards mentioned by the government in its observations, the treatment also should include some sort of psychopharmaceutical intervention, antipsychotics, antidepressants. So my question is whether there was such a treatment, whether the word therapy included this. This is because the observations of the parties are very controversial about what kind of treatment. So what kind of, whether the treatment was in compliance with the psychiatric standards. The sexual sadism is a very severe disorder. However, under the same standards, there is a scale of severity. Whether the scale of severity was diagnosed by the experts, so whether there is a necessity and requirement that the person with such a disorder should come through the special clinical tests. According to the case file and the observation of the parties, it appears that the diagnosis was taken in accordance with the interviews with the applicant. Just what he said without, or maybe with, this is what I would like to clarify, the point is to clarify whether there was a so-called differential analysis, differential test diagnosis provided for the applicant. I also have a question. Whether there is a requirement under German law that if the person, I mean the very first event when the applicant committed a crime. So the crime was committed, there was a murder, a very serious crime, which the punishment for which is lifelong punishment, which was recognized by the government. So it's a very serious crime, especially aggravated by the sexual act. So whether the psychiatric test, psychiatric examination of such a person is necessary, is obligatory from the very beginning. So it was not done and I have no information whether there is a requirement under German law. Thank you.
text.473: Oui, merci beaucoup, M. le Président. Et je voudrais juste demander, on comprend qu'après les observations des partis, les conditions matérielles dans ces centres de détention, de sûreté, sont évoluées. Est-ce qu'on peut dire la même chose? Peut-on constater la même amélioration dans le cadre des soins médicaux, d'une manière générale, par rapport, je dirais, aux soins qui peuvent être prodigés dans un hôpital psychiatrique normal, je dirais, ou civil? Et je veux aussi dire que, dans le cadre du requérant, est-ce qu'on peut dire que ce centre qui se trouve est adapté à ses besoins, c'est-à-dire un traitement pour le sadisme sexuel? Merci beaucoup.
text.474: Merci, monsieur le Président. Je voudrais poser une question qui, sous différents angles, a déjà été posée et elle s'adresse aux deux partis, mais aussi sous différents auspices. Pour le gouvernement, je ne sais pas s'il peut répondre, car la question devrait d'abord être posée aux tribunaux. Était-il envisageable et envisagé de faire juger la question de la détention du requérant après qu'il avait purgé sa peine par des tribunaux civils? Et pour le requérant, quels auraient été les avantages concrets, et j'insiste sur concrets, pour lui s'il avait été jugé par des tribunaux civils? Merci.
text.475: Thank you, Mr. President. I have four questions, some of which come with sub-questions. The first is one of factual clarification. In the respondent government submissions in paragraph 38, it is suggested that an appeal against decision 59 of the administrative court of Laura of the 28th of January 2014 is still pending before the Supreme Court. Can I just clarify, is my understanding right that in fact what is pending before the Supreme Court is only an appeal against the decision 269 of 2014 of the administrative court concerning the, and I quote, gross procedural violation, close quote, in the calculation of the compensation for the expropriation by the Council of Ministers? Secondly, is it right that the appeal against decision 59 of 2014, declaring that the actions carried out by the state in November 2013 were illegal, was finally determined by a judgment of the administrative court of appeal of May 2016? Or in the alternative, did the government appeal against that judgment? And if so, what is the status of that appeal? And if it is appealed, why was neither of these two appeals, i.e. that to the administrative court of appeal, nor that to a Supreme Court, if there is one, mentioned by the government in their submissions to this court? The second question is one of clarification in relation to Albanian law. And my question is this. Does the Albanian law or legislation provide for an effective measure, administrative or other, against the refusal by any party, including an administrative authority, to obey a court order? For example, akin to the concept of contempt of court proceedings available in common law jurisdictions. And if so, have any steps been taken against those responsible for noncompliance with the interim injunction first issued in November 2013? The third question relates to the events of the 3rd of November 2013, and is primarily directed at the government. The question is this. I understand that the purpose of the administrative action, as you call it in your pleadings of that day, was to check the regularity of the building permits. Now, is it normal practice, and if so, is it provided by law, that in order to check the regularity of a building permit, the building needs to be surrounded by crime scene tape, the administrative authority needs to be supported by police in order to carry out such a check? And if so, why would you say or would you say that that is proportionate in the circumstances of this case? And finally, again to the government, out of fairness, I probably have to ask you this. As you will know, Article 38 of the Convention and Articles 44A and 44C of the rules of court reflect some of the basic requirements for the conduct of a party before a court of law, including this court. These include the duty to cooperate fully in the conduct of the proceedings, the duty to adduce relevant evidence or information, not only when requested, but of its own motion, and the obligation on the member states to furnish all necessary facilities to enable this court to examine the case fully and properly. The rules of court make clear, at the very least, noncompliance with these requirements allows this court to draw such inferences as it deems inappropriate. Now, I noted in preparing for this hearing and during the oral submissions and the applicants positively assert that the government's submissions, in part, provided an incomplete picture of the factual circumstances of this case, and in particular, the domestic proceedings, and in part, so to say, were deliberately misleading, such as in relation to the outright denial, which you make in paragraphs 50 and 51 of your first written pleadings, that decision one of 2013 had, in fact, been appealed, and as we understand it, on a field being confirmed, only for the applicants to produce both the appeal filed, document 26, and the judgment of the Administrative Appeal Court of 2014 in relation to that appeal, document 28. The question is this. If this court were minded to consider whether the government has failed to comply with the obligations I identified at the beginning of this question, and whether, and if so, what inferences to draw from such noncompliance, what submissions not already made would you wish this court to take into account before drawing such inferences? Thank you very much.
text.476: Thank you, Mr. President. I have three questions to the government, and then, with your permission, one to the applicants' representatives. The first question, talking of the Supreme Court of Appeal, you assert that the applicants had access to the domestic courts and that their complaints were met, or at least examined, within reasonable time. How do you explain what appears to be a complete inactivity of the Supreme Court since its order suspending the execution of Judgment 269, 2014, of 15 January, 2015, more than two years ago? You assert the complexity of the issues and a necessity to call different experts. How can that justify complete inactivity for more than two years, where there is no even any evidence of the court having ordered, instructed any experts so far, and where it took the Administrative Court of Appeal seven months to consider and decide the appeal against Judgment 3916-2014, despite the fact that it concerned the same issue and also, at least potentially, required the calling of different experts? Second question, as I understand it, Article 142, paragraph 3 of the Albanian Constitution provides that, I quote, state organs must execute judicial decision, end of quote. Would it be correct, therefore, for me to start from the position that, as a matter of national law, an interim order is binding on all state institutions, including the Council of Ministers? You are asking us to conclude that an interim decision, 1 slash 2013, was taken, I quote, in open violation of the law and practice of the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Court, and turns out to be fictitious, end of quote. On what basis do you say this court, as an international court and compliant with the principle of subsidiarity, is competent to reach such a conclusion, essentially, of domestic law? In any event, did you raise this submission in the appeal against that decision to the Administrative Appeals Court or the Supreme Court? Is it right, as the applicants suggest, that the government's appeal against the interim measure was discontinued by the Administrative Appeals Court in its decision of 20 January 2014 because the subject matter of the dispute had become academic, but that that court expressly confirmed the competence of the First Instance Court to have made the interim order and indicated its view that the breach of that order was unlawful? Third question. Can a decision by the Council of Ministers, de facto, amend a court decision in the Albanian legal system? If not, could you explain what the legal impact of the Council of Ministers' decision of 9 April 2014 is on the merits of the lower Administrative Court decision of 6 March 2014, as far as the compensation amount is concerned? And the final question to the applicants. On the yellow tape, what is your case before this court today? Are you dropping Article 6.2 claim, and are you pleading the yellow tape issue only under Article 8? So, reputation limp, could you please elaborate on this point? Thank you.
text.477: Thank you. I would like to ask the government just to clarify in a more detailed manner which were the measures taken against the police official that surrounded the building with the yellow tape. It was already addressed but if you can add some more detail. Thank you.
text.478: Thank you. I would have two questions. The first one concerns the question of the transfer of ownership. The government has argued that the transfer of ownership of these properties took place immediately upon the... and by virtue of the Council of Ministers' decision on expropriation on the 27th of November 2013. My question is how does the government reconcile this assertion with the fact that, according to our record, the Council of Ministers' decision, 2015 on the 27th of November provided for the expropriation to be performed within 30 days of the entry into force of this decision by the Council of Ministers? And the second question concerns the movable property. As I understand it, there was a movable property belonging to the applicants which remained in the building and was also destroyed through the demolition. According to the statement of facts that we have, the expropriation order on the 27th of November by the Council of Ministers provided for expropriation of immovable property. So it does not seem that the expropriation decision by the Council of Ministers covered any movable property. So the question is, was there some other legal basis for the loss and destruction of the movable property that was situated in the building and that belonged to the applicants? Thank you.
text.479: Thank you, Mr. President. My question to government. So in terms of compensation, as I understand, it is not your case, but in any way, Supreme Court could reduce the compensation payment due to the applicants below the level fixed by Council of Ministers decision. Can you explain why even this level of compensation has not yet been paid to applicants? Thank you.
text.480: Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to ask the applicant the following. The court has invited the parties to reply to a question concerning to what extent the applicant had requested an oral hearing before the council and the Supreme Court. Now, we heard from the government's representative that such a request had been made only in one of the proceedings, the third one. So I would like to ask the applicant whether she confirms this information, that it was only in this one set of proceedings that a request for an oral hearing was made. The second question I would address to the government, we have here a situation where there was no oral hearing at any stage of the proceedings, not before the council and not before the chamber, the competent chamber of the Supreme Court. Is this the regular practice in disciplinary matters that are decided by the council and then decided on appeal at the Supreme Court? And how does the government comment on the applicability of such a situation with the requirements of Article VI?
text.481: Just two minor questions to clarify one point. Is it possible to convert fine into a prison term if fine is not paid, if the person is in default in paying the fine? Could it be turned into the prison? And then the effectiveness of remedies. Does the effective remedy exist at the domestic level to challenge independence and impartiality of the body as such, since the composition of the body is defined by the Constitution?
text.482: Just one question for better understanding and for information. Before the respective decisions were made, both before the High Council of the Judiciary and the Supreme Court, did the applicant know the composition of these bodies? If she knew them, could she then protest against the respective concrete composition? Thank you.
text.483: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai deux questions qui s'adressent avant tout aux requérants, mais peut-être le gouvernement souhaitera aussi répondre à ces questions.
