Elle peut aller au-delà du droit suisse substantiel et les tribunaux seraient compétents pour connaître le droit civil qui serait régi par le droit d'un autre État? Ou est-ce qu'entre les deux compétences, la compétence des tribunaux et la compétence de l'État pour régir les questions de droits matériels, il y a un lien? Est-ce que ces critères de lien entre l'État et les mêmes critères pour établir la compétence des tribunaux que pour établir la compétence pour régir les questions de fonds, pour édicter les droits matériels? Merci.
text.484: Thank you. I have three questions to the parties. First, the Italian aspect context was mentioned by the government. text.485: Thank you, Mr. President. I have only one question, which will be addressed to both parties. text.486: Merci, M. le Président. C'est une question qui s'adresse principalement au gouvernement. text.487: Thank you, President. I would have three questions. The applicant's lawyer said it would be higher. But I would like to know, would it be? Now it's one quarter. So what exactly would it be? How would it be calculated? My second question is about the role of the notary public. The applicant's lawyer said that there are many wills drafted in front of a notary public in this region. So I understand that the notary public is a legal expert. And my last question is, so we also have the two sisters in the whole family situation. So I understand these two sisters had a legitimate expectation to be heirs of their brother. text.488: Thank you very much, Mr. President. And I thank the parties for their observations. And also, the Article 43 of the Lausanne Treaty stresses the balance between the respect of minorities on the one hand and the order public on the other hand. And my question is related to the legal certainty in this case, and also to a certain extent to the legitimate expectations. At the same time, the government argues that the applicant should have known that in her case, the sharia law will apply. So my question is that the government stresses that there was never a reference made to the applicant's own religion in the reasonings of the judgments. However, if I read the judgments, the courts said that it is about succession relations between Muslims, and they have jurisdiction between Muslims, the muftis. So this is, for instance, said also at the Court of Appeal of Trusse, the second judgment after the Supreme Court judgment when the case came back to the appealed court in 2015. So the government says that the plan reformed is to strengthen the protection of the rights of the members of Muslim minority, and mostly women and children. But at the same time, the government says that it is not about the religion or the gender of the applicant. So Judge Nußberger has touched upon this, but if the applicant would have been a Greek national of other confession, let's say Greek Orthodox, would then the will of her Muslim husband still be invalid in this case? And also, if and to what point if the late husband would have explicitly withdrawn from the Muslim will, as the government also said, what does it actually mean? But that would have meant probably to have a gift, to give a gift to his wife or something else. But would have that otherwise also not been covered by the Muslim law if we were taking the jurisprudence of the court of cassation? So this is the question. As far as the second question is concerned, it is about the legitimate expectation. The legitimate expectation on the one hand of the applicant, and on the other hand of the sisters of the deceased husband, and the relation to what I have just asked as a first question concerning the legal certainty and the foreseeability, and concerning the fact that there seems to be not a problem concerning the interpretation of the treaties as such, but interpretation of the treaties by the jurisdictions, by the different jurisdictions. The applicant has in its observations in paragraph 27 said that the sisters had already inherited their parents, their deceased parents, according to the succession rules provided by the civil law. And my question is then about the legitimate expectations of the sisters, because they already had inherited in one case according to the civil law. And what would have been then their expectations, whether in this time it would have been civil law or sharia law that would have been applied? Thank you very much.
text.489: Thank you very much. My question perhaps overlaps to some extent some of the previous questions. I understand from the Court of Cassation's judgment that the Court of Cassation referred to the category of the property in question, that it was held in full ownership or the mulki type of property. So was this the reason why the will was declared invalid? Or was the reason, did it have to do with who was the beneficiary of the will? I think from the applicant's side, we heard that she lost the inheritance because she was a Muslim wife. So it is not entirely clear to me what was really the reason. Was it the type of property in question? Or was it the question, who was the beneficiary? What if the beneficiary had been someone else, a third person, not a family member at all? Would the will have been valid or invalid? Thank you.
text.490: Thank you very much. I have two questions relating to the prohibition of discrimination. The first question is addressed specifically to the government. The government have replied to the questions by the court in two ways. In the first place, they answered with respect to Article 6, taken alone or in combination with Article 14. And in the second place, they argued with respect to Article 1 of Protocol No. 1. And the conclusion of the government was that that article is not applicable. My question to the government is, can we assume that the arguments relating to Article 14, relating to Article 6, would also apply to Article 14 in combination with Article 1, Protocol No. 1, if that latter article would be applicable? And the second question is one to both parties. When we are dealing with discrimination issues, the case law of the court is that a treatment – a difference of treatment is discriminatory if it has no objective and reasonable justification. In other words, if it does not pursue a legitimate aim or if there is not a reasonable relationship of proportionality between the means employed and the aim sought to be realized. We have heard something about the legitimate aim, but not so much about the reasonable relationship of proportionality. Something has been said about it, but I would like to invite the parties to say more how they see this issue of proportionality. Thank you.
text.491: Just one, there have been many questions, so I want to pose one question, which is related to the question just posed by Judge Lemmens, and it relates to the applicability of Article I of Protocol I. In the pleadings of the parties, both in the applicants' and government's observations, there is a debate on whether there is an adequate recognition at domestic level of any kind of property rights. So I'm asking you not to focus on, if you may, on whether the property right existed or not, which is one line of case law, but the line of case law in discrimination type cases of property rights, where we're asking ourselves whether the mere fact that a condition has been applied in a discriminatory manner and has limited property rights, therefore, Article I of Protocol I is triggered or applicable. I want to, if you have time during the interval, to look at a case called Fabris versus France, paragraph 52 of that. And I invite you to make a comment on whether that has any bearing on the views of the parties. Thank you.
text.492: Sorry, just two short questions. One is, we're here, of course, looking at a complaint under the convention in the context of the Lausanne Treaty and possibly the Sèvres Treaty, the provisions of which are primarily addressed to Turkey on its face, and then, of course, applied in reverse to Greece by Article 45 of the Lausanne Treaty. But I wonder if anybody has given thought to how it is compatible with our case law under Article 9, not forcing the negative right of freedom of religion, which force the right not to practice and reveal one's belief, and the prohibition on states to ask individuals, in this case, the testator, about his or her beliefs and or to force them to follow the tenets of their religion against their choice. I wonder if you could address us on that, please, too.
text.493: Thank you very much, President. text.494: Merci beaucoup. Je voudrais poser une question spécialement au gouvernement, mais si le requérant peut donner des réponses, je l'apprécierai aussi. text.495: Thank you very much. text.496: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions addressed mainly to the government agent, but of course, the applicant can comment as well. text.497: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai une question adressée avant tout au gouvernement. text.498: Thank you, Mr. President. The applicant's constitutional appeal to the Constitutional Court was dismissed as inadmissible on 11 May 2012, as it had neither been signed nor endorsed by counsel. Now it's the well-established case law of this Court that domestic remedies are not exhausted if an appeal is dismissed because of the appellant's failure to comply with such formalities. And I underline criminal proceedings. But this substantive legal question is arguably distinct from the requirement in Portuguese law that a constitutional appeal on whatever legal question be signed by legal counsel. And this distinction is highlighted by Sir Nigel Rodley in his separate opinion, which is attached to the Human Rights Committee decision, and I quote, Important as it may be to ensuring justice in an individual case, a constitutional motion is not procedurally an integral part of a criminal trial. In the light of these factors, and also our established case law, I would ask both parties to explain if domestic remedies have actually been exhausted in this case, and if so, how.
text.499: J'aurais une question au requérant. J'aimerais bien savoir, le requérant a déjà porté une requête devant la Cour en 1999, et la Cour a rendu un jugement en 2001, et ce jugement est définitif, alors c'était la même chose, le même problème, maintenant c'est 16 années plus tard, et j'aimerais bien savoir quels sont les changements ou bien les facteurs que vous comptez importants pour justifier un revirement de notre jurisprudence. Merci.
text.500: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have two questions. One will be addressed to the government and the other to the applicant. text.501: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. J'ai une question à poser à la requérante. Si le gouvernement voulait commenter, ça sera bien aussi. Donc, la requérante avait fait une demande auprès de notre cour qui ne se fonde pas sur la question de la discrimination. Ca veut dire sur l'article 14. On voit maintenant qu'à nouveau, en voquant aussi les observations de la terre intervenante, la requérante souhaiterait que la cour requalifie l'affaire à cette étape en vertu du principe Iura novit curia et prend en considération une éventuelle violation de l'article 14. Que il suffit pour nous de faire référence à une interprétation littéraire de l'article 2. Et ma question est la suivante. Est-ce que vous pensez qu'à ce stade-là, dans la jurisprudence de la Cour, est-ce que vous pouvez nous donner des exemples? Merci beaucoup, M. le Président.
text.502: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to ask a question about something that has been raised by the applicant, also at the hearing, and something that is explicitly addressed in the written observations of the government in paragraph 80. Because moving in the same area is not going to increase the concentration. There is some difficulty for me in seeing how it fits the purpose that has been emphasized by the government here.
text.503: Thank you Mr. President. I have three questions to the government, but of course the applicant can also express her views on this issue. The first question relates to the motivation of the law. It is explicit from the travaux préparatoires of this law and explicitly mentioned in the explanatory memorandum of this law. And I'm quoting from a part of the chamber's judgment that these together with antisocial behavior, the influx of illegal immigrants and crime was said to constitute the core of Rotterdam's problems. And the third and final question regards the position of the government vis-a-vis other international bodies which have already dealt with this situation, namely the Human Rights Committee within the United Nations and the European Committee of Social Rights, which have expressed their views explicitly on this law. The European Committee of Social Rights in 2011 expressed a similar view, a similar concern, and invited the government to produce evidence that there was no discrimination, and concluded that there will be nothing to show that the situation is in conformity with Article 31, Paragraph 1 of the European Social Charter as regards effective access to and enjoyment of adequate housing in case the government did not produce this evidence. My question is the following. What was the reply of the government to these two international evaluations, one performed by the Human Rights Committee in 2009 and the other by the European Committee of Social Rights in 2011? Thank you very much.
text.504: Thank you, Mr. President. May I ask the government to clarify the aim of this measure? I understand from your presentation that it was primarily about desegregation or integration. But in the various documents which were submitted or were considered to be the basis of the measure, there might be an alternative explanation, namely that this was about combating antisocial behavior, which was just quoted by my colleague. text.505: Thank you, Mr. President. I have one question to both parties. It concerns the Gendarmerie unit, which carried out the investigation under the prosecutor's supervision. text.506: Oui, merci, M. le Président. J'ai des questions, surtout au gouvernement, tout d'abord. À la suite de l'arrêt du 18 octobre 2009 de la Cour constitutionnelle, qui concerne l'aléation de certaines dispositions de la loi sur les juges militaires, après cette décision de la Cour constitutionnelle, quelles sont les normes depuis lors concernant les questions de l'imprépendance et l'impartialité des juges militaires, à part la présence d'un officier, ce n'est pas le cas d'un officier siégeant au sein du tribunal militaire. Est-ce qu'il y a des situations où pareil accès est restreint ou interdit? Et si c'est le cas, pour quels motifs et sur quelle base légal? Et troisièmement, cette question concerne aussi les requérants. text.507: Thank you, Mr. President. My question refers to the one posed by Judge Karakaş. As I understand, the Constitutional Court ruling of 18th October 2009 established that the lack of independence of judges in military courts affected all the judges in these courts as they depended for their promotion to the favorable opinions and report of superior military officers or judges. text.508: Thank you. Just a minor point of clarification, if I could ask counsel for the applicants. In connection with this application which was brought before the Supreme Military Administrative Court, is it the applicant's contention, if I understood correctly, that this application for a remedy was brought without their knowledge by someone else? If I understood the submission by Ms. Butler correctly, or has any follow-up, have the applicants followed this up to see what actually happened in this particular instance? I would welcome some clarification on this point. This, of course, relates to the question of admissibility. Thank you.
text.509: Thank you, Mr. President. I have one question to the applicants. It's a question on the clarification of the scope of their legal arguments. I want to ask, does the applicant argue that the standards that you refer to, are they both standards as regards to what we can call formal or regulatory independence? Or are they also or mainly dealing with the criteria of impartiality? That's the first one. Are the applicants also here inviting the court to apply these standards associated with Article VI only in cases where there is a possibility of judicial review of investigatory measures in the member states, which is not always the case? Or is this argument of a general application? So then these independence and impartiality requirements would be directed at investigatory authorities, not of a judicial nature. And lastly, is the applicant's argument limited to the military context? Or is it an argument that has general application in all instances where the procedural component is triggered by a death in the member states? Thank you. Thank you.
text.510: Thank you Mr. President. Only one question and affirmation that somehow has struck me both to both parties. Now, looking at Nagorno-Karabakh, if Nagorno-Karabakh were a separate, independent state, not being a signatory of the European Convention, would be the European Convention applicable, will be enforced, will be the rights recognized by the European Convention enforced in the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh? text.511: Thank you, Mr. President. My first question is indeed on jurisdiction, since in the pleadings just now, we heard all three parties indeed discussing at lens this issue. And you were suggesting that in fact, this court has taken a different approach as compared to the one taken by the ICJ in the Nicaragua case. Thank you, Mr. President.
text.512: Thank you, President. I have a question to the respondent government, something that the learned representative said, which I didn't understand, and maybe I'm overlooking something. How could Armenian courts have provided legal redress to the applicants? Maybe I've overlooked something, and I'll be grateful if you could clarify. Thank you, President.
text.513: Thank you, President. Three questions, all addressed to the respondent government, and all regarding non-exhaustion of domestic remedies. Thank you.
text.514: Thank you, President. I have questions for both parties. First, three questions for the applicant. My second question may be not too much related to today's deliberation, because as court decided in his admissibility decision, we will be considering facts after ratification of convention. But in any way, what would be your comments on the statement of Vazgen Manukyan, who was Armenian defense minister in October 1992, and who made statement in 2000 about union of armies in Gaia and Armenia, which is mentioned in the book Thomas De Waal, Black Garden, referred by applicants. And also, more concrete question, could you explain how it was possible that the Armenian law enforcement agents operated in the case of Zalian and others in Nagorno-Karabakh and the regional, Sunni regional court of Armenia hold the hearing in Stepanakert? And my last question, could you please compare the financial support which Nagorno-Karabakh gets from all Armenian fund and from other sources, namely from the government of the United States? Thank you.
text.515: Thank you, Mr. President. I have one question for the applicants, and third-party interveners may respond if they so choose. The Applicants' Council cited paragraph 56 of this court's judgment in Loizidou v. Turkey. It's important of the submission that the effective control test does not necessitate a demonstration of detailed control over the policies and actions of local authorities in the disputed area. In paragraph 56 of Loizidou, the court stated, and I quote, it is not necessary to determine whether, as the applicant and the government of Cyprus have suggested, Turkey actually exercises detailed control over the policies and actions of the authorities of the TRC. It is obvious from the large number of troops engaged in active duties in northern Cyprus that her army exercises effective control over that part of the island. Such control, according to the relevant test and in the circumstances of the case, entails her responsibilities for the policies and actions of the TRC. In Al-Skeini, the court elaborated further, stating that the factual assessment of jurisdiction must be, and I quote from paragraphs 138 to 139, primarily based on the strength of the military's presence, as mentioned by counsel to the third-party intervener. Thank you.
text.516: Merci, monsieur le Président. J'ai 2 questions pour les représentants du gouvernement suisse. La 1re question. Dans le cadre du coopération Dublin, quelle est, en pratique, la forme et l'étendue des réponses pour la prise en charge des demandeurs d'asile de la part de l'Etat requis? Est-ce qu'elle se réfère à la situation spécifique des demandeurs d'asile, aux conditions spécifiques d'accueil, etc.? La 2e question. Quelle est la proportion entre, d'une côté, les prises en charge explicites à la base de l'article 22, paragraphe 1 du règlement Dublin 3, et de l'autre côté, de la prise en charge implicite à la base du paragraphe 7 du même article du règlement Dublin 3? Est-ce que les Etats requis réagissent régulièrement ou la pratique, c'est plutôt l'acceptation implicite? Je vous remercie.
text.517: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question to the respondent government. I would appreciate if you responded on this issue concerning the best interests of the child. And in particular, the question is, in what manner have the Swiss authorities taken into consideration the best interests of the child within the proceedings that we are dealing with today in the framework of the case? Italy? text.518: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai deux questions aux représentants du gouvernement suisse. text.519: Thank you very much. I do have a question to the applicant. It's a clarification question. On 21st of June, the file was removed from Judge M and the case was withdrawn from the judge. How this contributed to the proper administration of justice? Moreover, in circumstances when there was going on the investigation on Judge M's professional behaviour. Thank you.
text.520: Monsieur le Président, je voudrais faire une demande d'information au parti. Est-ce qu'il y a des règlements ou des régulations disciplinaires internes de l'ordre des avocats qui pourraient éventuellement avoir été appliées par des organes de l'ordre au fait du cas? Dans le cas, comment doit-on s'interpréter qu'on n'a pas introduit une telle procédure? Merci.
text.521: Merci. I would like to put a question to the applicant's lawyers. Two questions, actually. During your submissions this morning, you emphasized the fact, I think, that the character of the particular judge in question, Judge M, was not an issue in the freedom of expression enjoyed by the applicant, and that it was only her professional conduct that was commented upon. I would like you to elaborate on that submission in respect solely of the allegation of connivance. So, could you elaborate on how the character of Judge M was not an issue in circumstances where an allegation of connivance, which could involve criminal liability, was made? That's the first question. And the second question I would like some further submissions on is on the question of the duty of a lawyer. You focus, again, primarily on the lawyer's primary role to defend his or her client's interests. And you submit that the lawyer must enjoy a functional protection not limited to the courtroom, and that it be as broad as possible. I would be interested in any observations that you might have to make on the lawyer's duty, if any, in your view, to the court. And in this regard, I mean the court actually seized with the case, the court hearing the case, and not to the professional reputation of judges in general. I'm talking about the court that was actually seized with the hearing of this case at the time when the comments were made. What, if any, in your view, does... What duty, if any, in your view, does such a lawyer owe to the court as the decider of the facts and the law? Thank you.
text.522: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions for the government that I would like to present. And I would here like to refer to the applicant's contention here that the Migration Court, and this is paragraph 83 of the applicant's observations, that the Migration Court expressed no doubt as to the validity of F.G.'s summons to attend the Revolutionary Court on 2 November 2009. My second question deals with the conclusion, which is I think the crux of this case, the government contends that paragraph 57 and the counsel for the government reiterated this today. The government concludes that the applicant has not plausibly demonstrated that he would, on account of his conversion to Christianity, face a real risk of being subjected to ill treatment. Does this conclusion, because I didn't quite understand this issue, does this conclusion apply not only to the facts as established in 2011 and 12 by the migration authorities at domestic level? Or is it also the government's submission today that were the Grand Chamber to decide the issue in accordance with the materials submitted as of this date, the applicant has not made such a plausible claim? I would like an answer to that. Thank you.
text.523: Thank you. I have a question for the applicant. In a written statement to the court on the 13th of September this year, the applicant states that his family can never accept the fact that he has converted and that his friends will never tolerate it. In view of this, does the applicant consider that there is a potential risk that his family and friends will find out about his conversion should he practice it in Iran by way of, for instance, publications of religious texts on the internet or being active in a church? In order to better understand how familiar the Swedish authorities and courts are with the situation of Christian converts in Iran, I would like to know if the government know how common it is that Iranian asylum seekers invoke surplus conversions as a ground of asylum in Sweden.
text.524: Merci, Monsieur le Président. I have first a factual clarification. Referring to paragraph 41 of the chamber judgment and then to the conclusion, paragraph 42 of the chamber judgment, my understanding is that the applicant failed to raise or did not prefer to raise the question of his conversion, whereas today the government is alleging that he failed to substantiate. And then my final question, Mr. President, this court, since the early cases of Cruz Varas, Chahal, etc., I might refer as well to Sufi and Elmi, paragraph 215, has used the notion of ex-nunc analysis, to which Judge Spano, if I understood well, referred to. Does this kind of analysis take place at national level as well? So do the national authorities take into account the current circumstances, not only of the destination state, but also of the applicant? Thank you.
text.525: Thank you, Mr. President. One question for the applicant, and one question for the government. Starting with the government. The applicant was a Muslim, and he converted to Christian belief. This is a crime in Iran, and a very serious crime. It's a crime of apostasy. And it's a capital offense, punished with death. Iran punishes with death penalty those Muslim who convert to other beliefs. More recently, prosecutors have relied on other offenses, such as an attempt to the security of the state, which is also a capital offense. My question is the following. Can the government guarantee today to this plenary that if there is a new assessment of the applicant's situation at the national level, he's not going to be sent to a country where he faces the death penalty? I repeat, in the case the court finds eventually only a procedural violation of Article Two or Three, and the new procedure is launched at the national level, can the government guarantee today that this person, at the end of the day, at the end of that national proceeding, will not be sent to a country where he faces the death penalty? My question to the applicant. What has been the practical contribution of the applicant to his church? Could you please elaborate further on this practical life as a Christian of the applicant? Thank you very much.
text.526: Thank you, Mr. President. My question is addressed to the government and follows in a sense from Judge Spano's question. Apart from what the applicant did or did not do before the domestic tribunals, and apart from what the domestic tribunals concluded, I would like to know, because I'm still not quite sure what the answer to this question is, what is the government's position today? Is it of the view that the applicant is a real convert to Christianity, or is it of the view that this was not a genuine conversion, but simply possibly a means to an end? text.527: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question to the representative of the applicant, in particular to Maître Paoletti. Did I understand it correctly that she never wished to pursue the pregnancy because she didn't want to become a single mother? My second question concerns also the applicant. Did the applicant receive, before she went into in vitro fertilization treatment, a contract by the hospital in which she was informed about the fact that the embryos created by in vitro fertilization could only be used for the fertilization, but not for anything else? Thank you.
text.528: Merci, M. le Président. Je m'adresse aux deux parties pour leur demander si pourrait-elle nous donner son point de vue sur deux aspects moins scientifiques et plus techniques pour moi. Le premier étant, quel est votre point de vue sur l'applicabilité de l'article 8 de la Convention au fait de l'affaire qui est présente devant nous. Et le deuxième point, d'une certaine façon lié au premier, sur la qualité des victimes de la requérante. Merci.
text.529: Thank you, Mr. President. My questions are partly overlapping the questions which were already raised. My first question is, what was the legal system applicable in 2003 when the embryos were created concerning conservation and, in particular, research in Italy? Secondly, it is argued by government that embryo is life. My question is this, assuming that you are right and this is life, is it a life comparable to that of the fetus? Is the in vitro embryo that was called a cluster of cells by Professor De Luca, is this entity, a person, in view of Italian law, having regard to the position of the Constitutional Court which said in 75, "persona che deve ancora diventare"? To the applicants, if I understand correctly, the in vitro entity is 11 years old. Is there any research advantage to use these cells for research purposes given the age and given the doubts expressed? To the government, is an Italian scientist subject to criminal prosecution if he or she carries out research abroad on in vitro embryo? Thank you very much.
text.530: Oui, merci, Monsieur le Président. J'aimerais que le gouvernement clarifie le but légitime de l'interdiction de l'article 13 de la loi 40 2004, tout en considérant que les laboratoires peuvent pratiquer des recherches sur les lignes embryonnaires importées de l'étranger, donc après la destruction de ces embryons. D'après cela, j'ai une question plus simple. Est-ce qu'il y a une interdiction de destruction des embryons? Ça, on le sait, mais que devient-il s'il existe une interdiction? Alors, est-ce que les institutions gardent à l'infini? C'est ma deuxième question. Merci beaucoup.
text.531: Thank you, Mr. President. I have one question to the representative of the applicants. It's a factual question. Is the applicant obliged to maintain contacts with the embryo storage bank whilst her embryos are cryopreserved? For instance, should she still pay for cryopreservation of her embryo? Thank you.
text.532: This question goes to the government. I would like to know if there is any available data on the number of sterile couples who have benefited from fertilization with cryopreserved embryos of third couples who did not want to become parents. Do we have already any available data on these third couples who have benefited from this possibility? Thank you.
text.533: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions for both parties. As we saw from hearing, the main purpose and object of the law from 2004 is to protect the life of the embryo. In this context, is there any, I would say, internal inconsistency or contradiction concerning this main object of the law? I mean, in any case, embryo will be extinct, will be perished after the lapse of some time. Or more precisely, whether the holding embryo in cryopreserved status on the temperature absolute zero amounts also some sort of scientific experiment. And the second question is whether the prohibition of scientific research is motivated by other reason, not only to protect the life of the embryo. Thank you.
text.534: Thank you, President. My question is of a philosophical nature, and I would like both parties to comment on the philosophical underpinnings of each other's submissions. If I understand correctly, the submission of the government is founded upon a philosophical understanding of the embryo as a value in itself under Italian law, that the embryo is the subject of rights or is a value in itself, an end in itself. And if I understand correctly, the submissions of the applicant, the embryo, or as Professor De Luca has put it, may be seen as a cluster of cells, that this entity, this embryo or cluster of cells, may become a value for others. So not necessarily an end in itself, but perhaps a means towards some other end. And you mentioned some of the types of research and benefits that can accrue from the research on embryos. So I would like each side to consider the philosophical underpinning in terms of value, means end, and comment on the correlation of each party's position with the rights protected under Article 8 of the Convention. Thank you.
text.535: Mr. President, I have first a question to the applicants' councils. And in view of the submissions that we just heard, I would really appreciate if you explained more specifically your key submission that resort to equivalent protection doctrine, as developed by the court in the Bosphorus case, leads to a harmonization or harmonious application of the obligations, both that derive under Security Council resolution concerns and Article 6. And that in light of Article 103 of the charter, if I understood your key submission correctly. And I would like to really know how do you envisage this construction applied in practice in the facts of the case? Do you mean that the domestic tribunals are not prevented from assessing the well-founded character of the listing of the applicant? And if so, if the well-founded character were to assess, what would be then the expected outcome at the domestic level? And second question goes to the parties. And it concerns Article 6, because we've had submissions on the scope of the court's competence, "ratione personae and ratione materiae". But I would like you to answer a very simple question, and that is applicability of Article 6. We know that for Article 6 to apply, we have to have a civil rights in dispute or a criminal charge. So which aspect, in fact, do you plead, I suppose, the applicant or do you contest as far as the respondent government is concerned? And what case law do you invoke in support of the applicability? Thank you. resident.
text.536: Merci, M. le Président. La 1re question va à la partie requérante. Vous avez parlé d'intégration systémique et d'application harmonieuse des obligations parallèles, non pas contradictoires, mais parallèles, de la Suisse au titre de la charte de la Convention. Dans ce contexte, et à votre avis, quel aurait dû être concrètement l'étendue du contrôle de la part des juridictions suisses? Le tribunal fédéral aurait dû s'assurer simplement que l'inscription du requérant sur la liste n'était pas fausse ou arbitraire, ou bien le tribunal fédéral aurait dû opérer un contrôle d'opportunité de la mesure d'inscription et partant des mesures de gel et de confiscation des avoirs? La 2e question, M. le Président, va au gouvernement, et éventuellement au gouvernement intervenant. Tous les gouvernements ici présents ont parlé, ont vu dans l'article 103 de la charte des Nations unies une règle de conflit de normes. Donc d'un conflit entre la charte et la Convention. S'agit-il réellement d'une règle de conflit de normes ou bien plus simplement d'une règle de conflit d'obligations? La Commission du droit international, dans son rapport sur la fragmentation du droit international mentionné tout à l'heure, précise dans le paragraphe 331 du rapport, l'article 103 ne précise pas que la charte prime, mais renvoie aux obligations en vertu de la charte. Donc l'article 103, d'après vous, est une règle de conflit de normes ou simplement de conflit d'obligations? Merci beaucoup.
text.537: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions, one for the applicant, which is the first one. The government refers at paragraphs 58 to 64 to the court's case law on the limitation to the right of access to court under Article 6.1 in the state immunity cases, Al-Adsani versus UK, and recently the fourth section's judgment in Jones versus UK, where the limitation is based on a recognized norm of international law. The government here refers also to the dissenting opinion view by Judge Lorenzen, where he states, and I quote "Priority for implementing binding resolutions of the UN Security Council can be said to belong to this category of exceptions". I see from the applicant's submissions in written form, and also today, that towards this argument, an argument has not been made. So may I ask the applicants to explain to the court, assuming the applicability of Article 6, how would the applicant invite the court to distinguish the rule of priority under Article 103 of the UN Charter as regards binding resolutions of the Security Council and the case law on this aspect? My second question goes to the government. The government states at paragraph 49 of its observations that, and it considers that the court cannot find, and this is, I'm quoting the observation, that there has been a violation independently of the concrete and realistic feasibility of implementation of the obligations that such a finding would entail. This is the English translation. May I ask the government to develop this or explain this a bit in taking two things into account which are part of the facts of this case. Number one, as the government mentioned, the government has itself allowed for exceptions to the freezing of these funds, and it has done so under the Iraq ordinance, which was promulgated by Switzerland, where exceptions can be made due to hardship cases, and that is the fees allowed to the lawyers. And secondly, the Swiss authorities have stayed the execution of the confiscation decisions, whereas paragraph 23 of the Security Council Resolution talks explicitly about immediately transferring the funds to the development fund for Iraq. So on what basis has the Swiss government considered, because the argument was made that it has no room for maneuver, on what basis does the government consider that it can make these exceptions? And what is the extent of the possible exceptions that the government considers it can make in accordance with its so-called mandatory obligations under the resolution? Thank you.
text.538: Thank you, President. Well, in the resolution 1483, it's clearly defined who should be targeted by those sanctions. We have letter A, funds or other financial assets or economic resources of the previous government of Iraq or its state bodies, et cetera. And then we have letter B, funds or other financial assets or economic resources that have been removed from Iraq or acquired by Saddam Hussein or other senior officials, et cetera. So what now the question to the applicant, what is your argumentation? Is it, do you argue that the applicants do not fall under neither of those provisions? And if that's your argument, why does he not fall under those provisions? Do you think it was arbitrary to include him because there was a misunderstanding, he was taken for somebody else? Or do you argue that this text was interpreted in a wrong way when he was listed? Or do you argue it was disproportionate? Or do you argue, yes, in substance, it was correct if the text of the resolution is accepted as it is, but there was no fair trial? Or do you argue that the personal scope of the resolution should have been defined differently? Or do you argue the resolution should not have been adopted as it has been adopted? Thank you.
text.539: Thank you. Mr. President, my question is in line with the previous questions of judges Nußberger and Sicilianos. I appreciate the parties' submissions regarding conflicts between various norms of international law, but I propose to look more intensely to the applicant. And if you return to the first applicant, he was punished just because of being a senior official of the state without justifying the personal responsibility. My question is, is it evident for the parties? And what did the applicant seek the justice in this respect when he applied to the Swiss authorities? Thank you.
text.540: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. Ma première question est adressée au requérant. Donc, dans le procès verbal qui a été adressé par l'inspecteur Clays à l'égard de M. Bouyid Mohamed, M. Bouyid Mohamed mentionne le fait qu'il est plus vulnérable à cause de l'origine marocaine. S'agissant de ces cas et l'enquête qui a été faite par le comité de P, j'ai des questions concrètes pour vous dire, à la suite de l'enquête qui a été faite par le comité de P, pourquoi est-ce que, quand le juge d'instruction avait continué cette enquête, comme vous l'avez mentionné, pourquoi est-ce que certaines preuves n'ont pas été administrées? Parce qu'on sait qu'au moment où, comme vous avez dit, au moment où M. Saïd Bouide avait été interpellé, il était avec un ami. Pourquoi cet ami n'a pas été aussi entendu par le juge d'instruction? Et je vois une certaine contradiction entre ces 2 faits. Parce que si le certificat n'est pas accepté, quelle autre preuve ils auraient pu mettre pour que ça puisse être abordé? Comment vous voyez qu'on peut réconcilier cette acceptation de la présomption de causalité et le fait que, finalement, ces certificats donnés par des médecins autorisés ne sont pas pris en considération? Je vous remercie, M. le Président.
text.541: Thank you, Mr. President. The questions will be in English, in case you want to put the earphones. I have two factual questions, and in an aspect, they also go back to Judge Motoc's question. I would like to establish a timeline. So what happens on 8 December and 23 February, we are in the police station, then certain facts happen. At what moment in time did the applicants go to the doctor? text.542: Thank you, Mr. President. In fact, I have a rather technical question. text.543: Thank you very much, President. I have two questions to each party. One question, I will start with the question to the government first. The applicant's representative suggested that during all short-term visits he received from his family members, the meeting room was separated by class participation and the guard was listening at hearing distance. Was that really so? And were such modalities related to the applicant's personality and individual situations, or were they generally applied to all prisoners? And to the applicant's representative, I would like to get the information, how is now the situation with respect to family visits of the applicant? Does he receive any visits from his family members? And if so, which, what frequency? Thank you.
text.544: Merci, M. le Président. Je voudrais aussi poser une question aux représentants du gouvernement, M. Matyushkin. text.545: Thank you, President. My question goes to both parties. text.546: Thank you. The government has argued on the issue of admissibility that the applicant has been divorced in 1996. And I first wanted to ask the applicant to comment on this issue. Is it only applied to really married partners or also to partners living together in some other form? Is it really dependent on the fact of being married? text.547: Thank you, Mr. President. And I have two questions to both parties. And first to the government. And my question concerns the justification for the last 5.5 hours. Since according to the Police Act, a person could not be kept apprehended for more than 12 hours, and the longer apprehension time, up to 24 hours by the Criminal Investigation Act, would have been applicable only if arrest was available. And the applicant was charged and convicted of disobeying police order, and the statutory sanction of that would not have allowed arrest. Now, I understood from the submission of the government that the government's allegation is that the applicant was apprehended of rioting, and it was only later changed to disobeying police orders. However, according to the Ombudsman, a bystander who did not take part in violent actions as the applicant could not be apprehended of rioting. And therefore, the longer apprehension time, this 24 hours, seems to be excluded. And my question now is, since the legal basis for the apprehension for 12 hours, it's clear, but the question concerns the legal basis for the rest 5.5 hours. And then I have two questions to the applicant. And the applicant stated in his observation, and also today, that the police at the scene tried to hamper his journalistic work. However, in the video films, and in photos, and in witness hearings before the National Court, there did not appear any indication of hindering by the police carrying out his work as a photographer. And further, the applicant did not raise these allegations before the National Court or before the chamber. And now, after eight years behind the incidents, after the incidents, he raises new facts. And I only would like to mention the fact he raised today, here before the grand chamber, for the very first time, the allegation that he wished to give the memory card to the other journalist, which was not permitted by the police. So my question is, why the applicant did not raise these facts and these allegations before the National Court or before the chamber? Why the grand chamber is the first stage when these facts come out? My other question concerns the press card, the badge. And here, I again refer to the video film and the photo submitted by the applicant. And in any shots, in any photos taken of the applicant at the scene, the press card cannot be seen. And my question is, did he have the press card suspending around his neck? And was it visible when he was working on the spot when the order to disperse was given? Thank you.
text.548: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai deux questions. La première s'adresse au gouvernement. Si un journaliste avait la crainte que le groupe des derniers manifestants qui refusait d'obéir à la police risquait de subir des mesures brutales, la décision de ce journaliste de rester sur place était-elle liée ou non à son travail d'information? Dans ce que vous avez appelé des situations extrêmes, c'est-à-dire, à mes yeux, des manifestations, des catastrophes, des prises d'otages, est-ce qu'il suffit au journaliste d'invoquer sa mission d'information pour refuser d'obéir à la police? Si la réponse, selon vous, dépend des circonstances, quels sont alors, à votre avis, les critères qui doivent guider le comportement des journalistes face à des instructions ou des ordres de la police?
text.549: Thank you, Mr. President. The essence of the case, as characterized by the applicant, and my first question concerns the applicant, the essence of the case, as characterized by the applicant in the reasons for referring the case to the ground chamber, is the right of the state to restrict the impartation of real-time communications. My question is, was this raised before, either before the domestic authorities? I haven't seen it in the file. Now, my question is, the government acknowledges that at a certain moment in time, the authorities realized that the person apprehended was a journalist. This was at 9.30 p.m. or somewhat later the day. Have the government considered the possible interest of immediate use of the photographs taken by the person apprehended?
text.550: Merci beaucoup, M. le Président. Ma 1re question s'adresse au gouvernement. Et vous avez dit qu'il y avait des informations concernant lesquelles cette manifestation pouvait tourner dans une manifestation très violente et que c'était l'Agence de sécurité finlandaise qui avait donné cette information. Si vraiment l'information qui a été donnée a été correspondue à l'ampleur de la manifestation et aux actions violentes qui étaient sur place. La 2e question que je voulais poser s'adresse au récurrent cette fois-ci. Et je voulais savoir si vraiment... Comment est-ce que vous percevez dans la jurisprudence de la Cour l'effet dissuasif que nos collègues qui font l'opinion séparée, et vous-même maintenant devant la Grande Chambre, ont fait, ont exposé dans leur opinion séparée? Est-ce que, comme vous le savez, cet effet dissuasif part de jugements de la Grande Chambre, comprenant Mazaré, et continue avec des autres jugements de la Cour, mais ces jugements-là vont toujours envers la condamnation pénale? Et une 3e question que je vais mettre en deux parties, si, à part les investigations qui étaient faites par l'Ombudsman, il y avait d'autres investigations qui étaient faites par rapport au comportement de la police, et si vraiment on a trouvé qu'il y avait des plaintes contre le comportement de la police par des manifestants, et si vraiment, si ces plaintes avaient eu lieu, comment est-ce que la fin de cette plainte s'est passée? Merci beaucoup, M. le Président.
text.551: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions that are somehow peripheral. They both concern the exact scope of the case. text.552: Thank you, Mr. President. text.553: Thank you. I have one question to the applicant, a factual question. text.554: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question to first to the applicant. And the question to the government, were there any position on such public issues of public debate was manifested by the demonstration? So in fact, what it was, a demonstration or a crowd? Thank you.
text.555: Thank you, Mr. President. My questions, it's one big question with several sub-points, goes principally to the applicants' representatives, but of course the government is also welcome to comment on that. Am I right in understanding that the applicant's position is that in the name of freedom of expression, there is no obligation of pre-monitoring? So of course, while understanding that the filtering system with these few additions is not what pre-monitoring means in the expert world in this area, may I ask you to clarify, say, what were the considerations or the principles? And what were the purposes then for Delphi to put in place the filtering system and also these two other sort of, I understand, random possibilities of monitoring the comments? So it is all linked to my question as to how you understand the scope or the type of obligations of the internet media. So my question linked to those words is, am I right in assuming that those words are considered appropriate by the filtering system as in place at the time? Thank you.
text.556: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I have some factual issues that I would like to explore with the applicant and then one question to the government. Did he request that the comments be removed or was that a request that he did not make? Now as regards this request removal, had the defamed person been in any contact, direct or indirectly, with the applicant company before these six weeks, that is before he formally submitted the claim for damages? Can I especially ask you to respond to that assertion by the government? And may I ask, did the injured person request disclosure of the commentators in question, the IP addresses as they were, as I understand it, all anonymous? Lastly, my question to the government. The government, the applicant alleges in this case that the interference at national level was not prescribed by law. The chamber in this case acknowledges that the legislation in question was, and I quote, general and lacked detail. The government says here today, and I quote, everybody who makes information available to third persons is considered to be a discloser. May I ask for clarification on the following issue? Before the decisions at national level in Delphi, had this rule of civil liability ever been applied by the domestic courts to a situation where the alleged discloser had no prior control, editorial or otherwise, to the content of the information made available to third parties? And in relation to that, to what extent are we to consider the application of this rule in Delphi's case to be one of strict, no culpa, objective tort liability? Or is it based on a showing of actual knowledge of the illegal content of the information in question? And would this rule, under the way in which you describe it, would that automatically apply to social media platforms like Facebook or YouTube? Because these intermediaries, these social platforms, indeed make available information to third parties. So my question is, would this rule apply with the same kind of force to these social media platforms? Thank you.
text.557: Thank you very much, Mr. President. My question is addressed principally to the government, but of course the applicant company might wish to comment as well. The international documents adopted in this field, including those of the Council of Europe, which have been referred to extensively in the Chamber of Judgment and in memorials, show, at least in my view, a clear trend towards the opportunity of differentiating the regime of the Internet, especially as far as Article 10 of the Convention issues are concerned, from the regulation of, so to speak, traditional media. And we know, of course, that the position of the government is in the sense that the traditional legal framework, basically the civil code, so the "neminem laedere" principle, is sufficient to satisfy the needs of Article 10. Now, my question is, is there any reflection going on at the parliament level, at the government level or in other political circles, about the possible introduction of a specific legislation in Estonia on the model of, for instance, what has been done in the United Kingdom with the approval last year of the Deformation Act 2013 applicable for England and Wales? Thank you very much.
text.558: Thank you, President. I have a factual question to the applicant company. And in fact, it follows the question put by Judge Ziemele. text.559: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question for the applicant. In the chamber judgment in paragraph 10, is quoted a kind of disclaimer by your company, and I'm quoting that paragraph saying, the applicant company had made efforts to advise users that the comments were not its opinion and that the authors of comments were responsible for their content in the conditions where the users are anonymous. How can this disclaimer be operational, and have you referred to this during the domestic proceedings? Thank you.
text.560: The question is mainly addressed to the respondent government. Could you please explain the court the current situation concerning the proceedings in the case file 20-849, especially in respect of following the decision of 12th of September from 2005 to quash the previous decision of 3rd of December 2004. text.561: Thank you, Madam President. I have two questions. The first one concerns the investigation. According to the statement by the Ossetian EMERCOM Minister Sikoyev, at 7 a.m. on 4 September, the EMERCOM team started the clearance operation. EMERCOM had finished the clearance work at 7 p.m. – that is in 12 hours, more or less – after which the building was rendered to the local administration. So my question is, what was the impact of this clearance operation on the possibility to investigate on exactly what happened the previous days, and especially during the rescue operation? The applicants briefly referred to this issue, so my question goes mainly to the government. My second question is purely legal, and it goes to both parties. It concerns the planning and control of the rescue operation. If I got it right, Mr. Matyushkin, you said, and I quote, the use of force was a forced measure when the situation became critical. In other words, you seem to implicitly refer to the international law concept of the state of necessity as a circumstance precluding wrongfulness codified by the UN International Law Commission in Article 25 of the Articles on State Responsibility. My question is whether this concept of state of necessity is legally relevant in our case. Thank you very much.
text.562: Thank you, Madam President. I have two questions to the government and one question to the applicants. Apart from victim status, as we heard from Mr. Matyushkin, do the government support the previous observation on admissibility and whether they want to clarify something on this issue? Second question is about the criminal case against the terrorist. What does it give the understanding, a full understanding, what kind of understanding of circumstances of this case? And the question to the applicants, did the terrorist use indiscriminate weapons except bombs during this operation? And do the government support the previous observation?
text.563: Thank you, Mr. President. It's a question to both parties. According to submissions by the parties, Order No. 70 on technical requirements for the system of technical facilities enabling the conduct of operational search activities using telecommunications network, issued by the Ministry of Communications on 20 April 1999, stipulates that equipment installed by communications service providers must meet certain technical requirements which are described in the addendums to the order. I would like to know more about the functioning of this order in practice and its impact on the various safeguards and guarantees provided by the applicable legislation, especially the authorization procedure. Thank you very much.
text.564: Thank you, Mr. President. In view of the applicant's submissions, and since the second part of the submissions addressed the question of notification in greater detail, I would like to ask the government to explain exactly this aspect in your sort of rebuttals. Because would the government really confirm that there is no obligation to notify of surveillance that had taken place and that had not led to any criminal proceedings? So would the government confirm that that is indeed the case? And the applicant just referred to your written submissions. And if that is so, could the government explain the reasons for such approach in the Russian legislation? So if you would really address specifically this part outside the criminal proceedings. Thank you.
text.565: Thank you, Mr. President. It's a bit following up on the previous question also about the notification of the interception to the subject. text.566: A question for the applicants, we have heard today that the government is raising the issue of non-exhaustion of domestic remedies. And you did not refer to that. text.567: Thank you. My question is mostly to the representatives of the Azerbaijani government. Specific damages different from general expulsion of persons or displaced persons. Now my question is, is there in Azerbaijan some specific normative or regulation concerning this particular and specific damages resulted from direct military action or violent action in the line of contact or the front line? text.568: Thank you, Mr. President. My question is addressed to the applicant. The applicant did not address the main argument of the respondent government regarding jurisdiction. The respondent government say that they prohibited access of civilians to this particular area because it is dangerous. And they gave an order which is secret with that purpose of avoiding civilians in that particularly dangerous area. So those are my questions, Mr. Lepresto.
text.601: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions, one addressed to the, to counsel for the respondent government, and the other to both. The first question is, I would like to have some further reaction from the respondent government. What the government has to say in reply to the applicant's reference to the guidance note of the 6th of May, 1970. The applicant says it was totally ineffectual, in effect, no real guidance whatsoever. I would like to have the respondent government's reaction to that. I believe the counsel for the applicant made this statement, again reiterated the statement, even in his submissions. The second question is, and I ask this question because I don't know what the position is in Ireland totally, is apart from suing the bishop or the archbishop, which my colleague has just mentioned, is there the possibility of suing instead the diocese or the archdiocese as a juridical person? In other words, not the bishop in his individual capacity. I wonder if I could have some clarification on that point. Thank you very much.
text.602: Thank you, President. I have one question for the government and one question for the applicant. To the government, you have explained and attempted to distinguish the Zambrano principle as it arises in this case. But I would like you to comment on a submission made by the Immigrant Council of Ireland as to what effective legal protection actually requires. Effective legal protection. And you will see from their submissions that they deal with this under the heading of administrative and judicial decision-making bodies. The submission is that if national authorities suggest that the family may move elsewhere in the EU or are not actually forced to leave the territory of the EU, then the law would require and would expect that the decision-making bodies adverted to this possible solution and to have adduced evidence as to its practicality, its feasibility and its proportionality for any particular member. And I would ask the government, firstly, to comment on that submission, and secondly, to show where in the administrative and judicial decisions the practicality, feasibility and proportionality of a move or either within the territory has been made. And I would just draw attention to the fact that in the domestic decision of the court dated 8 December 2009, that's the regional court of The Hague sitting in Harlem, reference is made to EU law, but not to the possibility of moving within the territory, but rather to the fact that there's no obligation on the family, on the citizens to leave, EU citizens to leave, because the children could always stay in the Netherlands alone with their father. And if that alternative is to be submitted, is to be relied upon, then how would that not in fact result in a constructive interference with family life, with an interference in that the family would be broken up? That's the question that I would put to the government. To the applicant, the case, as I understand it, is mainly pleaded in terms of an interference or a failure to comply with the positive obligations insofar as the applicant's family life is concerned. And very little is made in terms of the claim under Article 8 to private life. Now, this court in a number of judgments has elected to examine both aspects, and I would like the applicants to comment on the private life of the applicant and to what extent identity as the mother of Dutch children forms part of the applicant's private life. So the applicant's identity as the mother of Dutch children, to what extent does that touch upon the applicant's private life? Thank you.
text.603: Thank you Mr. President. I'd like to make two factual questions to both the applicant and the government. It seems that the reason for the denial of the residence to the applicant was the lack of a provisional residence visa. This provisional residence visa has to be applied for in the country of origin of the applicant, that is in Suriname. So if the regular proceedings were followed, the applicant should go back to Suriname, then apply, they should apply them for this provisional residence visa in order to be able to go back to the Netherlands. Now my questions are, first, if the applicant would do that, would go back to Suriname and ask for a provisional residence visa, first, what would be the criteria followed by the government to allow or not to allow this provisional visa? Secondly, if up to the point you can answer to that, what are the perspectives of getting this permission, this provisional residence visa? And finally, how much time would it be needed for these proceedings? I mean, how much time would it take from asking the provisional residence visa and then to get the response by the government? Thank you.
text.604: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question to the applicant and a question to the government, and it equally goes back to the facts of the case. The parties have pleaded in front of the court the principle of the best interests of the child. And to the applicant, I would like to know, in the set of proceedings that the applicant has initiated in the Netherlands with the view of obtaining the residence permit, in what manner and with what arguments did the applicant reason the best interests of the child, apart from the evident fact of the Dutch nationality of the children, what other arguments were advanced as concerns the need to protect the best interests of the child, and maybe in which of the numerous proceedings? And the question to the government in the same context. The government, in its observations, written observations and oral submissions, especially in paragraph 67 in your written memorial, you have mentioned several arguments showing that there was the best interests of the children have been taken into consideration. Again, a factual question. Are these the government's arguments in paragraph 67, or were these exactly the words, the reasoning used by the domestic courts or the administrative authorities? If so, could you point to the court, could you direct the court to these judgments, decisions where exactly in the same manner the best interests of the child have been assessed and balanced in the proceedings? Thank you.
text.605: Thank you, Mr. President. Two questions to clarify certain facts, if I may. They are mainly directed towards the government, but perhaps even the counsel for the applicant can refer to them. If I remember correctly, if I understood correctly, counsel for the government said that the husband's criminal record is no obstacle to him entering and settling in Suriname. In view of the fact that, as far as I can understand, the husband has lost Surinamese nationality and the criminal record referred to something which was not really trivial, could government elaborate on that? The second question is, apart from the repeated applications for residence, what exactly were the reasons or the reason why it took so long for the government to actually take action to expel applicant from Dutch territory? Thank you.
text.606: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question for the representative of the applicant. On page 10 of your written submissions, you state that in the context of immigration cases, children carry no responsibility for choices made by parents. And in order to underline this position, referral is made to three cases of our court. First, the Nunez case, in which deportation and exclusion orders would effectively result in a mother guilty of immigration law breaches being separated from her young children for two years. Second, the case of Mubilanzila Mayeka and Kaniki Mitunga, which concerns detention and deportation of a five-year-old child without her family. And third, Osman versus Denmark. You mentioned this case also in your oral submissions today, in which refusal to renew residence permit of a minor who had been sent abroad against her will is the case. All of these cases concern a situation in which not finding a violation would result necessarily in accepting a breach of family life. And it would therefore need further explanation as to how this case law would support the applicant seeking a permanent residence in the Netherlands. Do you think this case law is also relevant in case the refusal to give permanent residence to your client would not necessarily lead to a separation, a rupture of the family?
text.607: Thank you, President. I have a question to the government, and it is related to the questions of judges and Power-Forde, and in a dissimilar. The government is, as far as I understand, submitting that, first of all, acknowledging that Article 8 rights are under considerations in the present case. They are also submitting that the Dutch government have not overstepped their margin of appreciation in examining this case, and that Article 8 issues have been thoroughly considered by the national authorities, whether you refer to the courts or the minister in deciding the applicant's case appears not to be quite clear, as their reasoning in the several accounts of applications seem to vary. But as a whole, from your submissions during the hearing today, it seems that you're saying that the consideration of Article 8 rights was already accepted as one involving a potential risk of alternative interference with Article 8 rights in both cases, whether the applicant should be separated from her family or whether it would result, a decision negative to the interests of the applicant would result in sending four Dutch citizens, including three children, to a country outside the territory where they were born and brought up. Do you see this as a matter of inevitable result as in view of the necessity to protect the public interests and the community interests? I would like the government to provide us with more information or views whether this is the manner in which they see that the potential interference with Article 8 rights has been thoroughly considered in your opinion.
text.608: Thank you, Mr. President. I do have one concrete question to the applicant. According to the chronology of events list we do have at our disposal in our files, it seems that the applicant, for the very first time, applied for a tourist visa to Netherlands on 19th of February 91. But her partner left to Netherlands at the end of October 91. So it was more than half a year before the partner left, and much more before they got married and had children. So my concrete question is, what was the reason for the applicant to apply for tourist visa in February 91?
text.609: My question is for both parties. At that time when applicant entered into Netherlands in 1997, the regulations in force did not require her to have obtained a provisional visa in Suriname before applying for a residence in the Netherlands. Why that law is not applicable in this case? Thank you.
text.610: Thank you, Mr. President. I have questions to the government. First of all, on the facts, I understand that Camp Bucca was U.S.-run camp. But yet, I will need clarification which state, the United Kingdom or the United States, or a combination of the two, was ultimately responsible for determining Tarek's status, the legality of his detention, and for ordering his release. My second question is again for the government, and this time on the law. In the case of person interned as a prisoner of war or as a civilian giving rise to a threat to security in the context of an international art conflict, should the requirements of Article 5 of the Convention be qualified or displaced by the provisions of third or fourth conventions? What is the meaning of displacement or qualification in this context? And to what extent, if at all, should the safeguards under Article 5, paragraph 1, 2, and 4 continue to apply? Thank you.
text.611: Thank you, Mr. President. As a follow-up to the questions by Judge Yudkivska, the question to the government that the applicants may want to comment as well. First, as to your thesis that the convention is displaced in the context of armed conflict, what value do you attribute to the International Courts of Justice statement of principle in the Wall advisory opinion, as repeated subsequently in a number of judgments? And what is the government's position as to whether this court should take an inspiration in those principles as identified by the ICJ? And that concerns the relationship between international humanitarian law and human rights law. That's the first question. The second question, if the government would be so kind to point out in terms of Geneva Convention No. 3 and in terms of Article 4, the groups of combatants, to which group would you attribute Mr. Hassan exactly?
