How does it happen that there is no – one clear record on the release? How does it happen that it is still uncertain which drop-off point exactly was he – well, dropped off? And do you consider that this lack of precision in the records is compatible with the principle under Geneva Convention No. 4, which requires to provide for safe release of civilians if Mr. Hassan is to be presumed a civilian? And finally, a small question. You are also aware that under Article 106 in Geneva Convention No. 4, there is an obligation to have the internees to make them contact their family, and there is also an information that, well, an independent body such as ICRC is informed of the presence of the particular internee. Could you provide the Court with an information what happened exactly in the case of Mr. Hassan in terms of contacts with the outside world, the outside institution? Thank you very much.
text.612: Thank you, Mr. President. I have three questions. First of all, two questions on the fact that are addressed to the government. Number one question, the government have informed the court that the military order in force at the relevant time called for a two-stage screening process for prisoners claiming to be innocent civilians with an initial interview to determine civilian status, and then a second interview to determine whether there were grounds to suspect that the person concerned was a security risk or a criminal risk. Well, did the two interviews carried out in respect of Tarek Hassan correspond to this two-stage process? Was it normal practice for one interview to be carried out by United States agents and one interview by the second one by United Kingdom agents? And if not, why did this take place in Tarek Hassan's case? The second question on the facts is, was Tarek Hassan detained in a compound specifically set aside for United Kingdom detainees at any stage while he was at Camp Bucca? Third question I have is a question on the law, and it is addressed to both parties. The question is, do the terms of Article 15 of the convention allow a state to derogate from its obligations under Article 5 in the context of an international armed conflict, such as the military intervention in Iraq? And would it be necessary for a state formally to lodge such a derogation in order for the court to interpret Article 5, so as to take account of the context and also of the applicable norms of international humanitarian law? Thank you, Mr. President. Those are my three questions.
text.613: Thank you. Only one question to the government concerning the circumstances of the release of Mr. Tarek Hassan on some date on the month of May of 2003. I see that in the observations of the government in page 15, the government concerning the place of release gives two alternatives, either Umm Qasr or Basrah. Well, there is some difference because Umm Qasr was the home of Mr. Tarek Hassan, it's two and a half kilometers from Camp Bucca, and Basrah is 50 kilometers north, a dangerous place. Would it be possible for the government to maybe to ask some additional clarification of where was it released, in which one of these two places, or give some brief accounting of what was the usual proceeding for release? I mean, where the prisoners were transferred to Iraqi authorities, or where they transferred to some ONG or the Red Cross, or where they just left in some village or some highway. I think that could be interesting information. Thank you.
text.614: Thank you. I would also just have one question about concrete detail. The applicants submit that Tarek Hassan was found, his body, his dead body was found, and he still had the ID, the UK ID tag in his pocket. So what was the practice of the British forces with ID tags as soon as they released prisoners? Were the ID tag usually taken away? What was done with a United States ID tag? What was the practice there? Thank you.
text.615: Thank you, Mr. President. My question is addressed to the applicant. What does the applicant think about Baroness Hale's remark in Al-Jedda that international humanitarian law does not displace international human rights law, but it qualifies international human rights law, in the sense that restrictions to the European Convention rights can be applied that are not foreseen in the European Convention? And insofar, the courts, these courts, we need is limited to control of the exercise of proportionality in the application of these rights. And my second question, also addressed to the applicant, is about to remark that the civilian was used as a bargaining chip, a bargaining instrument. I would like you to elaborate a little bit further on this topic. What is, in substance, the evidence that you can produce before us to sustain this statement? Thank you.
text.616: President, I have three questions, the first of them to Bosnia and Herzegovina. According to Serbia, Serbia and Slovenia referred to the 1997 act by which Bosnia and Herzegovina, and I quote, effectively acknowledged its liability for the contested savings, thereby creating a reasonable expectation on the part of the savers that they would recover their savings. Could you please comment on this legislation? To the Serbian government, Bosnia and Herzegovina referred to the 1998 Foreign Currency Savings Act and to the 2002 Public Debt Act, supporting, according to Bosnia, the position that by those two acts, you interfered with the savings of the applicants. Could you please elaborate on those acts? And finally, my third question goes to Slovenia. Bosnia and Herzegovina and Croatia referred to a series of judgments by Slovenian courts, including the Supreme Court of Slovenia, ruling in substance in favor of the applicants' legal positions. Could you please comment on those judgments? Thank you very much, Mr. President.
text.617: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a general question to all of the respondent states, with the exception of Macedonia. I note in our file and also as just explained by the Macedonian agent, that there was a possibility to acknowledge the liability over the deposits made in the territory of, in this case, Macedonia with the Macedonian banks. So the point of departure to my question to the other respondents is, given the example of one of the respondent states, would you sum up in a nutshell why in relation to the others, probably to a lesser degree, I would say, Croatia, why in relation to the other respondent states this was not considered and was not a possibility? And there I go back to Judge Sicilianos question in relation to Bosnia-Herzegovina, why there was a retraction of what seemed to be the earlier position similar to that to Republic of Macedonia. Thank you.
text.618: Yes, thank you. I would have three questions, two questions to all the governments and one question to Bosnia-Herzegovina. So the question to Bosnia-Herzegovina would be, is it true that in 1993 LB Sarajevo was registered in the company registry and that it was mentioned that the assets, rights and obligations of the LB main branch Sarajevo as the legal predecessor passed over to Ljubljana's Banka Sarajevo as the legal successor? Was it true and what was the meaning of this registration? And then to all the governments, for me it's still unclear when, by whom and with which explanation the decision was taken to freeze the accounts and what was exactly meant legally speaking by freezing. And the last question to all the governments, what were the necessary and at the same time the sufficient conditions respectively for your governments to restart negotiations and to bring them to a result acceptable by all? Thank you.
text.619: One is going to the government of Slovenia, but if others know, they might help. We heard about the Constitutional Act of 1994 and that the assets were transferred from the old Ljubljanska Banka to new Ljubljanska Banka. I assume it must be known how much of the assets were transferred. So this is one question. And the other question is related as well to the negotiations and NXC. Could you explain how do you understand what is the matter of negotiations according to the NXC? Thank you.
text.620: Merci, M. le Président. J'ai juste une question au gouvernement et aussi une question au requérant. Merci.
text.621: Thank you, Mr. President. Very short question for government. You have mentioned that there had now been a climate of impunity concerning these events in Romania in the 1990s. Can you answer that? How many persons had been finally convicted for the violation of human rights during this period? Thank you.
text.622: Thank you, Mr. President. My question goes to the government. We have heard today that the government thinks that the time limit of prescription expired before the complaint was lodged. And today it offered us two dates, June 1995 and June 1998. In the government's observations of July 2013, only one of these dates was presented, June 1995. In any case, the government also proposed or reserved the right in those submissions that I have referred to, the right to present to the Court examples of relevant case law following this interpretation. Where are they? Where are these cases? What are these precedents to sustain, to support the position of the government, the interpretation given to us by the government? And finally, if so, if the delay of prescription was already expired, can the government provide any explanation for the fact that the public prosecutor accepted the complaint in 2001 and went on and on with the investigation for many years? Is there any explanation to the fact that the public prosecutor did not find the complaint time-barred in 2001? Thank you.
text.623: Thank you. Questions to both parties. When exactly in time was the plea bargaining initiated? And second, who did initiate the friendly settlement negotiations with the prosecutor's office? Was it applicant's daughter, the applicant themselves, or the representatives of the prosecutor's office? Now question to the applicant. What is the applicant's explanation for the fact that the plea agreement had not been offered to the first applicant during the first four months of his detention in the same cell as the persons charged with his kidnapping in 2004, and another person serving a sentence for murder? And why did he decide to accept it only two months after his transfer to another cell? And now question to the government. What was the significance of the fact, if any, that the transfer of the factory shares and of the monetary payments had occurred before the procedural agreement was reached? Thank you.
text.624: Thank you. Thank you, President. I have some questions for the government and for the applicants, too. My first question is for the government. According to the Article 6793, second part point E of the Georgian Code of Criminal Procedure, before approving a procedural agreement, the court must ensure that the accused understands that he has constitutional rights, the right to a defense, the right to refuse to enter into agreement stating his admission of guilt, and the right to have the merits of his case examined. Could you explain whether the applicants mentioned rights, particularly the right to have the merits of his case examined? Was followed, whether there was examination of the merits of the case? And the second, the right to refuse to enter into agreement. As we can see from this provision of law, it is just in case of admission of guilt, so-called church bargain. What in case of sentence bargain, which was the case in the applicant's case, whether he could refuse entering into the agreement for the sentence bargain? This is the one question. And the second question relates to Article 34. My colleague already raised the question before getting these shares. In the mail exchange between the applicant's daughter and the representative of the prosecutor's general office, the prosecution authority was ready to return partially the factory shares to the applicant's family. My question is whether it was ex-gratia returning, or it was some kind of admittance by the prosecution authority of the arbitrariness committing during the investigation. And the second question, which is from the same email exchange, that the prosecution authority stated that the prosecution could unilaterally annul the player bargain and declare the first applicant wanted. What it means, whether it means the reopening of the criminal proceeding or not, and what was the grounds in the law. And the last question for the applicant, does the applicant understand that the possible finding of a violation under Article 6.1 of the Convention might entail the reopening of the criminal proceedings, as was asked by the government. And in this case, is this something he really wishes and is ready for such a course of action for the opening of the criminal proceedings? Thank you.
text.625: Yes, please. The government has mentioned the recently published judgment of the Czech Constitutional Court. And actually, you said that it's more a procedural violation that was found. I just want to quote a small paragraph out of this judgment and ask the government to comment on it. The right of parents to a free choice of place and mode of a delivery is limited only by the interest of safe delivery and health of the child. That interest cannot be, however, interpreted as an ambiguous preference for deliveries in hospital. So please, I would like to ask you to comment on this part of the judgment. And my second question would be also to the government. Are there any secondary aims of the legislation in protecting especially vulnerable women who might not be able to arrange safe birth at home properly? And in this regard, I would also like to know from the applicants why they emphasized that the women were highly educated. So is there a risk for women who are not that highly educated? And my last question would concern the statistics. The expert of the government has mentioned the risks that can occur, even if there was no risk visible in advance. So I would like to know, if you have any data, how often a normal birth has to be interrupted and the mother or the child given emergency aid in cases where no such risk was visible before. Thank you.
text.626: Thank you. We heard evidence today from the government, from an expert obstetrician, gynecologist, and I would be interested in hearing the applicant's response to the evidence that was produced today. The evidence was, if I understood it correctly, that at times an unanticipated risk can occur, such as an abruption during pregnancy, which requires delivery of the baby within minutes, if I understood correctly. For example, I think the example given was where there was a lack of oxygen to the baby, and perhaps in circumstances a baby may need to be delivered by a caesarean section. I would be interested in hearing the applicant's response to such evidence through the prism of a question, how would the best interests of the child be weighed in circumstances where such an emergency occurred, even where midwifery or medical care had been afforded by a state, but where such care was inadequate because, for example, it would take too long to get the baby to a hospital, the baby could suffer, I think it was either catastrophic or devastating consequences, if delivery was not effected within minutes. Thank you. How would the best interests of the child be served in the balance in those circumstances?
text.627: Thank you, Mr. President. Actually, I would like to continue somewhat on that question, but then more a question to the government, also focusing on the public interest that it is invoking. And I indeed heard Mr. Velebil referring to the need for urgent action in life-threatening situations. But my question is, having regard to that aim of the legislation, which arguably is a very legitimate one, why then does the law not go so far as to prohibit altogether deliveries at home? Why are mothers still allowed to give birth at home? And in the present situation, that means allowed and obliged to give birth at home in an unassistant way. In other words, why doesn't the state bring its reasoning to its logical end? Why does it stop somewhere before getting to that point?
text.628: Merci, M. le Président. Ma question est dirigée vers le gouvernement. Je comprends bien sûr toute l'importance que représente l'objectif de la santé de l'enfant. Le gouvernement a choisi la voie d'une prohibition indirecte, mais presque absolue. Certains Etats, à l'inverse, ont préféré la régulation à la prohibition. Cela signifie concrètement qu'ils ont établi une liste de conditions matérielles et médicales pour autoriser l'accouchement à domicile. Quelles observations le gouvernement fait-il à l'égard de tel système de régulation, d'une part au regard de l'objectif de l'intérêt de l'enfant, de la santé de l'enfant, et d'autre part au regard du principe de proportionnalité?
text.629: Thank you, Mr. President. I have some questions to both parties. And to the applicant. First, as a clarification of the facts and this question, since the applicant herself raised this aspect. And my question is, did the spouse object to the legal recognition of the current gender of the applicant? And my last third question to the applicant concerns the statistical information she refers to. The applicant in her referral requested to the Grand Chamber refers to the Rainbow Index, and that in that was said that 24 states transgender persons are permitted to remain married. My question is, what is the basis for this interpretation? Does it base on the idea that the states where there are no regulations at all for this situation have permitted same-sex marriages? And then I have two questions to the government. My question is, what effect does the turning marriage into same-sex partnership have in the population register to the child born in wedlock, born in marriage? Does it change something in his or her information in the population register? Will it mean that he or she is born out of wedlock, or if not born out of wedlock, will there be some other change in his or her status in that respect? And then I have a bit hypothetical question. Since same-sex marriages are permitted in the other Nordic states, and it might be quite possible that the same-sex marriage couple might move permanently to Finland, where same-sex marriages are not possible, how would they be registered into the population register? As a married couple or as a same-sex partnership? Thank you.
text.630: Thank you, Mr. President. May I ask the applicants two facts-related questions? First, there was reference to religious convictions, and I would like to know whether they contracted a religious marriage, and if so, when. And secondly, I see in the various applications and observations references to certain disadvantages of the current status. And I would like to have more information on this. I understand that you cannot change the number as long as you are married. I still have difficulties understanding the specific consequences. You referred to a travel card and also a passport problem. Is there no way to solve this problem? Is there no way to put in the passport the gender you would like to have maintaining the number? And are there any other consequences of the current status that are not mentioned here? Thank you.
text.631: Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to ask a small question about Article 14. We have heard and we could read a lot about an argument of the applicant stating that there is here an unequal treatment of persons in relevantly similar situations. The applicant says that there are similar situations. The government denies that there are similar situations to make a comparison. But in the observations of the applicant, and more specifically in paragraph 60 of the observations, it is also said that the two situations are sufficiently different in order to justify distinct regulation. I would like to ask the applicant to explain what is meant by this, because suddenly we have here different situations. Which situations could be meant here? And could we also have the government views on this? Thank you.
text.632: Thank you, President. I would wish to put a question to both parties. It concerns the per diem allowance. I would like to know more about the nature and the purpose of the per diem allowances paid to soldiers, reservists, in the Serb army. Are the per diem allowances of a salarial nature, or are they intended more as a compensation? And if so, a compensation for what? Thank you.
text.633: Thank you, Mr. President. As a clarifying question, I put the question to the both parties. What is actually the legal basis for the requested per diem? Is it the rules on travel and other expenses in the Yugoslav army and decision adopted by the chief of staff of the Yugoslav army? Or is it the agreement which was concluded in 11th January 2008? So that's my question. And if the answer is that they are both, so which was the legal basis for the agreement? Were these two rules? As a clarification, thank you. Thank you.
text.634: Thank you, Mr. President. To follow up on Judge Hirvelä's questions, we heard also now in the submissions, especially of the government, if the applicants could try systematically to answer to the following questions. First, are you maintaining that the per diems in 1999 were not paid to you? Why, if they were not paid at that time, why did you choose to go to the first instance court only in 2008? Thirdly, are you saying that 2008 agreement recognized that debt in payment of the per diems, or are you saying that this is a new or additional financial aid to which you should also be entitled to? text.635: Thank you, Mr. President. First, I have a question to the applicants. Could the applicants specify the number of days spent in the army during the critical period, that is for each and every one of them? And I have a question to the government and another one which occurred to me during the oral hearing. The first question is, could the government provide evidence on the exact dates and amounts of the transfers from the state budget to the municipalities enumerated in the agreement of January 2008? And the second question is, and I'm provoked by the intervention of the government agent because he put forward the idea of providing adequate solutions from the government to the reservists. May I kindly ask the government agent to specify what way and manner would they be satisfied and what sort of solution is envisaged by the government? Thank you.
text.636: Thank you, Mr. President. One question addressed to the Council for the Government. In the statistics you supplied with your letter, which the Government submitted with its letter of the 27th August 2013, there was a table indicating, among others, the incidents occurring in courtrooms as such. And there were incidents of a number of escapes from courthouses, a number of attacks on court staff, and a number of incidents of self-mutilation in courthouses for the period 2009-2013, which for the courthouse incidents, the figures are 4, 14, 20, 16, and 18. Could the Council for the Government explain these incidents in the courthouse? What is meant by self-mutilation? Could you give some examples of what is meant here by incidents of self-mutilation in the courthouse? And I refer to the figures, I repeat, 4, 14, 20, 16, and 18. Thank you.
text.637: Merci, M. le Président. Ma première question s'adresse aux représentants de la requérante. Au point 143 de vos observations finales, vous traitez de la question de la proportionnalité de la mesure d'interdiction que vous contestez. Vous écrivez notamment le gouvernement défendeur aurait pu adopter des mesures moins gênantes plutôt que de poursuivre celles qui portent le voile intégral en public. Pourriez-vous indiquer à la Cour de façon précise des exemples concrets de mesures moins restrictives que l'interdiction, qui, selon vous, auraient permis au gouvernement de parvenir aux objectifs qu'il estime légitimes? Mes questions suivantes s'adressent maintenant à la représentante du gouvernement. Le second paragraphe de l'article 9 énonce les buts légitimes qui seuls permettent d'apporter une restriction à la liberté de religion. À ce titre, le gouvernement invoque quatre objectifs légitimes. La sécurité publique, les exigences minimales de la vie en société, l'égalité entre hommes et femmes et la dignité de la personne. Je souhaiterais vous poser quelques brèves questions sur ces objectifs. S'agissant tout d'abord de la sécurité publique, est-ce qu'une mesure d'interdiction générale sur l'ensemble de l'espace public ne pose pas un problème de respect de la proportionnalité au regard de la sécurité publique? Vous nous avez indiqué à ce titre que le Conseil constitutionnel et la Cour de cassation avaient surmonté cette difficulté. Néanmoins, je remarque que dans l'étude qu'il a réalisée à la demande du Premier ministre, le Conseil d'État y a vu au contraire une difficulté pour respecter la proportionnalité. Pour les trois autres objectifs ensuite, c'est-à-dire les exigences minimales de la vie en société, l'égalité entre hommes et femmes et la dignité de la personne, s'agissant d'objectifs légitimes sur la sécurité publique, objectifs légitimes selon le terme que vous employez et non pas de buts légitimes comme le prescrit le second paragraphe de l'article 9, pourriez-vous indiquer à la Cour à quel but légitime chacun de ces objectifs légitimes se rattache? Ensuite, concernant l'égalité entre hommes et femmes, est-ce qu'il n'y a pas une difficulté à opposer ce principe d'égalité entre hommes et femmes à des femmes qui revendiquent la pratique interdite comme un droit? Enfin, s'agissant de la dignité de la personne, à ce titre, vous écrivez dans vos observations, je cite, que l'on se place du point de vue de la femme dont le visage est dissimulé ou de l'interlocuteur, il y a une atteinte à la dignité de la femme. Cette phrase suscite deux interrogations pour moi. Première interrogation, est-ce que c'est à l'État de décider qu'un comportement librement choisi est contraire à la dignité de celui ou de celle qu'il adopte? Et seconde interrogation, en quoi la dignité de ceux qui rencontrent une femme portant le voile intégral est-elle menacée? Merci, Monsieur le Président.
text.638: My first question goes to both parties, and it relates to the fact that it follows from the documents in this case, and in particular, those who describe the original behavior of the applicant, that she has not always been consistent as regards the use of the bird cup. And we have heard that the parties disagree as to whether she's a victim or whether she's not a victim for that reason. We are aware of that issue. Now the question relates to both parties concerning the merits of the case. This arguable, inconsistent manifestation of faith, could that have a bearing on the balancing of interests under Article 9, Paragraph 2 of the Convention? That was the first question to both parties. Now I have two questions only to the government. And the first question supplements Judge Potocki's, one of his questions. And it relates particularly to the aims involved under Article 9.2, which the government has referred to. And my question relates particularly to the alternative, the aim called the protection of the rights and freedoms of others. Could I kindly ask the government to elaborate a bit more on the applicability of that particular aim in relation to one of the stated purposes of the French Act, namely the social cohesion or the vivre ensemble problem? So that was the first question. The second question also, as I said, goes to the government. And that is something which has maybe not been so much focused on orderly. But it is about the tension or the episodes that we know from the documents have arisen in connection with concrete police control concerning the enforcement of the Act in connection with the full veil being, women being approached in the street wearing the full veil. Now this kind of tension, these kind of episodes may arguably indicate that the Act contributes to tension instead of social cohesion. Is this a problem in relation to Article 9.2 concerning the requirement that the purpose of the Act must be based on relevant and sufficient reasons? Thank you.
text.639: Merci, Monsieur le Président. Je n'ai qu'une question. Dans son témoignage, la requérante explique ce qu'elle appelle « compromise proposals ». Je cite, elle dit, « Firstly, I would be willing to accept restrictions regarding the visibility of the veils material. It has to wear only veils that were diaphanous see-through, thus ensuring that my facial features remained essentially visible. » Et dans la circulaire de mars 2011, on dit, on explique, « Les tenues destinées à dissimuler le visage sont celles qui rendent impossible l'identification de la personne. » Alors, ma question est la suivante. Est-ce qu'un tel comportement, comme proposé par la requérante, tomberait sous l'interdiction de la loi? Merci. Merci.
text.640: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions. And the first question could go to both parties. It stems from some of the statements in your both written and oral submissions. I would be very happy if you could clarify whether, in your view, a psychological violence was committed by the very fact that the girl, at the time, discovered that her intimate privacy, human dignity, if you will, might have been breached by the stepfather and the actual fact that the camera was found. So it's really, I would like your views on whether you consider that was, at that moment, an act of psychological violence. And my second question goes more to the government, but if the applicant have something to add, I think that would be appreciated. In view of the particular vulnerability of children against all types of violence, and I think we are in the presence not simply of the two private person relationship, but we are in the presence of a child, and the basic principle of human rights law that all decisions and actions of the authorities should have the best interests of the child in mind, could the government point out in what manner were the steps that you have just described, as taken following the complaints from the applicant, effective for the protection of a child, in a sense of both preventing that such acts occur in the future, and in a sense of giving some element of rehabilitation? Thank you.
text.641: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I have also two questions. The first goes to the government. Mr. Rönquist, if I got you right, you said that the gravity of the act by the stepfather was not such as to create a positive obligation of the state to criminalize it. And then you elaborated on the notion of significant flaws. May we take it that there was, in fact, a flaw in criminal law at the time of the acts, but that such flaw was not significant according to the government? Is this assumption a correct one or not? And the second question goes to the applicant, especially to Mr. Lewis. Since the time of the acts, there have been legislative changes and proposals for new criminal legislation. Do you think that the flaw you have referred to has been covered by legislation actually in force? Thank you very much, Mr. Chairman.
text.642: Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions to both parties. The government argue that the child pornography offense was applicable, at least in theory, to the facts. Assuming that this position is correct, why didn't the Court of Appeal use the provision of Chapter 30, Section 3 of the Code of Judicial Procedure and change the legal characterization of the criminal offense into this one? First question. Second question. According to Chapter 22, Section 7 of the Code of Judicial Procedure, the court can award compensation to non-pecuniary damages, even in the case of acquittal of the defendant. My question is, why the Court of Appeal did not use these Chapter 22, Section 7 of the Swedish Code of Judicial Procedure? And adding to that, if the government accept the view of the Supreme Court that there is no civil liability based directly on the convention, directly on provisions of the convention, when there are no other violations of domestic law? And I quote, from the decision of the Supreme Court of October 2007, an individual could not be obliged to compensate another individual directly on the basis of the convention. Does the government support this view? And as this view, this legal interpretation of national law object to the fulfillment of the positive obligations of the respondent state in this particular case. Thank you.
text.643: Thank you Mr. President. I have also two questions. The first one is sort of in the framework of comparative law because many countries in Central Europe at least and in France as well have something which is called personality rights. "Persönlichkeit Richten" in German, "le droit de personalité" in French. And by that kind of civil law standard, the right to one's own image would have been the minimum civil law tort claim which had been, the right which had been violated in this kind of situation without regard to any pornography aspect of the story. In other words, in some countries, if even in the public you are being photographed without your consent, unless you are a public figure, that might be a problem. And you cite of course, von Hanover, second grand chamber judgment in which a similar situation has occurred in this respect. And therefore my question is, does Sweden have this kind of personality rights tradition or registration in the context of the traditional tort law? My second question to the government is as follows. We are here talking about the rights of the applicant, but it is easy to imagine if we turn this situation like a glove inside out, that we might be dealing with a situation in which the perpetrator, the stepfather of the applicant here, would have been the claimant here, would have been the appellant here, applicant here. In other words, in that situation, if he had been convicted, he would have asked the reverse question because it would fall under article seven and it would be a question of whether the legality principle was or was not violated in this situation. Therefore, I know this is a speculative question, but to me it provides the mirror image of the situation. I'd be very grateful if the government could take the position on that kind of a question. Thank you.
text.644: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to ask two questions to the government. And the first question relates to the current situation of the applicant. The applicant, we know what her situation is with respect to the remission of her sentence. But I would like to know what the situation now is with respect to the days that she has worked. Do they have any effect on the duration of her sentence? Could that play a role with respect to a conditional release or in any other way? That's my first question. And the second question is about the point that was raised by you just at the end of your oral argument. If the judgment of the chamber would be confirmed by the grand chamber, what would be the concrete effects, not only for the applicant, but also for other prisoners currently detained in Spain? How many prisoners are affected? And what would be the effect, the concrete effect? Thank you.
text.645: Thank you. My question is first mostly to the government. Who was the legal representative, if any, of Mr. Câmpeanu? Or in other words, did Mr. Câmpeanu have any legal representative? And in that case, who was the representative? And the other question is for the applicant, concerning the events of the 20th February 2004, I mean the last day of the life of Mr. Câmpeanu. It seemed that, well, he was still alive. A team of monitors of the CLR visited the Poiana Mare Hospital. They saw directly Mr. Câmpeanu. They assessed his situation. And then they requested for him to be translated to another hospital. And the request was rejected. And it seems that this team made a report on the facts. Now, my question is possible at this time, so many years ago. First, did the centre have some previous knowledge of the situation of Mr. Câmpeanu? Or what was the reason for the visit to the hospital? Secondly, did the team then, after seeing Mr. Câmpeanu's situation, have a direct interview with the manager of the hospital? In this case, did they have a direct answer to their request? Or was it just that the manager did not take any decision? So, if possible, what were the terms of the relation of this team with the manager of the CLR, I mean of the hospital? Thank you.
text.646: Thank you, Mr President. I have a question to the Government. The representatives of the respondent state have referred to the mission of the Court under Article 34 of the Convention. They have underlined the meaning of the victim concept and its restrictions when it comes to admissibility. There is, however, another element in Article 34 to which I want to draw attention. Article 34 of the Convention on the Right of Individual Applications' last sentence reads, The High Contracting Parties undertake not to hinder in any way the effective exercise of this right. My question to the Government is related to that last sentence in particular, having in mind that there is little room between the act and the omission. The Government acknowledge the fact that Mr Câmpeanu was a particularly vulnerable person, that he was an orphan and that he had no legal guardian appointed when he turned 18. The Government note in their submissions that the CLR had the possibility to ask the domestic courts the lifting of Mr Câmpeanu's legal capacity and to ask for the nomination of a tutor pursuant to Articles 143 and 115 of the Code of Family. How could the Centre have done so before having even monitored his existence? Why should the State, on its own motion, not have taken the proper initiative to the appointment of a legal representative in order to secure that the vulnerable Mr Câmpeanu, who was confined and confronted with major decision-making concerning his health, would have had effective access to justice? In close connection to this, the matter can be raised whether a State that fails to provide proper representation to vulnerable persons in a situation like Mr Câmpeanu's thereby in any way hinders the effective exercise of the right to bring an application to our Court. Such hindrance may perhaps run against the obligation in Article 34, the last sentence. Does the Government hold a view on this matter? Thank you.
text.647: Thank you, President. My question follows those of judges López Guerra and Silvis and concern the applicant's representation. Had the applicant so wanted during his lifetime, could he in fact and in effect have obtained representation to defend his interests before domestic authorities and this court? For example, could he during his lifetime in fact and in effect have obtained representation to file the complaints which the Center for Legal Resources is today raising before us? Thank you.
text.648: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I do have two questions, one to the government and one to the applicant. Both are focusing on procedural aspect of the case. First question to the government. We do have in our materials information that in its decision of 15th of June 2006 concerning a criminal complaint lodged by the same NGO, CLR, on behalf of another patient, PC, that had died at the same hospital, PM Hospital, the High Court of Cassation and Justice dismissed the prosecutor's objection on the lack of standing of the same NGO. In its reasoning, the High Court held that the CLR did have local standing to pursue such proceedings deemed to elucidate the circumstances in which 17 patients had died at the same hospital in between January and February 2004. The question is, what is the difference between today's case and the case of PC where the High Court of Cassation and Justice recognized local standing? The second question is to the applicant. And it concerns the exhaustion of domestic remedies. In our case, in today's case, the prosecutor's office attached to the Calafa District Court appealed against the judgment. On 4th of April 2008, the Dole County Court allowed the appeal, annulled the judgment delivered by the Calafa District Court, and rejected the complaint lodged by CLR. Now, the court mainly relies on the conclusions of the forensic report and the autopsy report, as well as on the decision of the Doctors Association, and simply rejected it because there was no casual link between the medical treatment given by Mr. Câmpeanu and his death. My question is procedural. Why, in this case, CLR didn't go to the High Court of Cassation and Justice like CLR did in the case of PC? Thank you very much.
text.649: Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question for the applicant's representatives. If I understand well from the case file, at the domestic level, you're recognized as legal representatives of Mr. Câmpeanu. And today, before us, you are claiming to be recognized as indirect victims on the case. Could you explain to me the change on your position, why you claim today to be recognized as indirect victims, especially bearing in mind the Nancella case that you mentioned as well? Thank you.
text.650: Thank you, Mr. President. The government did not address the merits of the case. Thus, the silence of the government should be read as an acknowledgment of the violations imputed regarding Articles 2, 3, 5, and 8, leaving aside, of course, the question of admissibility of complaint. This is a question addressed to the government, of course. Thank you.
